PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Rifle Range, Malabar, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That over 67,000 men, women and students enjoy the pursuit of their sport and recreation every year at the Anzac Rifle Range at Malabar and have done so since 1967.

2. The people of Sydney through their membership of 41 clubs headquartered at the Anzac Rifle Range together with a number of other community, school and commercial groups, the police and armed forces will lose this community facility if the Federal Government proceeds to sell the Range to private developers.
3. The Australian Bicentenary Fullbore Rifle Championships are to be conducted at the Anzac Rifle Range in April 1988 as part of the celebration of Australia's Bicentenary.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should ask the Federal Government to retain the Anzac Rifle Range for the continued use and enjoyment of the people of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 October 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government. The Commonwealth has reneged on an established commitment as incorporated in Commonwealth legislation and benefit promise pensions are not being paid in full. In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of a pensioner and surviving dependants-into the 21st century for many. We consider this Government-induced penalty to be out of all proportion to the short-term `extraordinary circumstances of the economy' given as the reason for the discounting.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to:

1. limit the pension discounting effect of the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Act 1986 to the period 10 October 1986 to 1 July 1987 so that pensions are restored to the 9 October 1986 level as a base for the 1987 pension adjustment; and
2. consult with organisations representing pensioners before changing the terms and conditions of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Schemes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jones (from 15 citizens), Parer (from 14 citizens), Robert Ray (from 29 citizens) and Robertson (89 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:-
The costs of raising children are rising and the value of government provided economic assistance to families is declining.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:-
1. Restore family allowance payments to their 1976 real money value.
2. Provide for the regular and automatic indexation of family allowance payments.
3. Increase the value of the Dependent Spouse Rebate to $1851 per annum.
4. Amend the Family Income Supplement scheme so that its value is increased, its eligibility provisions widened and its withdrawal provisions eased.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education: Tuition Fees for Overseas Students
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament Assembled.
This Petition of the Undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. The introduction of the Higher Education Administrative Charge for tertiary students has and will continue to restrict access to higher education for a range of disadvantaged groups, particularly women, low income earners, mature age, and part-time and external students.

2. Students are being deterred from furthering their education because of the probable escalation of the $250 charge in future Budgets, preventing students' ability to plan the long term costs of their education.
3. The introduction of the Administration Charge is contrary to the ALP/ACTU Accord and ALP policy which states that the party ``will maintain the provision of free tertiary education.''
Your petitioners therefore pray that the annual administrative charge and Overseas students `visa charge' are abolished so that education will remain accessible to all.

PETITION.TITLE: Pre-retirement Incomes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and Honourable Senators assembled, the undersigned citizens call upon all Members to pay due respect to pensioners and other recipients of Social Security benefits and to Commonwealth Superannuants and to cease the constant erosion of our entitlements by the Government.

1. They ensure there is no further erosion of existing benefits to pensioners and other Social Security recipients and further that they honour their promise to Pensioners made before the last election that pensions be increased to a level equal to 25% of average weekly earnings.

2. That the Government reconsider its action in reducing by two per cent the level of superannuation paid to Commonwealth Superannuants, retired members of the Defence Services and other eligible Commonwealth Superannuants.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUGAR CANE LEVY BILL 1987SUGAR CANE LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 May, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate was adjourned last night I was acknowledging the part that the sugar industry had played in providing $600m worth of export sales and foreign currency. The Millaquin Sugar Co. and the producers of Bundaberg rum provide $60m a year in excise and sales tax. In my State of Queensland-from Beenleigh, just 20 or 30 miles from the Gold Coast, right up to north of Cairns-the sugar industry provides many jobs and much wealth. The fact that the industry has been in decline over, I believe, the last three years has meant that the rural coastal towns have felt the pinch, as many business people, including small business people, have not had the incomes that they enjoyed when sugar enjoyed a higher price overseas. The sugar industry needs all the help this Government can provide. Only a couple of days ago on the Australian Associated Press wire we received a message from some of our sugar representatives who were in New York on a deputation. They sent back a very alarming message that America was at the point of being a net sugar exporter rather than an importer. The quota has already fallen to around 75,000 tonnes a year.

SPEECH.PARA: The United States of America has subsidised its domestic sales by $15 billion during the last five years. It has also paid $85m in additional subsidies for farmers not to grow sugar. What alarms me-and a number of other speakers in the debate have picked up this point-is that under the American Farm Bill that $85m will be used to subsidise export sales. That must alarm everyone in this Senate and in primary industry in Australia. The European Economic Community is subsidising its beet sugar to the extent of $400 a tonne to compete in our markets. This is what we are facing, not only in the sugar industry but also in the wheat and grain industry-attacks on our markets from absolutely corrupted world prices. Last year, at the instigation of Ralph Hunt, an all-party committee visited America for very important discussions on subsidised exports of wheat and other primary products. I understand that this delegation met with moderate success. Another all-party delegation will be leaving next week for America, but the Government has not given this delegation a very high priority. It will be headed by a back bencher, an ex-potato farmer from Victoria. A delegation which is not supported by the Government appointing a Minister as its head will not receive very high priority in America.

We in the National Party see the American Farm Bill as potentially catastrophic to our rural export earnings and the survival of the rural sector. The US protectionist measures and export subsidy scheme being proposed will have a devastating effect on Australia. Every effort must be made to make US congressmen aware of the results of their actions and aware of Australia's point of view. Many arguments and influences can be used to put forward our case. Even if there were not, this US Bill is so crucial to the future of our major export earners that every last effort must be made to hammer at the doors of Congress until we are heard.

The deputation or delegation-whatever one likes to call it-must be headed by a Minister. It is an insult to the rural producers of Australia to send a delegation headed by a back bencher. The National Party has put forward its best delegate, the honourable member for Gwydir, Mr Ralph Hunt, who is well known in rural industry and well respected on both sides of this Parliament. He is once again going to America with a delegation. He will be supported by members of all other parties in the Parliament. Mr Cunningham, although I believe he is a fine man and may have picked up all sorts of useful information to use on the trip, lacks clout. I do not believe that the Americans will recognise him or give him the type of respect that is needed by this delegation. If we do not send someone in a senior ministerial position, the Americans will think we are not really worried and they will not give us the entrees to the people whom we need to see. The American Farm Bill has many implications, not only for the sugar industry but for all of rural Australia and for every primary industry. As I said before, the sugar industry contributes $600m to our export earnings, and that is down from $1.1 billion in 1982-83.

Part of the package to which this Government committed itself in the last election campaign was to put in place an underwriting scheme to set effectively the floor price for sugar at $230 a tonne for the 1986 season. This was touted as a wonderful and generous gesture on behalf of the Government. However, with the subsequent rises in world prices in the following years, the Government has managed to avoid contributing hardly anything to this support scheme. I think it made some small payment but, as the prices rose from between 2c and 3c a pound to 7c a pound, the price support scheme was not triggered. So the Government got away without making much of a contribution to the sugar industry.

It is good to see the Government coming through with a little money for research. Some Federal funds were made available last year for mill rationalisation, and those funds were matched, not dollar for dollar but 50c to the dollar, by the Queensland Government. So the Bill gives little enough back to an industry that has contributed so much to Australians over time. This industry has faced much hardship from our own Government in the last four years, particularly in terms of high interest rates, excessive taxes, fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax and the assets test. All of these factors have impacted very seriously on the industry.

One thing that this Government does not seem to understand is that, while it has removed the excise on diesel fuel for primary industry, 40 per cent of all fuel used on farms is still petrol. That varies from primary industry to primary industry. However, overall, 40 per cent of all the fuel used is petrol. The Government has been more than generous to other secondary industries: It has given $176m to the steel industry and $150m to the automotive vehicle industry. So, really, it has made only a token contribution to the sugar industry. However, this contribution is certainly acknowledged by the sugar industry, which supports the legislation.

I want to touch on another matter that is of serious concern to sugar growers at the moment. Over the last four years the Australian sugar industry has provided $10m to promote the image of sugar. Most of those funds have gone towards the television advertising campaign, `Sugar is a natural part of life'. That campaign has been very successful, and I am sure that everyone has seen it on television. It has changed the public's attitude towards sugar. The decline in consumption has stopped, and consumption has slowly started to pick up again. These industry funds also go towards sponsoring athletics and funding medical and dental research. The expensive struggle to promote the image of sugar and inform the public of its useful place in our diet is certainly not being helped by some Department of Health staff who cannot seem to overcome their prejudices and who continue to downgrade sugar in health guidelines, despite receiving numerous medical reports from overseas that sugar is really not a problem. Despite world recognised reports, such as that of the United States Food and Drug Administration published in August 1986 assuring the United States of America of the goodness in sugar and the important part that it can play in our diet, the Department of Health continues to tell the Australian population to avoid eating too much sugar. That is reasonable, I suppose, but it should also tell people to avoid drinking too much and eating too much of anything that is bad for health-too many fats and too much acid. Too much of anything is bad for a person. I wish the Health Department would not pick on sugar.

In its guidelines for the dietary requirements of Australia it recommends a reduction in the consumption of refined sugar. In the face of reports to the contrary, why is this prejudice from the Department of Health allowed to jeopardise the fortunes of a national industry which contributes so much to our economy? I cannot get a direct line on this matter, but it has certainly been mentioned to me by a number of people that the Department of Health is planning to push for an artifical sweetener, aspartame, to be mixed with sugar-a move that would dramatically reduce the demand for sugar. Aspartame is made in a laboratory. It is not natural; it is a chemical. There is no reason for it to be mixed with or replace any proportion of sugar. Already the consumption of 40,000 to 50,000 tonnes of sugar has been lost to artificial sweeteners in Australia.

It is about time the Department of Health got behind our established industries that have served us for years rather than sell out to the products of multinational companies. Once these artificially made products get a toehold in the market they pose a major threat to the natural products. The United States is a case in point. The United States consumption of refined sugar decreased from 10.18 million tonnes to 7.36 million tonnes in 10 years, from 1976 to 1986, while consumption of corn sweeteners increased from 3.238 million tonnes to nearly 8 million tonnes in the same period. Artificial sweeteners also experienced a significant increase, from 13.56 million tonnes in 1976 to 15.52 million tonnes in 1986. The pattern of sugar demand has undergone a considerable structural change with the advent of alternative sweeteners. This has reduced the demand for natural sugar products, particularly by industries which prefer to use the cheaper fructose made from corn and products such as aspartame which now control 25 per cent of the gigantic beverage market.

We must be very wary of the havoc that giant multinationals can wreak on our sugar industry since most of our sugar goes towards beverage production both here and in the United States. Yet Australia's Department of Health is considering plans to replace some of Australia's natural sugar with chemically formulated products made in Japan by giant multinationals. This is something about which I believe every honourable senator should be concerned, and every member of Parliament should be lending a voice saying that we are behind Australian farmers and that we will not see some chemical taking the place of our natural sweeteners. This product has a shorter shelf life than natural sugar, and health authorities in the United States are already expressing some doubts about this product. A recent study in America showed that heavy consumption of aspartame increases the occurrence of behavioural disturbances and birth defects. It was a very serious problem.

I wish the deputation to the US Congress every success next week. The Senate is represented-I believe that Senator Macklin will be going to Washington. On behalf of all rural industries, particularly the sugar industry, I take the opportunity to wish the deputation success. However, on behalf of all primary industry people, I express sorrow that the Government has not seen fit to send one of its Ministers to support the campaign. This is a cosmetic exercise by the Government, which would not even spare the Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, or any other senior Minister to go to Washington and lend the deputation some degree of credibility on behalf of Australian rural producers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sugar Cane Levy Bill 1987 and the Sugar Cane Levy Collection Bill 1987 are being dealt with cognately by the Senate. They are machinery Bills and provide for the collection of a levy of 5c a tonne on cane delivered and accepted into the mills; 2 1/2c to be paid by the grower and 2 1/2c to be paid by the miller, with the collection by the mills. The money raised will be matched dollar for dollar by the Commonwealth and is to be spent on research, which is put out to public tender, into the sugar industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition supports this move. The sugar industry is very important to Australia. In a competitive world it is only through research that we can maintain our markets. The sugar industry is one of the great export earners of Australia, and it has been for a very long time. That has been the primary effect; it has also had a beneficial effect on the standard of living of all Australians because of the export earnings it has provided. It has had a very important secondary effect that is lost on many people living in the southern States. First of all, it has provided a very strong decentralisation factor in the population of Queensland. In fact, the population in the tropical areas is primarily related to this great industry. It has generated a great deal of employment and a great demand for goods and services.

I have had a long non-financial involvement with the sugar industry. Before and after the First World War-long before I was born-my father was a sugar grower. One of my uncles was a scientific adviser with the Queensland Cane Prices Board for a record period of nearly 40 years. Another uncle was Secretary to the Cane Prices Board. I have many friends in the industry and I grew up in a cane growing area. The history of the sugar industry is an absorbing part of Australia's development. It starts right at Australia's origin. It is interesting to note today, 14 May, the day after the day the First Fleet sailed in 1788, that the First Fleet carried some sugar cane from South Africa when it arrived in Australia. The origin of successful sugar growing in Australia goes back to 1862, when John Buhot from the West Indies first grew some cane in Brisbane-successfully. In 1864 John Buhot and Captain Louis Hope, whom history regards as the father of the Australian sugar industry, established a plantation at Ormiston with a juice mill. That is taken as the starting point for the industry in Australia. A couple of years later, in 1866, a mill was built at Maryborough, which would have been the old Yengarie mill. When I was a boy, the brick smoke stack of that mill still existed at Yengarie just west of Maryborough and I think it still exists today. From there the industry spread up the Queensland coast. In 1868 a mill was built in Mackay and mills were also built along the northern rivers area of New South Wales. In 1869 the famous Colonial Sugar Refining Company, CSR, entered the field as a mill owner. The sugar industry was firmly established in Queensland by the time of Federation. As my uncle used to tell me, but for the sugar industry Queensland would never have joined the other Australian States and become part of the Commonwealth of Australia. Victoria was buying sugar in Mauritius and Hong Kong and putting a heavy levy against sugar produced in the Queensland colony. It was the promise of free trade between the States, and therefore the promise of markets in the populated areas of Sydney and Melbourne, that was the determining factor in Queensland joining the Federation in the latter part of the last century.

After Federation the industry embarked on a path which led to its becoming the most heavily controlled and legislated industry in Australia. The year 1915 saw the Sugar Acquisition Act passed by the Queensland Government, and an agreement on sugar was negotiated between the Commonwealth and Queensland governments. At the same time an embargo was placed on the importation of sugar. That embargo has been most valuable to the Australian sugar industry in protecting it from competition from sugar produced in other countries. It has been a controversial issue, but I think on balance there have been financial benefits to the Australian community from the embargo. That embargo is still in place today and sugar cannot be imported. In 1923 the Commonwealth handed over control and legislative powers in relation to the sugar industry to the Queensland Government and the Sugar Board was established. In 1924 Australia started exporting sugar. In 1929 the `mill peak' system, with controls on production, was introduced and in 1937, although not implemented at the time, the first international sugar agreement for marketing was negotiated.

The history of the sugar industry is one of great and notable families. The history of the Youngs at Fairymead in Bundaberg; the Drysdales in the Burdekin delta; the Gibsons in the Bundaberg area; the Braddocks in the Maryborough area. It is a history of great companies, such as the CSR company, Pioneer Sugar and Australian Estates at Kalamia in the Burdekin delta. It is a history of piracy with characters like `Bully' Hayes back in the latter part of the last century and their blackbirding and the Kanaka labour being recruited around the islands and being brought into this country. Today the industry stretches 2,000 kilometres from Mossman north of Cairns right through to Grafton in the northern part of New South Wales. Ninety-four per cent of its production is centred in Queensland; three-quarters of all sugar is produced in three great areas. There is the Ingham-Mossman area, which straddles Cairns; the Burdekin delta area, around Ayr and Home Hill; and the Mackay area with its five mills.

Sugar is very much a family industry. Ninety-five per cent of cane production comes from family-owned farms and only 5 per cent from plantations owned by proprietary millers. That 95 per cent involves about 6,000 farms and provides employment for about 45,000 people. There is a very big capital infrastructure behind it with 31 mills, two of which have disappeared in the recent past. The Bundaberg Sugar Company closed Qunaba, and transferred its quota to other mills in the group. Qunaba is an interesting mill. It was an old mill that got its name from the fact that it was the Queensland and National Bank that bought the mill from its owner two years after it was created back in the last century. Recently the Goondi mill in the Johnson River area has been closed down.

Let me give the House some statistics on the industry. There are about 25 million tonnes of cane crushed in the 22 weeks of the crushing season. That represents a production of about 150 tonnes of raw sugar per active worker in the industry. I said that it is a capital intensive industry. About $300,000 is invested per worker. It is a big consumer of fertiliser, fuel, chemicals and machinery. The industry has been characterised by growth ever since its inception. The statistics demonstrate very graphically the difference between what we were producing in 1900 with what was produced in 1980. In 1900 35 tonnes of sugar cane per hectare was grown, which yielded 3.7 tonnes of sugar per hectare. In 1980 the figure had risen to 82 tonnes per hectare of cane, which yielded 11.5 tonnes of sugar per hectare. In the last decade alone the average area per grower has increased by 30 per cent and the total area harvested has increased by 21 per cent. The qualification must be applied that there was a planned expansion of the industry through that period, but that does not negate the increased production per hectare.

The industry yields about $800m a year, of which $600m is export earnings. That $600m, as I said at the outset of my speech, is very important to the Australian economy and our standard of living. It has become particularly important at present, given the big spending, high taxing Government we have and the absolutely crippling overseas debt that the Australian Labor Party has given us. It has trebled our overseas debt in the last four years. We will not reduce that overseas debt by fictitious cuts in prospective expenditures, as the Treasurer, Mr Keating, announced last night. We will reduce that debt by hard work, by earning money through exports. The sugar industry will play a very crucial part in working off that debt for Australia. In regard to the $600m we are earning at present through sugar exports, only 28 per cent of our markets are covered by long term contracts. Seven per cent of the sales are covered by special quotas, but the great majority of sales we make are free market sales on world markets. They are spot sales-sales that are made as the opportunity arises. So we must be efficient if we are to sell this product.

One of the characteristics of the industry is that, relatively speaking, it is very efficient. It does face difficulties now. It has faced difficulties for some years and, as far as one can see, there will be difficulties in the future in fighting for markets. I said previously that it is the most tightly regulated industry in Australia. I think we have reached the stage where there must be some freeing up of the restrictions on the industry to make it more responsive to the changed markets to which we are selling, and changed conditions. It was not so many years ago that the International Sugar Agreement gave us some protection in the markets to which we were selling around the world. The International Sugar Agreement has not operated for some years and it is most unlikely that any regular marketing scheme will be re-established in the near future. So, we are on our own and we must be efficient. The thing that determines sales is the price. In order to make a profit, having regard to the price that is being offered, we simply must be efficient. That leads back to the importance of this legislation and the relevance of research in maintaining a competitive advantage.

I come back to the over-regulation of the industry at present. We have totally controlled internal production and we are selling on a totally unregulated external market. We must be flexible. We must be able to get the cost even lower. The nature of the industry is such that protection for the growers and the millers cannot be achieved through diversification, in the way this can be applied to other forms of primary production. The efficiency of the sugar industry depends on volume. It depends on having somebody deliver the crop to the mill and the mill being able to operate more or less at peak efficiency all the time. Growing tomatoes, tropical fruits or something like that, which other farmers might do, will not help. But if the sugar producers start to reduce their volume of production, and do not meet their assignments, the mills become inefficient and the cost of production inevitably goes up. So diversification is not of that much value within the sugar industry.

There is an argument, though, for diversification as to the use of the product. I think it is a matter of great regret that the sugar industry would not accept the advice that some of us tendered to it a few years ago at the time of the fuel crisis in the early part of the 1980s. I addressed many meetings of sugar growers and millers and some of them stick in my memory quite vividly. I remember the anger that various growers and some of the leading millers in the States demonstrated towards me in public when I tried to interest them in getting a market share in ethanol production. The proposition that I was putting to them was very simple; that it would be a guaranteed outlet for a minor part of their production, but a stable part that would be there year in, year out. The industry at the time viewed any move towards ethanol production as bringing about a diminution of return, because sugar prices on the world market were then very buoyant and growers could sell all that they were producing. I believe that had the industry in the early part of the 1980s accepted a figure from the Government and locked the Government into taking a fraction-it certainly would have been a minor part of production-of the raw sugar at a fixed price for ethanol production, and had the Government co-operated by allowing the successful mix of ethanol with motor spirit to be sold on an excise free basis, which would have made it price competitive with ordinary motor spirits, the industry would have had a valuable market there. I think the national interest would have been served, because I believed in the early 1980s, and I believe just as strongly today, that Australia must have 100 per cent self-sufficiency in fuels. Part of that comes from oil wells, but the supplementation of our fuel supply should come in part from ethanol and in part from methanol, and I think from coal-but that is another story.

In recognising the need for flexibility, I think there is a general acceptance on the millers' side that things need to be changed. There is a marked reluctance on the growers' side to change the way they do things in any way at all. The Federal Government, to give it its due, came up with a workable and constructive scheme of reconstruction over the last few years but, regrettably, the Queensland Government would not co-operate at all. The Queensland Government, regrettably, played politics rather than look at the issues involved and the principles of supporting one of Australia's great export industries. It took the advice of the growers who, as I said before, as a whole are not prepared to change. One of the tragedies of the increasing price that we face at present is that there are a number of growers about who think we will go back to the boom days. We will not go back to the boom days in the foreseeable future. I hope that we will have an improvement in the world price, but it is going to be limited and we will not go back to the boom conditions that we had in the early part of this decade.

What are the difficulties that face the sugar industry on world markets? As I said before, the great majority of our product-80 per cent-is sold overseas, so we are dependent on those markets. The difficulties come from two sources-subsidies and substitution. The European Common Market has played as much havoc with the sugar industry as it has with the rest of primary production through its support programs for the farming groups principally in France and to a secondary degree in Germany. Its policies have enabled beet sugar production to be economically attractive to farmers in that area. Beet is a crop that is in many ways simpler to grow than sugar cane, and historically the greater production of refined sugar in the world has come from the beet source rather than from the cane source. Most of the beet sugar, of course, has been used internally and has not been out on the world markets, and most of the world markets have been sourced on cane sugar. The European Economic Community has produced great problems for us by encouraging the overproduction of beet sugar, which in turn has been dumped on world markets. The United States of America has not been blameless in this either, but I would differ with some of the other speakers on this Bill who have tended to focus on the US as the sole cause of the problems for the sugar export market, thus losing a sense of perspective in the matter.

The US has not helped and certainly has played a contributing part but, if I was assigning blame, I would be more concerned about the European Economic Community than I am about the US. The basic problem in the US is that the farm lobby has been supported almost without constraint by the US Government. In 1985 Senator Gary Hart and Senator Bob Dole from Kansas moved the Hart-Dole amendment to the 1985 Food Security Act to compensate any sugar grower who was left high and dry by bankrupt refiners. Nelson Bunker Hunt had a big splurge on the Great Western sugar refinery and there were all sorts of contracts outstanding as a result. The Government, through the US Department of Agriculture, picked up the debts, and that little exercise cost the US taxpayer $54m-which was almost as much as the then Australian Federal Budget. On top of that there has been the basic selling pattern of maintaining an artificially high sugar price within the US to protect the sugar growers in that country. That has had the very serious effect of making possible substitute sweeteners which is the other great problem that we face.

Subsidies are one problem but sugar substitutes are the other. If sugar in the US had been allowed to be sold at the cost of production plus a small profit or at world price rather than being jacked up to an artificially high level to give returns to what is collectively an inefficient industry, the great substitution industries, those using high fructose corn sweeteners and aspartame, would not have developed, because it is all a matter of economics. Aspartame in particular cannot be produced at the same cost as we can produce fructose from cane sugar, and that is also the case with corn syrup sweeteners. Those products are not competitive with the world price of sugar and they would not have got off the ground if the US had practised the free market policies that it is so keen to talk about in its trading relations with Japan and all other countries of the world. Nevertheless, the US market was, and still is, important to Australia and it is one of great fluctuation.

About five years ago we were selling nearly 600,000 tonnes of raw sugar a year to the US. This year the figure, I think, is down to about 70,000 tonnes, which is a very great drop in five years. We are very keen to maintain the US market because we get a better price selling there than we get in the world market, so we would like to continue to have access to it. However, as well as the movement towards protection within the United States, there is also a political movement to take product from the Caribbean and those countries close to the US. One can understand that sentiment within the US legislature because these countries are America's neighbours, they have a low standard of living and must have a market for their products-and sugar happens to be one of the commodities that they can grow with relative ease. Be that as it may, at the end of the day and whatever the difficulties, we must meet the market. It is no good whining and saying that the European Common Market is unfair and that the Americans are unfair. This situation will be a fact of life into the foreseeable future. Whether it is the Americans or the Europeans there will always be someone subsidising and dumping sugar. We have a market and we want to hold on to it, and we can do that if we are efficient enough.

That leads to that whole place of research in relation to the sugar industry. The sugar industry has always recognised the importance of research. Cane growers at present contribute 19.2c per tonne to the Bureau of Sugar Experiment Stations, a research body dedicated to crop improvement and milling techniques. Eight cents a tonne goes to disease and pest control. The millers contribute 8c a tonne to the Sugar Research Institute in Mackay headed by Dr John Allen.

The measures we are debating today have the support of the sugar industry. The Australian Cane Growers Council in 1985 resolved to approach the Commonwealth Government for the establishment of a sugar industry research council under circumstances in which the council agrees to an initial levy of 5c per tonne of cane to be paid on a dollar for dollar basis by canegrowers and mill owners. The Sugar Industry Working Party report, the Savage report, commissioned by the Queensland Government, again supports the need for further research into the industry.

Sugar cane is attacked by a variety of pests. Before that, however, the quality of the cane itself has to be considered. The Australian industry has done intensive research into developing strains of cane which grow in the varying conditions of the different districts in Australia. Those districts differ enormously. The irrigation of the Burdekin can be compared with the very high natural rainfall area around Mossman and the Herbert River. The relatively low rainfall areas in the northern areas of New South Wales and the Rocky Point, Moreton Central and Maryborough areas can be contrasted with what is to be found further north. So the quality of the cane and its ability to grow in these different climatological situations, its yield, the commercial content of sugar in the cane in these different areas are all factors to be considered. A lot of research has been done on these matters. Very useful strains of cane have been developed to suit these various areas.

Cane is subject to a large range of diseases, as one would imagine of anything growing in a tropical area. Pests, parasites and other sorts of afflictions are quite common. A great deal of work has been done through the various research bodies to get on top of these. The great organisations in this respect have been, firstly, the Bureau of Sugar Experiment Stations, headed by Dr Owen Sturgess, which has a very great record of achievement in support for the industry; and, secondly, of course, the Sugar Research Institute under Dr John Allen, on the milling side, which has also made very great strides over the years to support the industry. One would hope that these established operators in the field will be able to compete for and gain the majority of the funds that are available for tender. The research is industry specific and, while anyone can come in, a great deal of background knowledge is necessary. But I am a great believer in competition, and I think that the two institutes I have named will not shrink from meeting the competition in the market-place to carry out the relevant research to support the industry.

Research is needed not only in the growing and milling fields; further research must also be done on advertising to sell the product, on transport and handling, and on marketing. On the marketing side, I would like to see the industry take more seriously moves towards selling refined sugar. As we see it, it would add to the value of the product, but this has been resisted collectively right across the industry-for some very good reasons. There are many technical problems with selling refined sugar. It has been easier for us in the past to sell raw sugar, but sales of refined sugar is something that we will have to look at quite seriously in the future-although it may be that the majority of sales will always be raw sugar sales.

I would like to compliment the industry on the way it has reacted over the last few years to the cumulative effects of the various health groups which have been saying that sugar is bad. The way the industry responded to that was through very attractive and intelligent advertising. Features on television, built around the theme of sugar being a natural part of life, have countered the elements in the Australian community unfavourable to the use of sugar, and this has been reflected in increased sugar consumption within the Australian community. We support this legislation. We believe it is essential, and we believe the benefits of this initiative will flow on to maintain the standards of living of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to speak for very long. In fact, I did not intend to say anything at all until I started listening to Senator MacGibbon. Whatever his faults may be, I had always thought before that Senator MacGibbon was fairly rational about economic questions. SPEECH.PARA: Cargo cultism in recent times has been camouflaged by the suggestion that the petranol mix-by which people normally mean a 9:1 mixture of ethanol and petrol or motor spirit-should be marketed free of excise. The other general comment I want to make is that, in terms of technical efficiency, the sugar industry is unsurpassed in the world.
