SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Olympic Insignia Protection Bill. The Opposition supports the Bill, which is an important step forward in providing scope for greater financial independence for the Australian Olympic Federation and, therefore, the development of Olympic sport and, indirectly, other sport in this country. The purpose of the Bill is to protect the Olympic insignia-that is, the five interlocking rings and other designs used by the Australian Olympic Federation-from use by persons not connected with the Olympic movement. As the explanatory memorandum to the Bill states, the purpose of the Bill is to enable the Australian Olympic Federation to regulate the use within Australia of the Olympic symbol, that is, the five interlocking rings, and other nominated Olympic designs. The Bill also provides that these insignia shall not be registered under the Designs Act 1906. The Bill invests the Australian Olympic Federation with a monopoly in the insignia and provides that they are not to be used in trade or commerce unless a licence for such use has been granted by the Federation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Olympic Federation has done a wonderful job over decades. The Federation being established under the charter of the International Olympic Committee, it is its responsibility to promote the Olympic principles in Australia and to co-ordinate the massive effort that is required to ensure that Australia is effectively represented every four years at both the summer and the winter Olympic Games by the best possible team of sportsmen and sportswomen in this country. The success of the Federation and the athletes it has supported has been one of the great sporting achievements of this nation. It is a task that the Federation has undertaken for 90 years now since the first modern Olympics in 1896. The changes that have occurred in that period are enormous. The growth of our competitors in terms of numbers has been staggering. It is interesting to note that Australia has the great achievement of being one of only three nations whose athletes have been represented at each and every one of the 23 Olympiads to date. The Federation's responsibility has increased greatly over the period of the modern Olympiads. As I said, the size of the teams that the Federation has had to prepare has increased greatly.

It was not that long ago-only 40 years-that the 1948 Olympic Games were held, and I should think that many of us would remember those games very well. In those games Australia was represented by 88 athletes and officials as compared with 1984, only 35 years on, when we were represented by 335 athletes and officials-a fourfold increase in that period. We have as a nation had an outstanding record at the Olympics. On a per head of population basis, we are certainly amongst, and may even be, the most successful of all the nations in the world in the Olympic sporting area.

As well as the changes that have occurred in that sense-the growth of the number of athletes that the Federation has had to support, deal with and build on-the environment within which the AOF has to set about its responsibilities has also changed dramatically over the years. The world of sport has become much tougher and much more competitive. It is the Federation's task to respond to these pressures in a way that strikes and maintains a balance between the desire to succeed and the no less important values and principles for which sport is rightly renowned. I emphasise that point.

We in this nation are often critical when our athletes do not perform quite as well as we might have wished if we wanted to win gold medals or achieve certain successes on the sporting field. That is in many ways a secondary consideration to the values and the principles that those athletes and those who support them bring to their endeavours, and we should, in my view, never judge our success in the sporting arena purely on the basis of the medals or the successes that we achieve. I think one of the challenges that sport and other aspects of Australian life probably face in 1987 and the years ahead is to maintain the values and the principles on which those endeavours and attempts are based.

The Opposition recognises the vital contribution that the Australian Olympic Federation has made and will, we hope, continue to make to Australian sport. The Federation has on its board leading persons from all walks of life who are deeply committed to the furthering not only of the Olympic sports but of all sports in Australia. The President of the AOF, Kevan Gosper, the Managing Director of the Shell Co. of Australia Ltd, who was, in his own day, a great athlete and an Olympic athlete, has put a great deal back into the sport which he dearly and clearly loves so well. Phil Coles, the Secretary-General of the Federation, was another great Australian sportsman. Mr Gosper and Mr Coles are also the Australian representatives on the International Olympic Committee, and Mr Gosper was recently elected to that Committee's executive. Mr Gosper and Mr Coles have taken over from Syd Grange and Judy Patching, both of whom retired at the end of 1985 and both of whom I, on behalf of the Opposition, would like to thank again, even though it is a little while since they retired, for their tireless and total commitment over the years in promoting Australia and the Olympic movement. Kevan Gosper, Phil Coles and others have a very hard act to follow in emulating the achievements of their predecessors.

The Opposition also wholeheartedly supports the Federation's endeavours. It has to be largely self-financing. Successive governments have made substantial financial contributions to the Federation, but importantly it has to be responsible for much of its own fund raising. That is an important part of the Bill that is before us. For the 1984 Olympic Games the Government provided $1.4m towards the preparation of the Olympic team. The total cost of that exercise was $5m. The proportion contributed by the Government, at $1.4m, was 28 per cent. The remaining 72 per cent, or $3.6m, was raised by the Federation. The $1.4m provided by the Government in 1984 compares with $40,000 provided by the then Government only a quarter of a century ago, in 1960. That gives an indication of how much the costs involved in preparing Olympic teams rose in the intervening period.

As I said, the Federation was responsible in 1984 for raising the $3.6m balance of funds required. It did so through a range of marketing programs which involved the use of its various insignia. I understand that for 1988 the estimated cost of preparing the Australian team for the Olympic Games in Seoul and Calgary will by $10m compared with the $5m for 1984. I also understand that the Federal Government will be providing something like $2m towards that effort-that is an increase from the 1984 contribution of $1.4m but it is a decrease in percentage terms from 28 per cent to 20 per cent of the total cost, which will leave the Australian Olympic Federation to find the other $8m. I also understand that that fund raising exercise is well under way and is proceeding satisfactorily to date, although it will obviously need a further boost as it goes along, as 1988 is not far away. I understand that the Federation has already raised nearly $2m of the $8m that it is required to find. On behalf of the Opposition, I congratulate the Australian Olympic Federation on its very responsible and professional approach to all its duties, including its financial responsibilities. The Bill that we are debating today should help particularly in that latter capacity.

Having mentioned the escalating cost of participating in the Olympic Games, I turn to how the Federation will go about financing it. It has embarked on a major marketing program based on the licensing and the franchising of the Olympic insignia. This campaign will provide an ongoing and major source of funds and will help to ensure that Australia is represented in future Olympic Games in a fitting and proper way. It may be seen as a measure of the success of the Federation's marketing program that it has encountered problems with certain persons whose use of the Olympic insignia suggests very deceptively to the public that they or their products are associated with and help fund the Olympic movement. Given the Federation's responsible efforts to ensure its financial independence, such unauthorised and deceptive use must be prevented. In this Bill, which, as I said, the Opposition supports, the Government has decided that, as with the Advance Australia logo and the Bicentenary logo, legislation is necessary to aid in securing the rights of the Federation to its insignia and to prevent them from being used in a false and deceptive manner. It will also ensure that if they are used deceptively the Federation will have a speedy and simple mechanism available to curtail such wrongful conduct. Those are the purposes of this Bill. The ability to ensure exclusivity of use is also a matter of critical importance to the Federation when negotiating the best terms for its licensing agreements.

It is worth pointing out that this protection that is being afforded in this Bill is not totally without precedent in Australia. Prior to the 1956 Olympic Games in Melbourne the Government of the day, the Menzies Government, brought in legislation prescribing the Olympic rings, the Olympic motto and the words `Olympic champion' as prohibited trade marks. That is, they could not be registered under the then trade marks legislation. That did not prevent persons using those insignia as unregistered marks, and in these commercial times when sponsorship plays such an important role greater protection is required.

I take this opportunity also to congratulate the Lord Mayor of Brisbane, Sallyanne Atkinson and her team on their enormous and very nearly successful effort in trying to attract the 1992 Olympic Games to Australia. It was a great pity that they did not succeed. They must rest happy in the knowledge that no one could have worked harder or more productively to attract those games. It was universally acclaimed in Australia as a great bid and it was a great pity, as I said, that in the end it was not successful.

I have already mentioned in broad terms the main features of the Bill. It provides that the Australian Olympic Federation shall have a monopoly in design in Australia with respect to the Olympic rings, thus ensuring its right to use the rings in relation to any article. The Bill also provides that the Australian Olympic Federation shall have ownership of the copyright in the Olympic rings. Those provisions will not impede the fair use by the media of the rings for the purpose of disseminating information on the Olympic movement or its activities. The Bill provides for the Australian Olympic Federation to grant licences to use the insignia in return for a payment or other consideration. That provision contains some of the fund raising elements for the Federation. I am glad to say that in the Bill it is recognised that some persons use the Olympic rings in conjunction with their goods and that they have done so for a considerable period. Those persons have never held themselves out as being connected with the Olympic movement and they do not increase their activity in Olympic Games years to take advantage of the use of these insignia. They have not therefore impeded in any way the Australia Olympic Federation's fund raising campaign when that has been at its peak. The rights of those persons to use the insignia are correctly recognised, and the Bill expressly preserves existing property rights in the insignia.

As I mentioned earlier, neither the Bill nor the Olympic Federation restricts the campaign to the Olympic rings themselves. The Federation has developed a range of logos for which it grants licences, the most recent and familiar being `Willie', the koala insignia. Other logos include the Olympic rings and boomerangs and the Olympic rings and a kangaroo. The Bill provides for these logos to be registered as Olympic designs and the registration provides similar protection to that provided for use in the Olympic Games. The Bill seems to us to be very sensible. It should assist the Olympic Federation in its fund raising activities. Also, in the broader sense, it should stabilise and ensure the Federation's integrity and prevent people from taking advantage in any unscrupulous way of the Olympic insignia.

I wish to comment briefly on the Australian Institute of Sport. To the extent that it improves the situation of the Australian Olympic Federation, this Bill has a pervasive effect on sport-not just Olympic sport-throughout the nation in a variety of ways. Throughout its history Australia has had many wonderful athletes. On a per head of population basis, over the years we have certainly ranked among the most significant sporting nations in the world-if not the most. This is not only in the Olympic arena but in many other spheres as well. Over the years we in this Parliament have had the privilege of having in our ranks some world famous sportsmen. We have one in the House of Representatives at the moment-Dr Ric Charlesworth, who is probably the greatest hockey player that this nation has ever produced. He has been a wonderful and inspiring leader of the Australian hockey team for many years and has done an enormous amount, not just for hockey but also for sport and sportsmanship in Australia. Many of us would remember with great affection `Oppy', Sir Hubert Opperman, who was a member of the House of Representatives for many years.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the 1950s, wasn't it?

—Yes, he was a member in the 1950s and 1960s. Back in the 1920s and 1930s he was the world road cycling champion. I am pleased to note that we have a record of having attracted some of Australia's better sportsmen into this area of sport, if one can describe it in that way. Unfortunately, it is more a blood sport.

SPEECH.PARA: We are still a great sporting nation. It is true that our Olympic Games results have declined a bit in recent years on a relative basis, but they are still wonderful. One of the reasons that the Australian Institute of Sport was set up several years ago by the Fraser Government was to lift our Olympic Games performance. I hope that the Institute will play a very significant role in lifting our results in the 1988 Olympic Games and lifting the level of sport generally in this country. I take this opportunity publicly to congratulate Ron Harvey, the new director of the Institute of Sport, on his relatively recent appointment. He is a very experienced administrator, and a great sporting administrator through his long term involvement in basketball in this country. I am sure that he will bring to the Institute the cohesion, financial accountability and flair which are so necessary in that arena.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are doing well in basketball, I believe.
—Yes, we are; we are doing extraordinarily well in world basketball and also, I understand, in netball.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by reiterating that the Opposition supports this Bill. It is a progressive step. It will give the AOF greater access to the private sector for raising money. We are very glad to support it. On behalf of the Opposition I wish the Australian Olympic Federation, our athletes and officials all the best for the 1988 Olympics. We hope that the Bill will be part of the further desirable development of sport in Australia in the years ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —My heart flutters with patriotism after that brilliant speech by Senator Short and that wonderful accolade for the athletes of Australia. The Australian Democrats support the Olympic Insignia Protection Bill 1986. Sending competitors and officials to Olympic Games is an expensive exercise and the Australian Democrats commend this Bill as an effort to make the Australian Olympic Federation less reliant on the public purse for its funds. The costs of sending an Australian delegation to the Olympic Games are increasing in proportion to the Government's commitment to sport in Australia through the Australian Institute of Sport. At this point, we are facing an estimated $10m to send our delegation to the Seoul Olympics, of which the Government is expected to contribute $2m directly. This is aside from the funding of the Australian Institute of Sport, the expensive organisation-about $120m has been spent since 1980-set up by the Fraser Government more appropriately called the `medal factory'. It would like to be called the `medal factory' if it could only produce more medal-winning athletes.

SPEECH.PARA: From the taxpayers' point of view, one wonders just how much of our money the Government is prepared to spend in pursuit of sporting achievements which involve so few head of population, which fail to encourage wider participation by members of the community, and which allow the majority of Australians to indulge themselves in `spectator' or `armchair' exercise-a la Norm-rather than the real thing. While there is no doubt that the public money poured into the recent hosting of the America's Cup challenge resulted in some return of investment, it is a pity that such attention is not given to sports in which one does not have to be a millionaire to participate.

The Australian Democrats believe that funding for sport must be looked at after an appraisal of what we really wish to achieve. For example, should our objective be to afford every Australian a certain number of times a year the vicarious thrill we collectively experience as a nation when a sportsman or woman who happens to have been born or naturalised an Australian wins an event? What does this thrill hold for the betterment of our quality of life, apart from the shortlived inner glow of pride and patriotism we experience in our living rooms without having to flex a muscle?

The Australian Democrats will be moving an amendment to this Bill, the intention of which is to preclude the Olympic insignia and other Olympic designs being used in a context where they may be associated with the promotion of tobacco or alcohol consumption. The amendment, as circulated, prohibits the Australian Olympic Federation from granting a licence for use of the designs to anyone selling tobacco or alcohol, and to anyone who may allow them to be displayed where advertising of these products occurs. It seems obvious to the Australian Democrats that without this amendment we would be allowing, if not encouraging, a situation to develop which gives the hungry tobacco companies and alcohol producers the opportunity to exploit the Olympic Games and all they represent to their own questionable ends. By that I mean the promotion of their products to the young and impressionable by their association with the heroics of sporting excellence.

Since the banning of tobacco advertisements on television, we have seen the injection of huge amounts of money by this industry into sponsorship of sport. Why? The companies at least give us credit for some intelligence: They do not claim they hand over this money out of the goodness of their hearts. Of course not. The companies will readily admit that it is because they expect some benefit out of it. Just what they expect is evidenced recently in the case of the North Sydney Oval. The North Sydney Council, which has a longstanding policy over 20 years of non-acceptance of tobacco company sponsorship, recently completed its $7.5m sports oval. The Council has been told by the New South Wales Cricket Association that no first class games will be staged at the Oval unless the Council refuses to accept government sponsored anti-smoking advertising at events.

A similar situation has arisen in the Victorian Football League in the past month. Negotiations with the Fitzroy Club for the Victorian Government's `Quit' campaign sponsorship were in doubt following the threat of Rothmans of Pall Mall (Aust.) Ltd to invoke apparently exclusive advertising arrangements at Princes Park. Similar pressure was applied by the Benson and Hedges Company Pty Ltd at the Melbourne Cricket Ground which resulted in the Richmond Football Club dropping sponsorship with `Quit'. The tobacco companies continually attempt to persuade us that their advertising is not aimed at encouraging non-smokers to smoke, but merely to persuade confirmed smokers to change brands. If that were true these `confirmed smokers' presumably would not be influenced by anti-smoking advertisements and the tobacco companies would have nothing to fear. Their heavy-handed reaction destroys their own argument. Certainly they are trying to attract new customers to their particular type of drug and are aiming their campaign at the young and impressionable, the people who attend sporting events and who look up to sporting heroes. The New South Wales Cricket Association and New South Wales Rugby League have apparently become so manipulated and dependent on tobacco company funding that they are now prepared to do their dirty work for them. The sporting organisations which have benefited from and prospered by sponsorship with funds diverted from television advertising campaigns have become the advocates of the tobacco companies. I think we should really ask ourselves: Do we want to allow this manipulation of sport to occur and, more particularly, do we want the ideals of the Olympic movement to be associated with the promotion of these products and the methods employed to promote them?

We all know that the reason tobacco companies sponsor major events is that these events are televised and the ban on television advertising of tobacco can be circumvented. The association by advertisers of tobacco and alcohol with the Olympic Games would allow the companies promoting these goods one more opportunity to use the advertisers' infallible formula: Promotion by association with the images of success which we as human beings are conditioned to strive for-health, wealth and sexual gratification. It is no wonder that promoters of potentially harmful products want to promote them by association with the embodiment of perfect health-the Olympic athlete. The temptation is too great and it must not be allowed to lead to the sacrifice of the potential of our young people who are, after all, the Olympians of the future.

Perhaps our own apathy in this area is what has allowed the Federal Government to get away with inaction in combating the trend towards abuse of these drugs by young people in Australia. Is it because they are socially acceptable drugs amongst our adult population that the Government chose virtually to ignore them in the recent drug offensive, and concentrate on the far more sensational-in the public perception at least-trade in narcotics and barbiturates? The Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, told a health seminar recently that alcoholism is Australia's fourth major health problem, affecting 20 per cent of the work force. But it is among our young people that abuse of these `social' drugs takes its worst toll. According to findings of a survey published in a recent edition of the Medical Journal of Australia, high school students alone spend at least $30m on cigarettes each year. This is double the amount that the tobacco companies spend a year on the sponsorship of 23 different sports and represents a not bad return on investment. The same survey found that in the week preceding the survey 23 per cent of 12-year-old boys and 14 per cent of 12-year-old girls had drunk alcohol, and that on average a 17-year-old boy had 9.3 drinks per week.

Perhaps there is another reason for the failure of the Government to tackle abuse of alcohol and tobacco head on. After all, it is the Federal Government which collects a hefty excise from the sale of tobacco and alcohol-to the order of $8.5m of the $30m spent on cigarettes by those high school students, and no doubt a similarly high figure for excise on alcohol. The amount the Government spends on education programs to discourage young people from abusing these substances is pitiful in comparison. The Government has a moral responsibility to direct these funds to this purpose. My colleague Senator Powell intends to introduce legislation which actually does this. The Liquor Advertising Tax Assessment Bill and the Liquor Education Fund Bill impose a tax on alcohol advertising and use the revenue gained to help pay for educational campaigns and promotion against alcohol abuse and underage drinking. Implementation of such a measure is all the more necessary since the alcohol producers seemed determined to tap the underage drink market.

We saw recent evidence of this with the release on to the market of wine coolers, in packaging similar to soft drinks and fruit juices and easily mistakable for them in the home. These so-called coolers have an alcoholic content of up to 6 per cent. Some producers event attempted to market their coolers in 250 millilitre packets equipped with a straw, similar to common fruit juice packaging available in milk bars and supermarkets, and then had the gall to deny the product was aimed at the juvenile market. It is fortunate that most State governments have now acted to prevent coolers in this type of packaging reaching the shelves. This recent development does go to show that we need to be vigilant in monitoring the activities of the alcohol producers if we are to prevent marketing strategies of this nature being implemented in the future. Current guidelines for advertising of drinking are such as to make questionable the legality of advertising of alcohol by association with sport anyway. The guidelines say that advertisements should only depict responsible drinking, that drinking should not be portrayed as a challenge, and that there should be no implication that success or social distinction is due to drinking. It is hard to imagine how the association of alcohol with the Olympic Games, a competition between the most successful sportsmen and sportswomen in the world, would not imply that success and social distinction are achievable by drinking. Surely that would be the motive of the advertisers' sponsorship of that sport.

The Australian Democrats trust that the amendment circulated under our name relating to this Bill will receive the support of all parties in this chamber. Despite the customary cynicism I sometimes display towards the motives of the elected representatives of this Parliament, I believe that the weight of obligation to the health of fellow human beings and children-specifically children-will be sufficient to persuade honourable senators of the desirability of supporting the amendment. Not to give it support would be to prove their own unsuitability to remain as elected representatives of the people of this country and unworthy of the trust placed in them. We support the Bill and will be introducing amendments in the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleagues and I will be supporting the Olympic Insignia Protection Bill, which will enable the Australian Olympic Federation to raise funds by licensing the Olympic insignia of five interlocking rings for commercial use. It is a good plan to allow our Olympic Federation to raise its own funds as best it can, and this Bill will protect it in its use of the insignia. When Australia attended the 1984 Olympic Games, I understand that it cost about $5m to send 355 athletes. The estimated cost of sending 400 athletes to the games in Seoul, Korea, next year will be about $10m. It is interesting to note that in 1984 the taxpayers put in about $1.4m of the total amount of $5m, 28 per cent of the total expenditure. In 1988 it is estimated that, even though the taxpayers' contribution will increase to about $2m, that will represent only 20 per cent of the total cost of sending our Olympic team to Seoul. In other words, the Australian Olympic Federation is slowly reducing the percentage required from taxpayers to send our team overseas.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall not trespass on ground traversed by previous speakers either in this chamber or in the other place, but I would emphasise that these games and the quality of our athletes who attend such international competitions help to put Australia on the international stage. For that reason we support the Bill, particularly in view of the fact that it will reduce the dependence on the Australian taxpayer for the necessary funds as the Australian Olympic Federation seeks to draw more and more funds from the commercial and private sectors.

I cannot let this opportunity pass without congratulating Alderman Sallyanne Atkinson and all those in Brisbane who were responsible for the bid for the 1988 games. It was a tremendous effort and put not only Brisbane and Queensland but Australia on the map as well as any campaign could have done. It was a sterling effort. We know that it did not come off, but at least those in the international scene know that Australia is alive and well. Indeed, that effort followed the Commonwealth Games that were held in my own State-to my knowledge, one of the best run games in recent times. That also put Australia on the world map. All these efforts add up to a tremendous advantage for Australia. I do not refer merely to the holding of games in our own country or to the bid for the games, but to the fact that we are able to send top quality athletes to international meets such as the Olympics, and there is none greater than the Olympic Games. Their sporting standard, their behaviour and all of those things mean that Australia is certainly very active in the world scene.

I understand why the Australian Democrats will move an amendment, but those sorts of decisions, which are basically social decisions, should be left to the Australian Olympic Federation. Even if the Olympic Federation sought to allow the insignia to be used by tobacco and alcohol organisations, which I suppose it must be admitted are great supporters of sport, tobacco and alcoholic beverages are two things that the coaches of our athletic teams would not allow the athletes to partake of to any great excess, if at all. It would probably put the Olympic Federation in a bit of a dilemma. Nonetheless, I think it is up to it to take what are basically social decisions. For that reason, and that reason alone, we will not support the Democrats' amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to reiterate briefly the purpose of this legislation. It clarifies the Australian Olympic Federation's rights to the Olympic rings and 10 other registered Olympic logos and enables the Federation to grant exclusive right to use the rings and logos in association with goods and services. This ability to grant, and guarantee, exclusive use of the rings and logos is the cornerstone of the AOF's fund raising campaign to send the Olympic team to next year's, and subsequent, Olympic Games.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation protects pre-existing rights by not permitting the registration of logos that are already in use. Moreover, existing bona fide users of the Olympic rings will be able to continue their use of the rings. What the legislation prevents is the use of the rings and Olympic logos by persons who wish to cash in on the fund raising campaign of the AOF by selling goods with the rings or Olympic logos on them. The Australian public will be assured by the passage of this legislation that if they purchase goods endorsed with an Olympic logo or the rings during a fund raising program, they are helping contribute to the sending of Australia's team to the Olympics. The enforcement mechanism of this legislation rests with the Olympic Federation or the persons who have the rights to use the registered logos. This will ensure speedy action if breaches occur. Also it avoids the necessity for enforcement action by the Commonwealth.

In closing this debate I would like to emphasise the significance of this legislation. Not only will it facilitate the Australian Olympic Federation's ability to raise funds so that Australia will be represented by the best possible team at Olympic Games, and hopefully be able to do so with a smaller proportion of the associated costs being met from Commonwealth funds than would otherwise be the case, but it also provides the Olympic movement with the means to protect and maintain the dignity of its logo, the five Olympic rings. The International Olympic Federation has been seeking this type of protection for the Olympic rings for some time and Australia is only the second country, after the United States of America, to pass legislation providing appropriate protection. This maintains Australia's fine record of support and close connection with the Olympic Games. Only three countries have competed in all the modern Olympics. They are England, Greece and Australia. Further, there is an Australian on the new International Olympic Committee Executive-a committee that comprises only 11 members. When one remembers that the full Committee represents 157 nations, representation on that Committee reinforces Australia's standing within the Olympic movement and in the area of international sport generally.

Australia's Olympic reputation is in the excellent hands of members of the Australian Olympic Federation, all of whom are dedicated to the Olympic ideals. This Government is proud to be able to assist in this matter of protecting the Olympic insignia and thereby help maintain Australia's reputation as a strong supporter of the Olympic movement. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 9, after clause 15, insert the following new clause:
``Prohibition of certain licences
``15a. The Federation shall not, in respect of a protected design, grant a licence:
(a) to a person carrying on the business of selling:
(i) goods for smoking, being goods manufactured wholly or partly from tobacco leaf;
(ii) alcoholic beverages;
(b) in circumstances in which the Federation is aware, or ought to be aware, that it is intended that the protected design will be used for, or in connection with, the advertising or promotion of:
(i) goods for smoking, being goods manufactured wholly or partly from tobacco leaf; or
(ii) alcoholic beverages; or
(c) in circumstances in which the Federation is aware, or ought to be aware, that it is intended that the protected design will be displayed at any function or venue where advertising of:
(i) goods for smoking, being goods manufactured wholly or partly from tobacco leaf; or
(ii) alcoholic beverages;
occurs or is likely to occur.''.

The purpose of this amendment to the Olympic Insignia Protection Bill, as I explained in my speech in the second reading debate, is to make sure that drug dealers are not allowed to advertise their wares in conjunction with the Olympic symbol. The people to whom the amendment refers are dealing in drugs. Alcohol is a drug and tobacco is a drug; we know this. I think it is absolutely absurd that these well-known killers and maimers in our society should be allowed to associate their image with that of the Olympic symbol which is, of course, the image of excellence and purity. It is a symbol which should be guarded. I think that the people who actually put forward the concept of the Bill should be worried about this because their image will be degraded by the inclusion of alcohol and cigarette advertising. For those reasons the Australian Democrats have moved this amendment. We do not do it lightly or mischievously. We feel that the Olympic movement will suffer if the drug dealers are allowed to attach themselves like leeches to the Olympic insignia. Therefore, we commend the amendment to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment is not acceptable to the Government. The evidence certainly is clear that tobacco is inimical to health and appropriate warnings are visible on packaging. The Commonwealth controls television advertising of tobacco. That direct approach is to be preferred, as opposed to discriminating in a patronising way against a voluntary body which has always acted responsibly. If it is considered desirable to further control the advertising of tobacco and alcohol, that should be looked at in a rational, planned way, not by the ad hoc measures proposed by the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition also opposes this amendment. I understand from Senator Collard's speech on the second reading of the Bill that the National Party of Australia also opposes it. The amendment is a very clear indication that Senator Sanders and his Party have not done their homework on this issue. That, of course, is absolutely typical of the sloppy, disorganised approach of the Australian Democrats in this place which we have to put up with.
—I wonder where I have heard that before?

—Let me tell Senator Sanders a few things of which he is obviously not aware. The first is that the Olympic charter of the international body to which Australia is a party states that the Australian Olympic Federation should not be associated with the advertising of tobacco or alcohol. The AOF has never been associated with tobacco advertising. Secondly, the wording of the AOF charter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The use of the emblem for advertising alcoholic beverages or tobacco is strictly prohibited.

The terms of the amendment are extraordinarily wide. For example, the amendment could prevent the use of the insignia by a conglomerate in circumstances in which tobacco or alcohol, although part of the operations of the conglomerate, were not actually being advertised, but would prevent the conglomerate from advertising other products. Paragraphs (b) and (c) of the amendment propose to prohibit the use of the insignia, at venues under existing obligations, by tobacco or alcoholic beverage producers. This could place the AOF in very difficult circumstances. As the Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, said, the Australian Olympic Federation is a body of very responsible people. They have always exercised their social responsibility to the highest degree. It seems to me to be entirely inconsistent to proscribe certain activities when the whole purpose of the Bill is to give the Federation certain broad responsibilities in this area, and it is very insulting, if I may say so, to the Federation and its very distinguished members. For that variety of reasons the Opposition opposes the Democrats' amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It saddens me that the National Party, the Liberal Party and the Australian Labor Party are all opposing this amendment. I suppose it indicates that they feel they do not want to offend their rich and powerful friends in the tobacco and alcohol industry, and it saddens me greatly that this is the case. But if this is the stand they wish to take, they will have to answer ultimately to the voters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last comment by Senator Sanders is beneath contempt. As Senator Short has already quite clearly pointed out, there are sound, practical and decent reasons for objecting to this amendment. As Senator Short quite clearly pointed out, the guidelines from the International Olympic Committee, which have always been endorsed, followed and underlined by the Australian Olympic Federation, state that the use of the emblem for advertising alcoholic beverages or tobacco is strictly prohibited. As Senator Short said, not only is it insulting to the people who make up this Federation to seek to give them the instruction that Senator Sanders intends, but also it is insulting to all those who happen to disagree with Senator Sanders that his only riposte, his only response, is to doubt the integrity of people who regard his action as foolish, misguided and offensive. In that situation the Opposition naturally finds that it cannot and will not support this specific amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Short has said, in this legislation, which is being supported by both the Government and the Opposition, we are giving powers to a body to undertake a whole range of activities. If we did not believe that it has the integrity or the capacity to carry out those duties to the benefit of Australia, presumably we would not be supporting this Bill. The fact is that we are and, as I understand it, the Australian Democrats are supporting the thrust of the Bill. It is just that they simply do not trust people to follow an instruction from the International Olympic Committee or the wording of the AOF charter. I must say that we do not share that contempt for the people of the AOF that has been demonstrated by the Australian Democrats.

I want to underline very strongly the point that Senator Short made about conglomerates. This amendment is so inept that a group that produces, for example, a newspaper or sells real estate or is in the meat industry would, under this amendment, be prohibited from using the Olympic symbol, because one other company in that group may either make or supply beer or cigarettes. What arrant nonsense. Presumably not even Senator Sanders could fail to recognise how ridiculous such an amendment would be. Why should someone be prohibited from doing a quite proper deal with the Australian Olympic Federation relating to the use of the advertising of some real estate, newspapers, meat-you name it-simply because that group also happens to be involved in cigarettes or alcoholic beverages? Yet that is what this inept and incompetent amendment seeks to do.

I think it is quite clear that there is within this chamber a range of views about the merits or otherwise of advertising cigarettes and alcohol. The important thing is that those who totally oppose the principle of advertising alcohol and tobacco can nonetheless feel totally comfortable opposing the Democrats' incompetent amendment, because in fact it seeks to do far more than simply to prevent people who are selling alcoholic beverages or goods for smoking from advertising those items. As I said, it goes far beyond that to an unreasonable degree and seeks to intrude and impose a restraint which is inappropriate and bears no relationship to the advertising of alcohol or tobacco products that the Democrats claim they are seeking to prevent.

Nonetheless, I think it is reasonable to say that all members of this chamber would expect the Olympic Federation, in making its decisions, to recognise certain social obligations, because it has always acted in that way and always will act in that way, and its charter requires it in effect to act in that way. So on almost every score the Democrats' amendment, which is a grandstanding amendment aimed at creating phoney righteousness, is in fact something that I am certain no honourable senator, apart from the Australian Democrats for a political purpose, would really be seeking to support.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Sanders's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 May, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:

TALK.START.PARA: —It may suit the convenience of the Senate to debate cognately the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987, the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1986, the Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Bill 1987 and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Amendment Bill 1987. There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of Bills before the Senate today include two which seek to amend the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 and two which relate to the grant of Aboriginal land in Victoria. I will be largely confining my contribution in this debate to the proposed amendments to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act, although I think some very important issues arise out of the Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Bill. The first thing that one must say about the amendments to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act is that they have been a long time coming. Territorians have been waiting many years for some relief from the problems arising out of the Aboriginal land rights Act. They have seen the Act in operation over the past 11 years and have witnessed first hand the problems in its implementation and the detrimental effect of certain aspects of the legislation on the Territory community.

SPEECH.PARA: There can be no question that the impact of the Act as envisaged by its architects and draftsmen has been far exceeded by the reality of its implementation. In the Northern Territory we have reached the point where almost 50 per cent of the area of the Territory has been either granted or is under claim as Aboriginal land. The extent of the claims has far exceeded what was anticipated by many of those who supported land rights 10 years ago. It would be true to say that the way that the land rights legislation has been extended in its application through the interpretation of the courts has led to a great change in the attitude of the Australian community towards the whole land rights issue. The manner and extent of claims under the Act has led to divisiveness in the Australian community and open resentment to some degree of the benefits extended to Aborigines which are not enjoyed by other Australians. I certainly do not believe that it was the intention of the original proponents of the Act for this to happen. Surely the Act was intended to allow for recognition of the special social and cultural aspirations of Aboriginal people, in a way which could see them effectively co-exist with public and private business sector initiatives and which would be readily accepted by the community at large.

Even the principal architect of the land rights Act, Mr Justice Edward Woodward, has sounded a warning note to the Aboriginal people that they are endangering community support for their cause through the extent of the claims that are being made. At the 1985 Australian Legal Convention Mr Justice Woodward suggested that Aboriginal advisers give careful thought to the extent of future claims. He said:

I suggest that Aboriginal councils and their advisers give careful thought to the extent of future claims and even consider the advisability of forgoing or surrendering some land already claimed or granted.

It is quite significant that Mr Justice Woodward should voice this view, and I believe that the Federal Government, too, must heed the message which Mr Justice Woodward is sending in relation to land rights. We are now in a position, 11 years on, to review the Act, examine the problems stemming from its operation and do something to redress these problems.

In some elements of the community there has been a feeling that the land rights Act is sacrosanct, that it cannot be altered regardless of any problem which it might be causing those who must live with it. Clearly this is an unrealistic view, and it is being seen as such by those in the community who are witnessing the damage it is doing to Aboriginal interests. It is an undeniable fact that in practice the land rights Act is not working as planned and is in need of change. That brings me back to the legislation now before the Senate, which will supposedly provide the changes needed to rectify these problems. I will deal with the Bills separately and address my initial remarks to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1976. The amendments proposed by this Bill are disappointing because they do not adequately address a number of the major problems identified with the Act. Some of the amendments, in fact, look set to provide additional burdens for Territorians, both Aboriginal and otherwise, who have to live with this legislation on a day to day basis.

It is important that the Senate be made aware of some of the glaring omissions from the amendments put forward by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding). I deal firstly with access to the provision of essential services. The first aspect is the failure of the amendments to address the quite basic matter of access to Aboriginal land for the provision of essential services. The Northern Territory Government's right to provide such services should not continue to be inhibited. When the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act came into force the Commonwealth reserved unto itself the right to acquire, under a law of the Commonwealth, Aboriginal land for public purposes. A similar power was not reserved to the Northern Territory. The Commonwealth does not have a monopoly of good works. Indeed, it is the nature of the division between Commonwealth and State responsibilities which sees the burden for the provision of most community services-such as health, education, power and sewerage services et cetera-fall on the Northern Territory Government. Yet the Northern Territory is expected to fulfil its obligations without the benefit of the power of acquisition, which is seen as essential to enable governments in other parts of Australia to provide such services.

The lack of such power has led to the ridiculous situation where Territory authorities attempting to carry out their responsibilities to provide services on or across Aboriginal land-particularly services for the Aboriginal people-have been met with the outrageous suggestion that they should have to pay for the privilege of providing those services. Even the Commonwealth has been on the receiving end of this crazy mentality when, in attempting to supply an improved telephone service to Port Keats-which involved placing communications equipment across Aboriginal land-Telecom was hit with claims for excessively high compensation. Similar demands were made when attempts were made to put in millions of dollars worth of high technology equipment to provide upgraded communications at Lake Evella in Arnhem Land. The provision of the service was held up for two or three years.

There have also been instances of Aboriginal people attempting to claim compensation for the gravel extracted from their land to build roads for the Aboriginal people themselves. Another example occurred when traditional owners in one community wanted to charge the Northern Territory Housing Commission rent for the houses it had erected on Aboriginal land for Aboriginal people to live in. These are but a couple of examples of the anomalous situations which have arisen, and, while they may ultimately be resolved, they have greatly frustrated the efforts of the Northern Territory government departments to provide services to Aboriginal people, and heated up community feeling to the point of confrontation. I might add that, most times, the traditional owners themselves are not the problem-it is the money- and power-hungry land councils which become embroiled in these matters. Indeed, one even finds that land council members themselves are expressing criticisms of the land council bureaus, which employ 70 to 80 people, many of whom are retained as consultants and advisers, at not inconsiderable cost to the Aboriginal people.

It is the land councils that have attempted to control access to Aboriginal land and have said that other Australians cannot enter Aboriginal land without permits. In an article in the Bulletin, journalist David Barnett made the point that even Norforce, the North-West Mobile Force-which is supposed to train to defend and patrol our northern coastline-has experienced some difficulty in obtaining permits to carry out the exercises in Arnhem Land. Another example of these sorts of difficulties has been the inability of the parties involved to reach agreement which would enable the Northern Territory Government permission to build a road from Nhulunbuy to Katherine, thus linking Nhulunbuy with the Stuart Highway. Such a link is essential for development and for servicing the Nhulunbuy community. It also has considerable defence significance, particularly in view of the Federal Government's recently announced northern defence developments and upgrading. Mr Holding's amendments have done absolutely nothing to rectify this situation. I will be proposing an amendment to the Bill which would overcome the difficulties faced by Northern Territory authorities. But I will deal with that matter in more detail at the Committee stage.

I turn to stock routes and public purpose land, and what the amendments do not do in relation to these issues. The Commonwealth Government is the only government in Australia which appears to have adopted a policy of abandoning the stock route systems which are under its control. All of the States maintain the stock routes within their territorial jurisdictions for sound economic reasons. But in the Northern Territory there is a clear and conscious policy, under the auspices of land rights, of abandonment of active stock routes. The problem with this development is that, once a route is broken, the effect of a break flows on to other routes within the same network, which leads to the ultimate breakdown of the network.

These amendments purport to include alterations to the Act which would make certain stock routes unclaimable. But what Mr Holding gives with one hand he is taking away with the other. His amendments propose that stock routes will not be claimable, excepting those already subject to claim at the commencement of the operation of the amendments, and those where claimed land adjoins both sides of a stock route. While this would seem to represent an improvement on the present situation, which has seen claims upon stock routes divide some pastoral properties, the reality is that the Minister has retained unto himself the power to declare a stock route, which is prima facie exempt, to be claimable where no agreement between disputing parties can be reached. This means, in effect, that, as at present, all stock routes are claimable, because prospective claimants would only have to take an unreasonable position, which the user of the land subject to the dispute could not accept, and the stage would be set to make out a case for declaring that route claimable under the amended Act. What the Minister is proposing will provide no reassurance to the pastoral industry. The Minister is saying that he is willing to see negotiations between the pastoralists and traditional owners, but, if the traditional owners are dissatisfied with the outcome of negotiations, they can then have the land in question declared claimable under the land rights legislation. In my view, it is a not particularly subtle form of blackmail.

The private member's Bill which I introduced late in 1985 made a real attempt at overcoming this problem by including a provision which set aside those areas of unalienated crown land which, over the years, have been nominated by the crown for any number of public purposes. These include use as stock routes or stock reserves, land set aside for entertainment purposes, such as for racecourses, for the erection of police stations, historical monuments, forestry reserves, cemeteries, and conservation parks. Under my proposed Bill, land so set aside or reserved would no longer be identified as crown land for claim purposes. The Holding amendments before the Senate do not even take account of these parcels of land; nor do they protect from further claim the beds and banks of various streams and estuaries, which would otherwise be available for claim, or the remaining foreshore areas of the Northern Territory are not already Aboriginal land.

More than 60 per cent of the coastline of the Northern Territory-to which more than 75 per cent of the population, including many aboriginals, have effectively been denied access-is Aboriginal land. We are talking about 3,720 kilometres of coastline, out of a total of just over 6,000 kilometres. In proportional terms, in New South Wales, this is the equivalent of depriving Sydney, Newcastle and Wollongong of access to a stretch of coastline from Bateman's Bay to Coffs Harbour; or, in Victoria, the equivalent of depriving the population of Melbourne, Geelong and the La Trobe valley of access to a stretch of coastline from the South Australian border to Wilson's Promontory. That would not be politically tolerated in either of those States. On that point, I might say that I have noted with interest the call by the Victorian Government for the Federal Government to legislate to provide certain limited land rights in Victoria, and the Bills which are before the Senate as part of this package arising out of that call. I would be much more interested to see Victoria whole-heartedly embrace the Northern Territory style of land rights, but of course it is not about to do that. The Victorian Government is not about to commit political suicide by imposing in Victoria what territorians have had to put up with for 10 years or more.

Of course, on this issue of Federal intervention in land rights matters, it is my view that land rights is properly an issue to be left to the States. The Labor Government in Victoria should not be calling on the Federal Government to intervene in what is an area of State responsibility simply because it has some problem with the numbers in the Upper House. This is an attempt to circumvent the due processes of the State legislature which, I suppose, should not come as a surprise from a Labor Government, considering the Australian Labor Party's preference for centralism in government, as opposed to States rights. One wonders what the people of Victoria feel when their own Premier abrogates to Canberra his responsibilities.

I turn to the question of the limit on claims. At the outset of my remarks in this debate I made the point that the manner and the extent of claims made under the Land Rights Act have far exceeded the expectations of those responsible for the preparation of land rights legislation. Mr Justice Woodward recently has acknowledged this. The Land Rights Act has been in operation for over a decade. To date, almost 50 per cent of the Territory has been granted or is presently under claim. At the time of the enactment of the Act, some 18 per cent of the Northern Territory was held as Aboriginal reserve, to the agreement of all. Contrary to popular belief, large tracts of this land, both in Arnhem Land and in the southern part of the Territory, in Territory terms was quite valuable land-particularly the pastoral land held in the south. It was estimated that land claims would add at most some 10 per cent to that figure.

I will give some idea of the magnitude of the area under claim. It is over 450,000 square kilometres. The concept of the land rights legislation was that land rights would be granted in recognition that Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory were entitled to give full expression to their affinity with the land. The principle underlying the legislation was widely accepted within the Australian community. Sadly, the same cannot be said of the attitude of Australians today towards land rights. The implementation of the Act has created divisiveness in the community and resentment in come areas towards Aboriginal people. The aversion which has developed towards land rights does not stem from opposition to granting land to Aboriginals as much as the manner and extent of claims which have been made with little regard for the needs and aspirations of other Australians.

The open-ended nature of the claim provisions has also meant that a great deal of uncertainty and scepticism has developed in the community. The concept of land rights has become the object of ridicule, not just by those who can be characterised as bigots opposed to assisting Aboriginal people in any way. I am sure that other senators must have seen cartoons and heard stories about Aboriginal people erecting `sacred site' signs on sites of recently discovered mineral deposits or on other areas found to be of commercial value. The whole matter has become farcical. It is quite a pity that it has become a reflection on those who do not deserve it. Many Australians now view land claims with a good deal of scepticism. Because no time limit has been set for the lodgment of Aboriginal land claims claimants over the past 11 years have lodged claims any time it has suited them. There have been occasions on which the lodgment of a claim coincidentally has occurred hot on the heels of the discovery of a mineral deposit.

Claims cannot be allowed to continue unabated. There must be a realistic and sensible cessation of the land claim process. We must face the fact that in the Territory there will be a continuing need to foster pastoral and fledgling agricultural industries and to further provide land for government and community requirements. There has to be a limit to Aboriginal land claims. It has taken only 10 years for almost half the Territory to be claimed as Aboriginal land. The Minister is proposing that claims not cease for a further 10 years. Perhaps he feels that that is sufficient time for the outstanding unalienated Crown land in the Territory to be claimed as well. I would encourage Aboriginal people to become more active in the Northern Territory land law system rather than delve more into the Federal Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act system of land ownership. Another 10 years of land claims, divisiveness and uncertainty is the last thing that the Northern Territory needs, but that is what the Minister is prescribing.

One sometimes wonders whether the Minister, in attempting to fulfil his portfolio responsibilities, forgets that the Territory's population is over 143,000 and that, whilst his primary responsibilities are to the 20 per cent who are Aboriginals, he also has some responsibility, as a member of the Australian Government, to the other 80 per cent. It would be quite possible for him to fulfil his commitments to all Territorians in the matter of a limit to land claims by setting a more realistic limit-say, 12 months-instead of the 10 years proposed. I will be moving an amendment to the legislation before the chamber which will provide for such a 12-month limit. There is no reason why those Aboriginal people who regard themselves as having a claim as traditional owners of land should not be required to lodge such a claim within a 12-month period, because, as I say, this has been going on now for 11 years.

I pass now to the clause which relates to Aboriginal-held pastoral leases. Aboriginal people have played a very important role in the pastoral industry in the outback and they deserve our recognition and thanks for their contribution. Those Aboriginal people who became involved in the industry acquired skills which have enabled them to become involved in running pastoral leases of their own and the present Commonwealth Government, its predecessor and the Northern Territory Government have encouraged the purchase of such properties. The Land Rights Act, as it stands, allows for these properties to be claimed and converted to inalienable freehold Aboriginal land but it is certainly not always the case that those who claim the leases are suited to operating them productively.

The amendment contained in clause 25 is to the effect that a land claim in respect of an Aboriginal-held pastoral lease may not be heard unless the Land Commissioner is satisfied that the holders of the lease, or the body holding the estate on their behalf, has consented in writing to the claim. The difficulty which I have with regard to this amendment is that while I am pleased to see that claims can now only be made with the consent of the leaseholders, ultimately there is still room for claims to be made on good pastoral land which, once it is converted into inalienable freehold, is out of circulation forever. The reality is that the Aboriginal holders of a pastoral lease are invariably the same people who lodge the claim and give the consent.

The fact that such land can be claimed in the first place is anomalous when one considers that the Act was supposed to apply only to unalienated Crown land. Yet over the years claims have been successfully made on these pastoral leases-on land which is alienated. In some cases the land which is taken out of circulation in this way is not properly managed and is lost to the pastoral industry forever. This is of great concern to the pastoral industry and the people of the Territory, and it is a very legitimate concern. The Federal Government has not really done anything to allay the concerns of the industry. In fact, this amendment is quite half-hearted, like many of the other provisions of this Bill.

It is a great pity that so little will be achieved by this Bill because the Minister seemed to start off with considerable vigor and enthusiasm. He now seems to have been worn out and defeated by the magnitude of the task before him. So now, instead of genuine reform, we have a series of amendments which most certainly are not worth the four years it has taken to get them this far. Some of them, like the one which required negotiated agreements on claims to stock routes, are supposed to show the Minister's preference for negotiated rather than imposed solutions, yet the Minister is still retaining the big stick-he will impose a solution if the negotiating parties cannot reach agreement.

These amendments fall very short of the mark. They will do nothing to alleviate the problems which have caused such resentment among non-Aboriginal Australians. The list of critical omissions from these amendments goes on and on, but there can be no doubt that the aspect of the operation of the Land Rights Act which has attracted the most attention and has caused, in economic terms, the most damage to the Northern Territory's past, present and future prospects is the effect this legislation has had upon mining exploration and development within the Territory.

The Minister has had four years in which to do something to begin to solve the problems caused by the operation of the Act on mining. Last Thursday in the Senate we were presented with the fruits of his labours-the amendments proposed to the mining provisions of the Land Rights Act. At the outset, let me stress that I fully appreciate that it is no easy task to attempt to reconcile the differing and competing interests of Aboriginal people and mining interests, and I acknowledge that attempting to work out an agreeable compromise is a job which necessarily involves time-consuming negotiations and consultation. The Minister has had four years-and has been working on amendments to the Land Rights Act throughout that period. I have to say that while what is proposed in the amendments to the mining provisions is a step in the right direction in that it at least recognises the need for change to facilitate access to Aboriginal land for the purpose of exploration and mining development, it does not go nearly far enough.

The Minister has made a great deal of the amendments, and the fact that they include a removal of the power of veto on mining once an exploration agreement has been reached between an intending miner and the Aboriginal owners of land. The Minister claims that this, together with the timetable which has been set up, and the conciliation and arbitration process will clear the log jam of applications for exploration on Aboriginal land. This, however, overlooks the very basic fact that nothing in the proposed amendments makes it any more likely that miners will be able to get over that threshold of obtaining the consent of traditional owners to explore on Aboriginal land.

The experience of recent years gives little cause for hope. Currently there are 152 applications for exploration licences over Aboriginal land in the Northern Land Council area. In the case of almost 90 per cent of these there has been some five to six years in which agreement could have been reached; 54 approvals to commence negotiation were given in 1981, 77 in 1982, and 14 in 1983. To date 32 applications for exploration have been vetoed in the NLC area-that is, no exploration has been allowed. The area which has been effectively withdrawn from exploration by the mining industry as a result of these vetoes is some 18,000 square kilometres. Since the commencement of the land rights Act, only one solitary application for exploration has been approved in the NLC area. It allows Uranertz of Australia Ltd to explore an area of 64 square kilometres. No applications for exploration have been approved in the Central Land Council area.

No statistics could be more damning of the Aboriginal land rights Act and its failure to adequately provide a mechanism whereby the mining industry has reasonable access to Aboriginal land. But, even with Senator Gareth Evans's much vaunted changes to the Act, there is still no removal of the veto power at the exploration stage. Until there is, I doubt whether we can expect much, if any, improvement in the number of applications for exploration on Aboriginal land which are approved. The Opposition will be moving an amendment in the Committee stage of the debate which would remove the veto power at the exploration stage, with suitable arrangements.

Even overlooking what seems to be a fatal flaw in the Minister's amendments, and assuming that exploration agreements are reached between traditional owners and miners, there remain a number of problems which have been identified by the mining industry, which will ultimately have the task of putting the Federal Government's theory into practice. The industry tells us that it cannot do it. The amendments, as the Minister has proposed them, would be unworkable under certain circumstances if they became law. For example, there is inadequate provision for some forms of Northern Territory mining tenements. One of the largest mining companies in Australia has identified a number of problems with the Bill in its present form, and concludes that if it is passed, as drafted, it will result in widespread industry dissatisfaction.

The point has been made that the Bill needs to mesh in with the Northern Territory mining legislation. It is a matter of regret that the Bill has been foisted on the Senate at extremely short notice, giving senators very little opportunity to examine it and giving industry an equally inadequate period in which to scrutinise it. One can only wonder whether this short period for consideration of the Bill is intentional and designed to minimise the chances of the mining industry seeing through the gloss of the removal of the veto at the mining stage and discovering some very significant cracks in the specific provisions of the Bill. Amendments which would rectify a number of deficiencies which have been identified by the mining industry will be moved by the opposition at a later stage.

There are very many more matters that one could bring up in the second reading debate on these important Bills. However, time is not now with me and some important matters that are extremely pertinent to these Bills will be raised in the Committee stage.
