TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking on the Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Bill and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Amendment Bill insofar as they affect the Aboriginal people of Lake Condah and the Framlingham Forest in south-west Victoria, and I shall confine my speech to those aspects of the Bills. The aim of this legislation is to enable three Bills which were passed in the Legislative Assembly of the Victorian Parliament but which did not pass the Legislative Council to become law. The Legislative Council is Victoria's upper House and, like the Senate, does not have a Government majority-by a margin of one vote. Thus legislation passed in the lower House cannot pass if it is opposed by both the Liberal and National parties, which incidentally, have been separate in Victoria for some time. The Victorian Government has, after two years of frustration about fulfilling its obligations to some of its Aboriginal citizens, asked the Commonwealth Government to enact the Bills. This is a matter of Federal-State co-operation, in contrast to the situation in Tasmania that has been discussed in this chamber recently.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kilgariff, in his speech, claimed that these Bills frustrate the due process of the State legislature. On the contrary, they enable the will of the Victorian Government to be realised, and it is significant that, as a senator for Victoria, I have received absolutely no representations opposing this legislation, whereas I have received a great deal of support from a number of sections of the population.

The Victorian Bills were the Aboriginal Land (Framlingham Forest) Bill (No. 2) 1986, the Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah) Bill 1986 and the Aboriginal Cultural Heritage Bill 1986. The purpose of the Aboriginal Land (Framlingham Forest) Bill (No. 2) was to grant inalienable title to 11 square kilometres of land adjacent to an area previously granted to the traditional owners in a previous Bill. The Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah) Bill sought to grant title to 0.5 square kilometres to the traditional owners of that land. The aim of the Aboriginal Cultural Heritage Bill 1986 was to directly involve Aboriginal communities in the preservation of objects and places of cultural or historical significance to the traditional owners.

The Bills before the State Parliament resulted from at least three years of discussions between the Victorian Government and the Victorian Aboriginal community, and incorporate a recognition by the Victorian Government that the land was taken from its traditional owners by force, without consideration of compensation. Unfortunately the Victorian Opposition, for reasons best known to itself, saw fit to oppose these Bills. It sought to amend the legislation to give the Aboriginal communities alienable freehold title, which would mean the land could be sold or mortgaged, despite the fact that the conservative Bolte Government had granted inalienable freehold title to the Lake Tyers and Framlingham Aboriginal communities in 1970. I never thought I would find myself standing here supporting the actions of the Bolte Government, but in this case that Government was certainly more progressive and in more touch with community opinion than its successors in the present Victorian Opposition.

So the Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Bill will implement the intent of two of the Victorian Bills which were frustrated by the Legislative Council. It seeks to vest the Framlingham Forest and the Lake Condah land in two Aboriginal corporations. This will give these two bodies full powers of management and control of their land, subject to the laws of the Commonwealth and of the State of Victoria.

The two Aboriginal communities of traditional owners will be incorporated under the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act 1976, which will provide for a community council and committee of elders for each community. These bodies will have local government-type powers to make by-laws concerning the protection of flora and fauna and use of and access to the land. Such by-laws will be gazetted and be subject to approval by the Minister and to disallowance by the Commonwealth Parliament.

The communities will be obliged to keep a register of sites on this land which are sacred and significant. This register would be kept by each Aboriginal corporation so as to prevent disclosure of its contents without the permission of the committee of elders. There will be provision for the register to be made available to the Minister if the Minister has to make a decision relating to the granting of permission for mining operations. The Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Bill also provides for the regulation of mining activity on the two parcels of land, and for the establishment of two trust funds to receive moneys for distribution in accordance with the Bill.

Although this Bill, together with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Amendment Bill, comes to us at the request of the Victorian Government and on its initiative, it is consistent with other Aboriginal land rights initiatives of the Commonwealth, such as the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 and the other Bill being debated cognately today. I believe that members of the Victorian Opposition did a very great disservice to public understanding of these Bills over a number of months by making outrageous allegations in the State Parliament and elsewhere as to what their passage would mean for the people of Victoria. For example, several Victorian Opposition members alleged that the Bill would enable the whole of Victoria to be carved up and allocated to Aboriginal groups. In spite of this allegation that all Victorian land was threatened, several members of the Victorian Opposition claimed that they would support the Bills if they gave ordinary freehold title to the Aboriginal communities. In other words, they presented two totally inconsistent views.

Such a proposal to grant freehold title flies in the face of the wishes of the Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest Aboriginal communities. It reverses the policy of the Victorian Liberal Party under the Bolte Government, to which I referred before, and demonstrates a complete lack of understanding by the Victorian Liberal and National parties of the relationship between Aboriginal communities and their land. Mr David Hawker, the Federal member for Wannon, alleged in the Portland Observer-a local newspaper-of 6 April 1987 that the Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs had not consulted properly local Aboriginals. However, the Victorian and Federal governments' extensive consultations with a wide range of Aboriginal organisations throughout Victoria are in stark contrast to the whistle-stop tour to Lake Condah in March by the Federal Opposition spokesperson on Aboriginal affairs, Mr David Connolly-I assume he is still the Opposition spokesperson. This tour was roundly condemned by the Lake Condah and District Aboriginal Co-operative which claimed:

. . . the Connollys, Hawkers and Co. of the world prefer to have a feed now and not worry too much about the future. They have no understanding of Aboriginal values, customs and our belief in securing a land base for future generations.
A similar whistle-stop tour by Jeff Kennett, the Leader of the Victorian Opposition pro team, was referred to by the Framlingham Aboriginal Trust as a:
. . . General Custer-style Gallop through the Western District media with quotes like `No land was safe from Aboriginal Land Acquisitions'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he say that on his car phone?

—Probably. No, the language was too pure for the car phone. That trip was also notable for its lack of consultation with the traditional land owners. The Victorian Opposition's propaganda seems aimed solely at hiding the fact that the Victorian Opposition has no viable Aboriginal policy. The Australian Mining Industry Council, in a recent Press release that was sent to me, alleged that the Government is relying on the Tasmanian dams case to bolster constitutional support. This is not the case. The Commonwealth has a clear constitutional obligation to its Aboriginal citizens, conferred on it by the 1967 referendum which was supported across parties. I remember that this was one occasion on which I was in the unusual situation of handing out how to vote cards on the same roster as the Liberal Party. The Bills are in accordance with the generally bipartisan approach taken by this Parliament and should be supported by all honourable senators.

Nicholls Society, that there should be an address with the title that I have chosen-`Abuses of power in contemporary Australia'. I shall be canvassing what I regard as abuses of power across a quite wide spectrum.

—I ask a supplementary question. I notice from the official program of the conference that the Minister's name does not appear. Will the Minister be replacing any of the other speakers listed in the program, including Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, Mr John Stone, Mr Andrew Hay, Mr Brian Jackson, Mr Hugh Morgan, Mr Charles Copeman, Mr Bruce Perkins, Mr Neil Brown and Mr Paul Houlihan?

—I am not sure what arrangements Mr Stone or whoever is responsible has made, but when he first wrote to me he said that the brochure had already been printed and if I were able to attend or somebody else from the Government, the Society would make the appropriate arrangements. It has, I presume, made those arrangements but I do not know what they are. I understand, however, that the session at which I shall be speaking will be chaired by John Hyde. I think that is significant because one of the more trenchant and, in my view, effective critics of the Petersen regime in Australia has been John Hyde, even though some of the other people with whom he may be associated do not seem to be so worried about it.
—He has the intellectual backing of the Liberal Party of the Left.

—That is probably true. I have known him for a considerable time. Although he was not in any sort of alliance with me, we were pursuing a common objective in 1972-that is, the removal from the seat of Moore of the then Country Party sitting member. We both failed in 1972, but Mr Hyde succeeded in 1974.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. On what factual grounds does the Minister disagree that last night's health changes in the mini-Budget will lead to a rise of up to $50 a year in the cost of private health insurance which, on top of recent rises forced by last August's Budget, will mean that the one-third of Australians earning less than average weekly earnings who hold private health insurance will have been slugged up to an extra $125 a year after tax, in addition to last December's 25 per cent rise in the Medicare levy of about $50 or so that they are forced to pay? What provision has the Minister made in the mini-Budget for added funding of the public hospital system needed to cater for additional demand for its services that will result from lower income groups and pensioners being forced out of private hospital insurance by this Government's discriminatory, anti-private sector health policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that Senator Michael Baume, in phrasing his question, acknowledged that so much of the tremendous contribution which Medicare has made to the health care of Australians and their economic security whilst that health care is provided has been left untouched by the Treasurer's statement of last night-though, indeed, the Health portfolio has needed to make its contribution to the savings in expenditure that are required if this country is to face not only the next decade but the next millennium with some confidence. I believe that that general objective of the statement of the Treasurer last night, of course, has been achieved. The Health portfolio has made its contribution, but in a way which has not made any impact at all on the out of hospital contribution by Medicare to those who seek the services of doctors and health care professionals. The Medicare rebate for all out of hospital services is maintained at 85 per cent of the schedule fee, with a maximum patient contribution of $20. That needs to be emphasised for those who may be concerned. Of course, Medicare preserves the right of every citizen to have free hospital treatment as a Medicare-only patient.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to those patients who may be described as private patients, whether they receive their treatment in private or public hospitals, it is a fact that there has been a change insofar as the rebate available for them will be 75 per cent rather than 85 per cent of the schedule fee, with private health funds picking up the difference. Senator Baume suggested in his question that that will add--
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Mr President--
—He sat down. It is the end of the answer.
—I will sit down as long as I am interjected on in a way which prevents me from giving a sensible answer.
—Order! The Minister should be heard in silence.

—It is a fact that behind Senator Baume's question lies the implication that it will cost a family an extra dollar a week to fund the difference that the private health insurance funds will have to make up. The Government does not think that that is a necessary implication of last night's statement. Insofar as he asked for a factual basis for that lack of concurrence with his suggestion that an extra dollar a week will have to be paid by a family, one can point to the very substantial reserves held by the private health funds at the moment, which are in the region of half a billion dollars. Over $500m is held in reserves at the moment by the private health funds. One would expect that private insurance contribution rates, which may have to be altered, will certainly not have to be altered by an amount in the region of a dollar per week per family, because those very substantial funds will be able to absorb some of the extra costs.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to Senator Baume's concern about the impact of the statement last night on families in relation to their health care, one has only to remember that last time the Liberal and National parties were in coalition government two million Australians were stranded between holding a poor card to prove their credentials in order to get free treatment and having private insurance. Those two million Australians who could not afford private insurance were left stranded by the policies of the previous Government. If the health policy proposal of the Opposition to move $3 billion of costs from the public to the private sector is carried out it will require families in Australia to pay $27 a week in private insurance contributions. That would be a tremendous blow and would have a tremendously adverse effect on the disposable income of Australian families. Whilst the Health portfolio's contribution to last night's statement is significant in one aspect that has been mentioned by Senator Baume, I believe it is something that most Australians will see as a very sensible and moderate change in the Medicare system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The second half of my question asked what provision the Minister had made in the mini-Budget for added funding of the public hospital system that was needed to cater for additional demand for its services that will result from lower income groups and pensioners being forced out of private hospital insurance by this Government. While the Minister conceded in his reply that he did not expect that the additional cost would be a dollar a week-because of the existence of surpluses or reserves in some of the funds-he nonetheless conceded that there could well be a rise of some amount. In view of his admission, will he now say what provision the Minister has made for added funding of the public hospital system which is needed to cope with the additional demand?

—The clear implication of my answer was that the Government does not expect that the additional money which Australian families may have to contribute per week in order to cover the gap will necessitate the pressure on public hospital beds which is suggested in Senator Baume's question.

—The Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs will be aware of the deep concern of interested Australians about Australia's relatively low level of overseas aid compared with our promised 0.7 per cent of gross national product, and about the additional reduction of $20m announced in the Treasurer's economic statement last night, on top of the significant cuts in last August's Budget. Can the Minister tell the Senate how that further reduction can be justified and what the impact of the cuts in Australia's overseas aid vote will be?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian aid program, like most other areas of government activity, has had to share the burden of economic restraint necessitated by the Government's decision to introduce what has been the greatest cut in government expenditure for 30 years. The forward estimate for next year's aid program has been reduced by $20m and now stands at $1,005.8m. That represents in real terms a decline of 3.6 per cent on 1986-87 outlays, which were $976m. While the decision to reduce Australia's overseas aid funding was a most difficult one for the Australian Government, it simply reflects the stringency required in all areas of expenditure in current economic circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: Despite the savings, I should emphasise that all existing formal obligations, commitments and country pledges can be met and other programs can be maintained in real terms. The actual allocations to particular programs have not been finally determined. These will be decided in the Budget context. I can, however, assure Senator Coates at this stage that some key programs will not be affected. The Government's pledges to a range of recipient countries, including those in the South Pacific and the Philippines, can be accommodated, and so can our commitment to provide 300,000 tonnes of food aid under the Food Aid Convention. The Government is also able to proceed with an increased allocation to the DIF facility-the development import finance facility-which will increase from $16m to $30m, thus helping to promote Australian exports. Cuts have been made possible by a reduced funding requirement in some areas, such as the level of Budget support for Papua New Guinea, funding required to meet anticipated draw-downs by the international financial institutions, and the level of contribution by the aid program for overseas students studying at Australian institutions. This will decline as a result of an increase in the overseas student charge.

I should say finally, in response to Senator Coates's opening remarks about our commitment to 0.7 per cent as a target ratio of overseas aid as a percentage of gross national product, it is the case that this year's reduction in aid expenditure will reduce official development assistance as a percentage of GNP from 0.4 per cent in the current year to 0.36 per cent. I emphasise, however, that this remains above the average for the major aid donors represented in the OECD's Development Assistance Committee. The Government remains unequivocally committed to achieving that target ratio of 0.7 per cent and will pursue this objective as economic circumstances permit.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Is the Minister aware that the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre is $45,000 overdrawn due to the failure of his Department to release the previously allocated funds despite the fact that the Centre has provided expenditure advice to the Minister indicating that all expenditure over the past two months was within the conditions of grants? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Haines has asked a number of questions. On behalf of Mr Holding, I give her the following information in reply: I am informed that the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre commenced the 1986-87 financial year with a deficit of $12,000. At 31 December this deficit had accrued to $47,900. The TAC is expected to report its financial position to my Department before 31 May. The TAC has provided to my Department some details of its expenditure but not yet all. Further, the honourable senator will recall my informing the Senate yesterday that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has raised a number of questions with the TAC in relation to the recent activities of the Centre's solicitor, Mr Michael Mansell. The Minister has sought assurances as to whether any Commonwealth funds may have been employed in relation to Mr Mansell's visit to Libya or in relation to his recent activities in Australia not related to the discharge of his duties as a solicitor retained by the TAC. The response of the TAC is awaited. Consideration will be given to the next quarterly release of funds to the TAC once the inquiries referred to above have been completed.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the fourth part of Senator Haines's question is no. The Minister has not sought Cabinet approval to legislate for Aboriginal land rights in Tasmania. The Minister has been pursuing negotiations with the State Government and Tasmanian Aboriginal groups for some time. For the moment, the Minister will continue these attempts. However, the Minister cannot rule out the possibility of future Commonwealth action, should the Tasmanian Government maintain its intransigent position.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MAY ECONOMIC STATEMENT: IMPACT ON SMALL BUSINESS

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce been drawn to the comments of the Australian Small Business Association on the effect of the statement brought down last night by the Treasurer on small business? It is reported in the Australian Financial Review today that the Australian Small Business Association has condemned the statement as a confidence trick. In fact, the Federal President, Mr Peter Boyle, who is also the Acting Chairman of the Australian Federation of Employers, said that the Government had squibbed the issue by not addressing fundamental issues. Does the Minister agree with Mr Boyle's comments or does he take a different view on the impact of the statement on small business?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some things which I agree with Mr Boyle about and some things which I do not.
—He definitely agrees with Mr Boyle!
—The May economic statement is one thing which I clearly do not disagree with him about.
—You don't disagree with him! That is good.

—I will fix that up. Senator Chaney has stimulated me into further thinking about this matter. I cannot, as a matter of fact, at this moment recall any issue on which I agree with Mr Boyle. I would like to think that there would be one or two things that we could possibly agree on. Mr Boyle is one of those people who use an association as a personal launching pad for political statements.

ANSWER.PARA: The measures announced in the May statement last night, contrary to what he says, are aimed at reducing government spending and thereby easing pressure on interest rates, which is a matter of conceded fundamental concern to small business. The statement is an important part of the Government's economic and social strategy and will make a significant contribution to the prosperity of Australians in the medium to long term. Small business, along with the rest of the business community, will ultimately benefit from the spending cuts and the consequent improvement in Australia's economic outlook. I concede that in saying that there may be a difference between small business and large business. For example, the Business Council of Australia recommended that there be 5 per cent cuts across the board in industry assistance. That may well have suited the Business Council of Australia but it would have been very detrimental to the interests of many small to medium sized businesses, companies which in my view are very important and will perhaps, in the future, become members of the Business Council of Australia, given their current growth rates.

I find Mr Boyle's comments quite astounding because it is my view, and that of other intelligent impartial commentators, that the expected easing in interest rate pressures and enhanced prospects for industry will contribute greatly to the future performance of small business. One wonders whether Mr Boyle truly represents the view of small business or whether he is concerned, as I said, to use his organisation as a launching pad for political statements, as a significant number of espousers of lost right wing causes are at the present time. I will be very interested to hear the views of the Small Business Council, which was established as a Commonwealth-State initiative and which is bipartisan in its nature, when I meet with it in June and discuss its impressions of the effect of the statement on small business operators. I certainly had the benefit of its views before the statement was made. I think it is unlikely that it will adopt a similar attitude to that given by Mr Boyle in his statement last night.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MAY ECONOMIC STATEMENT: HOUSING INTEREST RATES

—Thank you, Mr President. Has the Minister read the speech made by Mr Hayden when he presented the Media Peace Awards for 1986, in which he referred to the pervasive influence that secrecy has in fuelling the arms race? Given the reference to the United States National Security Agency operations in Australia in several books, journals and newspapers, such as the Asian Defence Journal, will the Minister explain why, in light of Mr Hayden's comments on secrecy, he still refuses to admit what he knows, the public knows and the Soviets obviously know, that the National Security Agency operates in Australia with our own security and intelligence agencies, and that the NSA will be involved in the latest intelligence operation near Geraldton?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a speech made when presenting the Media Peace Awards on 24 October last year, Mr Hayden did make such a reference about the virtues of the Fourth Estate in the context of the arms race. In order that his remarks be understood in context, I will quote the relevant passage in full. Mr Hayden said:

ANSWER.PARA: Jerome Weisner, who was President Kennedy's science adviser, made the point recently: `An effective way to build a common security system,' he said, `is to substitute information for weapons.' The longer and more closely the phenomenon we call the arms race is examined, the more obvious becomes the validity of this statement; the more obvious becomes the pervasive influence that secrecy has had and still has in fuelling the arms race. The media therefore has a central role to play in the pursuit and protection of peace.

I guess they are sentiments with which we would all agree. As to the second part of Senator Vallentine's question, which actually seeks specific information, I have to say that, in seeking a response from the Government about what is essentially speculation regarding intelligence matters, it has been the long-standing practice of this and previous governments neither to confirm nor to deny speculation of this type. Accordingly, I decline to provide a response.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the Minister recall that, in the Government's May 1985 economic statement, the Treasurer announced that five surplus migrant centre buildings and associated land would be sold to yield an estimated $16.6m in 1985-86, and that the administration of the defence service home loans scheme would be handed over to the private sector at a saving of $60m in 1985-86 and about $120m in a full year? Is it a fact that neither of these commitments were met in 1985-86 and that indeed the only thing that has yet occurred is the sale of one of the five migrant centre buildings for proceeds of only $630,000? In view of the critical importance to the Government's 1987-88 Budget strategy of the $1,000m assets sales announced last night, I ask whether the Government will give an undertaking that that proposed sale of assets will not suffer the same inglorious fate as those announced in 1985. I also ask whether the $1,000m is a gross or a net figure. If it is a gross figure, what are the Government's estimates of the additional costs involved through the leasing of accommodation and the like?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Regarding two of the items from the 1985 statement mentioned by Senator Short, to the best of my recollection the facts are as he stated them in that the sale was not completed in 1985-86. However, I recall in the same statement another asset sale, that is, the Belconnen Mall, which was completed-I think, on 1 April 1986-well within time despite attempts by the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association and the former Speaker of the House of Assembly to sabotage the sale.
—Despite the inability of the previous Government to sell it.

—Yes, and, as Senator Button reminds me, thereby to emulate the incompetence or lack of performance of the previous Government, which made the same decision but never got around to carrying it out. Indeed, it was the first, to use the vernacular, razor gang exercise of 1981, which had been preceded by months of hype from the Fraser Government and the Treasurer of the day about massive cuts in government expenditure and programs. As I recall it, the final result was a list which was supposed to total $360m, most of which never happened.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the items in this year's list, the Government believes that the total value of the assets listed for sale is a good deal more than $1 billion. I will not be more precise than that because obviously it would be very silly for the Government to make known its notional reserve price on a lot of those assets, just in case there is someone in the market-place willing to pay more. We would indeed be failing in our duty to the taxpayers if we failed to receive the maximum price for that sort of reason. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Am I to take it from the Minister's answer that a calculation is included in last night's figures for the ongoing costs involved through consequential leasing of accommodation for the redevelopment of the Tokyo Chancellery site and the like? Is such a figure included in last night's statement?

—There is-but I am not going to disclose it-an estimate in that bulk total for the sale, or perhaps long term lease, of part of the Tokyo site, along with pencilled-in estimates of what we might expect to get for a number of the other assets. The figure pencilled in for the Tokyo site is net of our remaining accommodation requirements.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education. I draw the Minister's attention to the announcement in the May economic statement concerning the abolition of unemployment benefits for 16- and 17-year olds. What will be the effect of this decision on the participation of young people in education and training? How will the Government adapt its policies and programs to meet the consequences of this decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the first thing to say about this decision is that it is a very constructive step towards providing young people with useful options in their teenage years-education, training, work or some combination of those options. I strongly believe that the step we have taken will ensure that young people move into those three constructive options. The decision should be seen also in conjunction with our Government's record in increasing the participation of young people in education and training. I remind the Senate that already the number of young people participating in years 10 to 12 has increased by 118,000 since our Government came to office-an increase in the retention rate by 40 per cent to a record level of half our young people. The initiatives announced last night provide positive incentives for young people to stay at school, particularly those from low income families who have always tended to leave school before completing a comprehensive secondary education.

ANSWER.PARA: Education allowances for the first time in the history of this country will relate wholly to the age of the young person regardless of the type of education that he or she is involved in, and will equal on a means tested basis the rate of benefit for young unemployed people of the same age. No Austudy allowance will decrease and the levels of allowance for the majority will increase by a large proportion. For example, rates of assistance have increased from a mere $16.70 a week in 1983 to $50.00 a week for 16- and 17-year olds, and $60.00 a week for the 18- plus age group, in 1988. Similarly, the maximum rate for secondary and tertiary students aged 18 years and over who live away from home or are independent will have increased from $59.45 in 1983 to $91.20 next year.

The importance of our commitment to young people is shown by the fact that, in a time of severe economic restraint and even when the savings on the Forward Estimates are taken into account, we will still be spending over $100m more on Austudy assistance in 1987-88 than we have spent in this financial year. In addition, $32.5m will be directed through the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations to the support and establishment of training courses. I think in terms of preparing young people for the future needs of the work force, in giving individual young people positive and constructive options, this series of decisions is a historic step forward.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether he is aware that one of the factors which the Treasurer used last night to justify his claim that the Government's economic policies were working was:

QUESTION.PARA: Investment has begun to increase, especially in manufacturing.

It is not a fact that, despite a welcome small increase in private business investment for the December quarter of last year, both the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the recent Confederation of Australian Industry-Westpac survey predict a fall in real terms in investment in industry for 1987-88? Does the Minister agree with the Treasurer's statement? If not, why is the Government not telling the whole truth about investment in industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, let me say that this matter came up in the economic statement last night and it was referred to in the context of rising exports and declining imports. That was the context in which the Treasurer addressed this general issue. He was talking particularly about the manufacturing sector, a point which I made in an answer to Senator Chaney earlier today. In fact, manufacturing exports increased by 32 per cent in, I think, the last 10 months. I am not sure of the precise period, but I think it was the 10 months prior to the end of March compared with the previous 10 months.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as investment is concerned, the last real survey material which Senator Messner referred to in his question showed an 8 per cent real increase in manufacturing investment in the December quarter of 1986. That is a significant increase in investment in manufacturing in Australia. We have had no survey material, I think, since then other than surveys of investment intentions conducted by such bodies as the CAI-Westpac group, which survey intentions and expectations in respect of various industries. In looking at the investment question, it is very important, in regard to some of these surveys and so on, to compare like with like. When looking at the aggregate investment performance in Australia now compared with that of such years as 1981-82, when there was enormous investment in the mining sector, much of it talked up by Ministers of the time-there was an enormous talking up of investment and anticipation in respect of the mining sector-and when we compare the volume and value of the investment at present, we have to consider the fact that there is at present very little investment in the mining and mineral sector, apart from gold, which would in any way provide a comparable figure with the period of 1981-82. It is in that context that the real increases in manufacturing investment have to be seen. I think the figure for the December quarter is quite encouraging and it should not be seen in isolation from a variety of other factors.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. The Reserve Bank of Australia's bulletin of February 1987 shows, on page 9, an increase of $29 billion in private sector debt in the non-finance sector for 1985-86. That is a very large amount of money compared with the $4 billion that the Government has just cut from government expenditure. Is not the Government concerned that, under its policy of absolute deregulation of all money markets, the majority of this $29 billion is likely to go into such things as stock market speculation or other speculative areas-because they are so profitable-and that very little of this amount is likely to find its way into productive investments to create jobs and to improve our export potential?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —A few points should be noted at the outset. The $29 billion increase in private sector debt would include debt which is owed overseas, but it includes very much more than that. As the term indicates, it is the total private sector debt, apart from that of financial institutions, for pretty obvious reasons. The Reserve Bank bulletin shows that aggregate figure as standing presently at $208 billion, up from $179 billion in the year before. I think that figure is in dollars of the day, too, but I am not quite sure of that. There is an indication on the table that the figures going back beyond that time are not strictly comparable. I am not sure why this is the case, but the figure for 1983-84, for example, is $157 billion. That aggregate figure includes, among other things, debt owed on owner occupied housing.

ANSWER.PARA: The linkage between the increase in that debt within Australia and more money being made available for speculation on the stock market eludes me but I do share Senator Siddons's concern that speculation on the stock market-indeed, speculation anywhere at all-usually produces, in the end, some pretty anti-social outcomes. I do share his concern that we may have moved now into a danger area in the present notional value-or paper value-of shares on the Australian Stock Exchange. But I really do not see how an increase in the debt owed by private citizens and private businesses in Australia makes more money available for indulgence in that sort of activity.

—Is the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women aware of reports that the decision to means test family allowances will disproportionately affect women and that this decision will neutralise the effects of the tax cuts that have been, and will be, put in place by this Government?

—I have heard some comments along these lines. It is the case that family allowances, as they are paid directly to women, have always been an important source of additional income for women caring for children. However, when the Government is asking all members of the community to share in economic restraint, we consider that in the present circumstances an income test on families with incomes above $50,000 is justified. The decision is consistent with the Government's policy to target assistance to those most in need. To say that women will be disproportionately affected is to overestimate the number of families that will be means tested. Only 10 per cent or 200,000 families across Australia will be affected. Those families are relatively advantaged in the community, earning as they do more than twice the level of average weekly earnings. In addition, by 1 July these families will have gained significant increases in disposable income through the combined effects of our tax cuts. For a single income family with one child--
—That is a single person on $50,000.

—Senator Walters obviously does not want to hear the facts but I believe that all other honourable senators will be interested. Senator Chaney, for example, has raised this matter time and time again. So I point out that for a single income family with one child earning $970 a week, which is just over the point where family allowances begin to taper, the combined effects of the tax cuts under the Hawke Government are $61.98 a week. For a dual income family on incomes of $30,000 and $20,000, the combined tax cuts amount to $39.32 a week. The family allowance that these families begin to lose at these income levels is $5.70 a week, a very small sum when the tax cuts are taken into account. In addition, families with more than one child will have even greater gains with an additional $2,500 a year allowed before family allowance starts to taper. The decision announced by the Treasurer last night overtakes the decision announced in last year's Budget to put a sudden death income test on family allowance for 16- and 17-year-olds where the family income exceeds $39,000 so those families also are in an improved position as a result of last night's budgetary decisions. In conclusion, it is clear that those families that will suffer some reduction or total reduction in family allowance payments will, when we take into account totality of effect of the tax cuts, certainly still come out very much ahead.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the advertisements. Indeed, I have a copy of it here. It makes that claim to which Senator Cook and a number of others have referred. It is true that average annual days lost per employee as a result of industrial disputes are higher in Australia than in Japan or West Germany-indeed, a good deal higher. But the Australian figure has improved very substantially since 1983, as we all know, or should know. Japan and West Germany have fundamentally different industrial relations systems. Indeed, in the case of Japan, I think it would be generally agreed that it has a fundamentally different culture, which really makes it not fairly comparable. Against countries with which, on cultural and other grounds, Australia is much more comparable, since 1983 we have had a substantially lower strike rate than the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Canada, Italy and a number of other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. I have a table referring to days lost through industrial disputes or per working employee in 14 OECD countries, which I now table.

ANSWER.PARA: We should not be complacent that we have done considerably better in recent years than those countries to which I have referred. However, this shows that a great deal has been achieved since the accord came into operation in 1983. There is certainly no rational reason to believe that that achievement should be thrown away for the alternative of confrontation, which is very clearly the course upon which the Queensland Government has embarked. The Petersen regime's anti-union campaign and seeking of confrontation does not have anything to do with Australia's international competitiveness-it has a great deal to do with politics and the Petersen regime's desire to get itself re-elected in one way or another; and, more importantly, with the chief of that regime because he thinks it will give some impetus to his flagging campaign to get himself elected to the Federal Parliament. TALK.START.PARA: —The ninth annual report of the Legal Aid Commission of the Australian Capital Territory is indeed a timely reminder that many Australians-possibly a majority of Australians-cannot afford to pursue justice in issues or individual episodes. This is one reason why legal aid commissions have been established around the nation and why we have such bodies as the Canberra Welfare Rights Centre which is a specialised body operating on the community legal centre model. As legislators we should not be satisfied just with the existence of such bodies and forget about the simplification of procedures, reforms of the law and awareness by the people of their rights. We should not just rely on the existence of legal aid as an excuse for not pursuing actively the decrease in the cost of justice in Australia. When we look at the guidelines for the Australian Capital Territory Legal Aid Commission we see, for instance, that small claims court matters are excluded, as are class actions unless all individuals in a class qualify under a means test arrangement. Limited funds are available to the Commission and decisions have to be made about the deployment of these funds.

SPEECH.PARA: During this short presentation I would like to concentrate on the need for real legal reform in the Australian Capital Territory so that the energies of the Legal Aid Commission can be directed to produce greater good for the people of Canberra. For instance, for some years there has been a proposal for a small claims tribunal. This has been toing and froing between the Department of Territories and the Attorney-General's Department. The difference is that the processes within a tribunal would be very much more informal and would not daunt so many people from approaching the law to try to get justice. We have to recognise that, for a lot of people, having to fill in forms which they do not really understand is a real worry. What might have been a matter readily resolved in a conference becomes bogged down in paperwork and unnecessarily jams the court system.

The tenancy and public housing matters could be dealt with much more sensibly on an informal basis if we had such a tribunal. These types of tribunals are present in a number of States. The Social Security Appeals Tribunal is recognised as a very good model for providing justice in an effective and inexpensive manner. I believe there is plenty of room for improvement in administrative matters in the Australian Capital Territory and in simplifying the processes of appeal.

There is also a need for more educational work in the community about what people's legal rights really are. The Legal Aid Commission and the Welfare Rights Centre are involved in some of these activities, which provide citizens with an understanding of their rights. The Law Society of the Australian Capital Territory also provides a free lunch-time advisory service. These are essential steps in demystifying the law for people. Another welcome development is being sponsored for an alternative dispute settlement procedure. That is the possibility of a community mediation service in the Australian Capital Territory. Such a facility is available in New South Wales and has helped there to resolve many disputes where an adversary system might have inflamed these disputes.

A matter which I believe needs rapid resolution in the Australian Capital Territory is the appeals system for variation in lease purpose clauses. The whole land planning and lease administration system needs a full judicial inquiry because of a succession of disasters in inner city development. We have a situation where the Supreme Court is the first testing ground for such appeals. This makes it almost impossible for most people to stand up for their rights. The situation is made worse when the Department of Territories and the National Capital Development Commission use their financial muscle to strangle legitimate public disquiet. We saw this with the Town House Motel redevelopment case where the Conservation Council of the South-East Region and Canberra Inc. had to withdraw from an excellent case because of lack of funds. The Government sought to recover costs instead of agreeing to test the ordinance on grounds of public interest. I believe that that is most unacceptable bullying. We have seen similar tactics in the Morpath case, where the Minister has appealed against the original decision. The Youth Accommodation Group has raised $7,000 to keep the case alive and only now are there signs that the Attorney-General's Department will provide some aid under the public interest guidelines.
