TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Messner has moved:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes the depressed investment climate in this country as exemplified by a number of recent surveys published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics and other private sector organisations, including the Australian Chamber of Manufactures.

He condemns the Federal Government for this depressed investment environment and the ever increasing taxes and charges. He deplores the anti-business impact of the new dividend imputation and its interaction with the foreign tax credit system.

This is the day after the Government's mayday call. The ship of state is foundering on the rocks of a short-sighted, final sell-out of our last remaining assets. Yesterday's Budget has moved us from the prospect of becoming a banana republic to that of becoming a manana republic. Everything is being deferred. Education, social welfare, defence spending and communications are all being deferred. In fact, our whole infrastructure is being deferred. Governing this country is being deferred, and that is really the problem we face.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can't we defer Hawke and Keating?
—Mr Keating seems to be down in the bowels of the ship screwing holes in the bilge while Mr Brown is upstairs advertising the place for tourists.
—Now, now!

—It is all in the mind, Senator. We will end up with a long string of pot holes in place of a road system. The bicentennial pothole competition is now in process-especially after the cuts in both State facilities and the road funds. The last attack is under way on any type of investment into the future. This is not complementary to what Senator Button is trying to do; his efforts are being sabotaged by his cabinet colleagues.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us just take a look at one of the measures of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It all started with the advertisement of Priority One: Young Australia. That has become Priority Lost. Our youth is being sacrificed to the treadmills of foreign mill owners. Education is not seen as a national asset but as a personal gift to students who may one day become a threat to our foreign owners if they challenge the foreign control of our technology and innovation. The Government is intent on returning us to a serfdom in which we are completely controlled by foreign investment. The Australian Labor Party has given up its policy ideals. The Government is buying the view that we want serf labour to fulfil the needs of international business. It is allowing the country's economy to be run by people outside this country, by the gnomes of Zurich, by the foreign investment bankers of Wall Street and by the gurus of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. It is not taking its own advice or following policies which those in the Labor Party set up and nurtured for many many years. In fact, I maintain that we are in a spiral of doom. Yesterday's Budget was very clever because basically it took all the friends of the Labor Party and hurt them or removed things from them. The Budget did no harm at all to people who might change their vote to the ALP. I believe that it is scandalous that the Labor Party has forsaken the people who have stood up for it for so long. I do not think that that will continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —To whom are you referring?

—I am referring to the students, the working people of this country, the unemployed, the disabled and the women who have been amongst the strongest supporters of the Labor Party and whom the Government has now abandoned to the mercy of large business organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government believes in corporate welfare instead of social, personal and individual welfare. It is sacrificing people to the economy. In this Budget the Government has tried to get money invested in Australia; it has raised interest rates and those interest rates are harming the ordinary people of this country. They are harming those people who cannot afford to be harmed. The prospects of escape from the general treadmill and the poverty traps have been cut off for most people. Education has been squeezed. Further education has been cut in this mini-Budget so that if people do not get a job immediately they cannot move from one area of work to another, they cannot retrain. The Government's whole operation is moving in the wrong direction. A load has been put on those in the community who are always the hardest hit. Our young people have been put into strait-jackets. The universities, colleges and technical and further education colleges have suffered cutbacks. This has all been done in order to make Australia apparently attractive to foreign investment. I believe that assumption is wrong. We need a planned, stable economy and we need to develop the skills of Australian people in order to operate that economy effectively. Just at the time when Australian industry is calling for more investment in education and retraining, the TAFE scheme has been cut. At the time when we most need investment in skills and technological knowledge in the work force, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the TAFE system and the university system have been hit.

I uphold that this Government has no concept of a planned economy. It has no business plan for `Australia Incorporated'. It is running scared because of the large deficits which it has been responsible for developing. It has no investment plans for the future for the Australian people. Its ideas are bankrupt. In the absence of controlled government planning, Australia is at the mercy of foreign investors. It is also at the mercy of absentee media barons who can impose their will on this Government. Business plans are being put upon us by default. This is a reason for sadness. The Government has been indulging in a huge sell-out of Australian assets for some time. It has now stepped up the selling of government assets. This is a one-time operation and the Government is putting this money into the current account to try to make it balance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you understand that or not? Do you understand the benefit of the Budget?

—I understand what is happening. I understand what the Government sees as the benefits of the Budget. I believe that we can balance the books by getting our industries in order, by getting them working effectively, by encouraging investment in industry and in productive capacity, by investing in education, by developing our skills and by making people in Australia want to work for the welfare of `Australia Incorporated' as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not understand why the Government is squeezing everybody short-sightedly. Small business is being hit hard and faces great difficulties in meeting the interest rates which the Government is presiding over. The Government does not realise that there is no reason why internal interest rates should match the external interest rates which from time to time may have to be paid to balance the external budget. If we can set up some type of barrier around the economy in the form of a tax on money leaving the country, I believe we can maintain investment in the country by those who care about our productive capacity rather than pander to those who just bring money in for pure speculation and to heat up the stock market. What has been happening is that the type of money that has been attracted to Australia by the Government's program has been the wrong type of money.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hot money.

—Probably hot money, as the honourable senator says. The inflows of foreign capital are having an adverse effect on our export prospects and these moneys are not being productively invested. Less than 5 per cent of this foreign money ends up in any form of productive investment. Most of this investment is still of a speculative nature, and is being used to buy up the farm on the cheap.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has further encouraged the selling off of Australian resources. It has pulled the teeth from the Foreign Investment Review Board and relaxed nearly all the constraints on foreign takeover of Australian resources, land, industry and development. This it has done in the name of deregulation, which is its latest god. It has kept interest rates high to depress local industry, while allowing a free-for-all in the scramble by foreign investors to buy our industry and resources and to go in for the kill in terms of the total control of our economy. This Government, although it may not even realise it, is serving foreign interests. I believe that it is the enemy of real Australian business, of real Australian workers and of ordinary Australian citizens.

On top of the high interest burdens and the resulting problems for exporters and small business, particularly farmers, the Government has failed to manage its own business as badly as it has managed the economy as a whole. It was re-elected on a promise of tax reform, on a platform of deregulation of business. Certainly it has deregulated in favour of foreign investors, foreign banks and foreign media interests, but it has failed completely to cut the red tape that ties up small Australian business at every stage. It is adding, even in this mini-Budget, more red tape for all people. It is bringing in means tests which are totally uneconomic ways of controlling the social distribution of wealth.

The Government has failed to come to grips with the tax reform problem because it lost its nerve at the National Taxation Summit. It has failed to grasp the principles of good business management, of conservation of resources and assets, and of maximising profits and minimising costs, principles which are fundamental to any type of business operation. In fact, what it is doing with the resource rent tax it put up the other day is giving a free run to a number of external oil companies.

The examples of poor government, poor management of government business, are indeed many. The Government is running down, selling off and giving away quite a large number of our assets. I am not talking about the gardens of the Embassy in Tokyo or about the Paris Embassy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is: What are you talking about? You do not know.
—I am talking about stupid decisions like selling off the government offices in Sydney and Melbourne and the Government having to pay rent on those offices after that.
—That is not true.
—What does the Minister intend to do?
—I am not here to answer questions, but you should not make the allegation because it is untrue.
—The mini-Budget states that the Government intends to sell them off. Where will the Government put the public servants? Are we to get rid of them too? Maybe that might be a good idea.
—The allegation Senator Vigor has just made is not true.
—That the Government will have to pay rent?
—Yes.

—That is interesting. I shall be interested to hear eventually the Government's magic scheme, what pot of gold it has at the end of the rainbow to house public servants, because I can see no other explanation in the statement made in the mini-Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some places where this Budget will hurt business and where it will not help to get good business investment in Australia. The one thing that Australia used to offer was a reasonably high standard of living, with reasonably well-educated people who could carry on technologically and socially desirable projects and could work towards adding more value to the enormous resource of primary materials in both mining and farming products. This Government has missed the opportunity to encourage that type of investment, to get investment into more value-added enterprises. It has been cutting out the infrastructure which allows business to work-the roads, communications, housing, energy and water infrastructure. All those areas are being run down at escalating rates.

In my view the mini-Budget is somewhat of a disaster. We shall end up paying more for our transportation as the Government sells airports and promotes ideas such as privatising our national airlines while still keeping on some of the regulations, as has been mooted. I refer also to the way in which the Government is strangling Telecom, which is offering a reasonable communications service for the whole of industry; the way in which it is ripping funds off Australia Post in this Budget; and the way in which it is failing to develop new industries to face the oil crisis which will hit this country fairly soon. We are not investing enough in the area of renew- able energy resources. We were the leaders in solar energy research. We have had some leading projects in liquefaction of fuel gases. We have had leading projects which have just gone overseas in the high-tech area simply because there has not been the support from Australian governments. I refer, for example, to the Sarich fuel injection system.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not know what you are talking about again.

—The Government has put some resources into the Sarich orbital engine, but the Minister himself said that it was probably better if the Sarich fuel injection system were developed and produced nearer the points where the large proportion of cars were produced, outside Australia.
—I did not say that. I said it should be developed here and it would make sense for it to be manufactured near centres with large manufacturing use of the engine. That is a commercial decision.

—I believe that if we develop things here, we should be using and manufacturing them here. We should use the fact that we have such skills and knowledge to the advantage of Australians, not just to the advantage of a few. At this time Australia's future wealth and development depend on maintaining our growing skills base. All sectors of the economy are calling for increased investment to increase that skills base. But the Government has introduced a student administration charge and has cut the level of funding for technical colleges, which provide retraining in a very effective way within the community. It has cut out the community employment program, under which people were retrained and moved from one area to another in a very effective way. It has not really replaced these schemes with any other effective scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: Our natural resources are being flogged off under this policy of encouraging foreign investment. Our minerals are being shipped out of Australia to be processed into manufactured goods with a high value-added component in overseas so-called developed economies. We are not using any type of resource diplomacy to make certain that the firms which take these products from our soil actually put more effort into Australia by providing jobs and by using our skilled labour.

Our primary produce is being given away, as our farmers struggle to make ends meet in the world trade wars between our major trading partners. The only assets which have not been bought out to a major extent are our individual farms and small businesses. They are the ones that are being squeezed by the overall policies that this Government is operating. The citrus industry and the wine industry have been mercilessly hit by taxation measures which the Democrats oppose, but which were supported by both sides of the House. Currently we are even looking at selling off a number of public institutions. Privatisation has been mooted for a number of our service industries such as Telecom Australia, the airports, our standards laboratories and our materials laboratories. All of these proposals need to be looked at very closely. It is important that this Government, which is devoted to corporate welfare, should also consider the welfare of ordinary Australians.

We must ask: Why do we need business investment in Australia? I believe that business investment should not be used as a means of producing good figures in order to make the Government look good to foreign bankers. It is needed so that we can have a better standard of living and so that we can provide better educational opportunities for the people of Australia and welfare for those in our community who are less well-off. If we can be a thriving business that can support these objectives, we are succeeding as a nation. Unfortunately, I believe that we have somewhat lost our way. I believe that somehow we have to get citizens to be more productive. I do not believe that the measures that we have in this mini-Budget are encouraging this, either at the first order or even at the second order.

Ordinary Australians are being pursued for more taxes, while huge tax rorts are seen to be operating for business. I refer to the large transfer pricing rorts, the operation of large overseas tax havens and the huge surge of takeover activity and stock market activity which has arisen from the negative gearing concessions given to big business, but denied to ordinary Australians who might own a flat which they are keeping for their retirement.

The dividend imputation changes to the tax system represent another looming disaster for the Government. I believe that this is another gift to big business and the multinational corporations which are in a position to exploit the new provisions of the foreign tax credit system. The Government is short-sighted. It is blind to the excesses of its friends-the corporate giants, the takeover merchants and the media barons. It is unthinkingly prepared to accept the advice of the Stone clones in the Treasury and to respond to those who are putting forward economic policies which put economic statistics before people. That is very sad when the treasury bench is inhabited by people who are of a Labor persuasion. The Labor Party has some very good policies. It is extremely important that those policies be considered by government. I urge all senators and the people of Australia to look closely at whether this Government is fulfilling the responsibilities which it had a mandate to fulfil. It was elected on the basis of those policies. I recommend to everybody that they re-examine their voting, that they re-examine what they will do at the next election and see exactly what it is that Labor is offering. I believe that those people--

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not help you.

—It may not help me, but it will certainly help the country. I say to Senator Button that the Labor Party and the country are suffering from `new rightis'. The New Right seems to be overcoming even within the Government. Senator Button's Government has accepted the terminology and the forms of words which the New Right put forward. It is displacing the Liberal Party by implementing a number of those types of policies in these budgetary measures which it has put forward in the mini-Budget. I commend Senator Messner's motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, commend Senator Messner for bringing this motion before the Senate. It is two or three weeks since the debate was adjourned. Therefore, it is worth reiterating the main points of Senator Messner's motion which, in part, reads:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) notes the depressed investment climate in this country . . .

(b) condemns the Federal Government for this depressed investment environment which is a direct result of the high interest rate policy pursued by the Government, pushing the small business and prime interest rates to record levels;

(c) notes the depressing effect which ever-increasing Government taxes and charges, such as the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax, are having on the after-tax real rate of return on business investment; and
(d) deplores the lack of appreciation by the Government of the anti-business impact of the new legislation on dividend imputation and its interaction with the foreign tax credit system.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what your new-found ally here says.

—On some points we agree, but not all, much as I admire Senator Vigor's vigorous advocacy in this chamber. The thing that disturbs me, and which I think is a matter of grave concern-I urge the Government to look again at its policies-is that the Government has produced a range of anti-business policies at the very time when the business climate in Australia is deteriorating. The Senate may have noted reports over the past week or so emanating from expert international organisations-I have in mind in particular the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development-which have pointed out to the Western world that the economic climate facing industrialised countries and therefore all nations, and the outlook over a year or more ahead, are the worst and gloomiest for decades. I think that is a very serious state of affairs which the Government has not taken into account in the framing of its economic policies.

SPEECH.PARA: The slow-down in world economic activity has not really hit us as yet, but it is going to do so increasingly over the period ahead. Despite the fact that it has not yet hit us we are witnessing a very rapid slow-down in the rate of growth within Australia. Only last August, eight months or so ago, the Government forecast in its Budget an estimated growth in Australia's gross domestic product in 1986-87 of 2 1/2 per cent, with some strengthening through the year. In the mini-Budget statement brought down last night by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), both he and the Department of Treasury are now saying that growth in the year we are now completing will be down from the 2 1/2 per cent forecast at the time of the last Budget of the order of 1 1/2 per cent. The Government has also largely revised downwards its forecast of growth for 1987-88. The earlier forecasts, and indeed the forecast as recently as last December, only five months ago, when the Government brought down its report on the Forward Estimates, were done on the basis that growth in 1987-88 would be 3 1/2 per cent. It has now revised that figure downwards to 2 1/2 per cent. Given the outcome for this year, which has been a period of declining growth-something like only 1 1/2 per cent-I think there is every probability that the Government's growth forecast of 2 1/2 per cent for 1987-88, even though it has been revised downwards, will again prove to be too high.

A statement in the Treasurer's mini-Budget last night which I picked up in passing is the extraordinary assumption, despite the fact that he has severely revised down his growth forecast, and despite the fact that he has increased the inflation estimate for next year relative to the earlier estimates, that unemployment throughout 1987-88 will remain at the 1986-87 level. There would appear to be no way in the world that we could have economic parameters of falling growth and rising inflation, and no increase in unemployment. The prospects for unemployment rising in the year ahead, very sadly, are very strong. As I say, these factors are rising at a time of a declining outlook not only for the world but for Australia, and when business investment, private sector investment, has fallen quite severely in real terms during the period of the Hawke Government. Virtually all the surveys carried out by the Australian Bureau of Statistics and other private sector organisations, such as the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, point to a further fall in business investment.

There is no doubt at all that the decline in business investment and the deterioration in the business investment climate are due unequivocally to the policies being pursued by the Hawke Government, and particularly the policies which have led to the highest real relative level of interest rates that we have ever had. Interest rates in this country are now four to five times as high as the level of interest rates in some of our major competitor countries. No other country in the Western world has real interest rates at anything like the level that we have. Indeed, in many non-Western countries, some of which are our very important competitors and trading partners, such as Taiwan and Korea, the overall level of inflation and interest rates is far lower than ours.

All of these factors-declining business investment; a depressed business investment environment; record interest rates; inflation, which the Government is forecasting will remain high next year, and indeed it has increased its previous estimate of next year's inflation level; and a major increase in taxation on business, with the whole raft of anti-business taxes that have been foisted on the private sector in Australia over the last couple of years by the Hawke Government, such as the capital gains tax, the elimination of negative gearing, the introduction of the fringe benefits tax and the new tax arrangements, including in particular the increase of 6 1/2 per cent in the rate of company income tax from 46 to 49 per cent, which is often neglected in comment-are having a major effect on the business climate and on the cash flow situation of companies and therefore on their ability, let alone their incentive, to invest.

I note that the Treasurer this week announced that the tax takes from the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax have already been considerably higher than the Government had initially estimated, and that for the year ahead the level of those tax takes will be very much higher indeed than had earlier been estimated. We are now talking about figures for that raft of new anti-business taxes in excess of $2 billion in the year ahead. As a result of all the factors I have listed, it is no wonder that the private sector is facing the future with very little confidence indeed.

Last night's mini-Budget given by the Treasurer-I do not want to pre-empt later debate on it-would certainly have done nothing at all to allay the concern of the private sector about where this country is going. As several commentators, including the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), myself and others said last night, the $4 billion cut in the prospective Budget deficit is very much a mirrors trick by the Government. It is almost trying to take us on a magic carpet ride. It is trying to make the electorate believe that it is really serious in attempting to get its own economic house in order and to resolve the fundamental problems of the Australian economy. The Government has a $1 billion asset sale as a key plank to getting the Budget arithmetic right, when the experience of not just this Government but also previous governments, including the Fraser Government, has been that the prospect of getting rapid asset sales of the magnitude envisaged at the time of decisions is very difficult indeed. Yet that $1,000m assets sale proposal announced by the Government last night is a key plank of its economic strategy for the year ahead and must at the very best be considered rubbery in the extreme.

I was absolutely staggered to hear Senator Button in response to an interjection from Senator Vigor earlier in the debate say that, despite the fact that the Government is going to sell off the Commonwealth centres in Melbourne and Sydney-centres which house thousands of public servants; I am not sure of the exact figure-the Government will not have to pay any rent for the consequent accommodation of those public servants. That is an unbelievable statement-

TALK.START.PARA: —Trying to do it with mirrors somewhere.

—Yes, trying to do it with mirrors. It is a real pea and thimble trick. I do not think that the Government will fool anyone at all on that because it is simply a nonsensical statement. I would urge the Government to clarify what Senator Button has just said because it is really a quite extraordinary statement. When there is indecision and confusion arising from Government statements of that nature less than 24 hours after the Government has made what it claims is a firm economic statement, no wonder the business investment climate in this country is, at best, confused and is becoming more confused and depressed day by day. But there are other elements of last night's Budget statement which are equally serious for the future of the private sector and the future of business activity. I draw the Senate's attention in particular to the fact that taxation increases of over $400m were announced in last night's mini-Budget, and the Government had the gall to say that those tax increases were in fact expenditure savings. They were no such thing; they were downright tax increases. In particular, I refer to the removal of sales tax and the customs duty exemption that certain Commonwealth Government enterprises had been enjoying. I am not necessarily suggesting that they should have exemption from sales tax and customs duty, but it is an absolute mockery and a deception for the Government to say in a savings statement that those things are savings. They are not savings; they are simply an increase in taxation. Today we have had the release of the April balance of payments figures, which show a blowout again in the balance of payments deficit on current account to a figure just $4m short of a $1 billion deficit-$996m.
—That is well up on the previous figure.

—As Senator Messner says, it is indicative of a rising trend. It is certainly $180m up on the deficit in March, which in turn was up about $40m on the February deficit. So the past three months have seen a rising trend in the balance of payments deficit. It is true that these figures can jump around, and indeed the major adjustments to them are made from month to month. The very least that one can say about today's figures is that they certainly bring no joy to us when we consider the fact that the balance of payments position of this country is the worst it has been since the Depression and, unless we get our balance of payments in order, Australia will face in the period ahead major problems of a nature that we have not known for decades, if ever.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole thrust of government policies should be concerned with correcting that situation. That can be done only if the Government adopts policies which make us more competitive and more productive. Everything that the Government has done in its fiscal policy operations, its monetary policy operations and its wages policy operations over the past two or three years-indeed, since it took office-have worked the other way. I give the Government credit for its work in various areas in trying to restructure the manufacturing industry. The stupid thing-and it is a situation that we have pointed out, particularly to Senator Button, time and time again-is that any sensible industry policies that go towards the desirable restructuring of the Australian private sector, particularly the manufacturing sector, will go for naught if the fiscal, monetary and wages policies that the Government pursues are inconsistent with the sectoral industry policies. That is precisely what is happening in this country. That is precisely the reason that we are not responding to anything like the extent that we should be in terms of the business investment, growth and dynamism we should be enjoying in our economy.

I repeat: We are becoming more uncompetitive because of our inflationary situation, our interest rate policy situation, our wages policy situation and our industrial relations situation, which will deteriorate enormously as a result of the package of legislation brought in by the Government in the past 24 hours and following the Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems. All those things are working in the wrong way. They are not encouraging incentive, enterprise and investment in this country; they are not encouraging greater competition; and they are not encouraging greater productivity. At the end of the day they are the things which will make this country the place we all want it to be-a country of rising living standards and prosperity for all. Until the Government realises that the whole thrust of the policies which Senator Messner has drawn attention to in his motion today is acting contrary to the desired interests of the nation, we will continue to have the difficulties that we are experiencing in full measure today.

I again commend Senator Messner for his motion. I hope that this debate has brought to the Senate a much greater realisation of the enormous problems we will face in this country over the years ahead. Those problems will be resolved only by a fundamental reshaping of the whole tenor of government economic policies in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I rise to wind up the debate and exercise my right of reply. This debate has been characterised by two things: First, the remarkable consensus of views of those who believe that the Government is totally on the wrong track in terms of investment policy in this country; and secondly, the absolute, total lack of any debate at all from the Government benches on this matter. There has been no attempt by any Australian Labor Party member-from the front bench or the back bench-to stand up and defend the policies of the Labor Government. One might believe that that is a quite remarkable event because clearly the Australian Democrats, the Liberal Party and the National Party have expressed views in favour of this motion. Clearly no one on the Labor Party side-not even Senator Cooney, who is usually put in the position of having to pinch hit in these situations-has the guts to get up here and talk about the record of this Government in seeking to improve the investment climate of this country. The answer is simply that the investment policies of this Government are totally indefensible.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of the comments that have been passing our way from Senator Button. Ever since he took over the portfolio of Industry, Technology and Commerce, which was some four years ago now, we have seen him busily trying to do his best to restructure the Australian industrial scene. He has achieved something. Sometimes it has been at the expense of taxpayers, but nevertheless he has done a great deal to bring about some kind of different direction, especially in the automotive industry and the textile, clothing and footwear industry. That has been acknowledged by honourable senators on this side of the chamber for a long time. We have never failed to make that point. The problem is that poor old Senator Button is being undermined by his Treasurer (Mr Keating), his Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the rest of his Cabinet, because he simply does not have control of the economic policies which are being run by this Government. That applies not only to the matter of interest rates and the sorts of competitiveness issues that we have just heard discussed by my colleague Senator Short; it applies also, of course, to the very big question of taxation policy. This Government's tax policy has been an absolute disaster. Notwithstanding that Treasurer Keating has sought to take credit for the changes that have occurred since September 1985, it is quite clear that the Government has had no objective in its ad hoc approach to this matter.

I instance just one issue, one which concerns business-the fringe benefits tax. The fringe benefits tax is not about equity; it is not about simplicity or fairness. The law certainly offends on all those grounds. It is about ensuring that extra cost is put on to business. It will simply have the effect that payroll taxes, such as those imposed by the States, have-that of taking away jobs from ordinary people. It takes away the spirit of competitiveness and the ability of business to compete on world markets because it adds significantly to the costs. That is a fact of life. Competitiveness is a dead issue as far as this Government is concerned, simply because everything it does tends to put more and more costs on to business, making it less and less able to compete effectively on the world scene.

Senator Short mentioned the Committee of Review into the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems, which produced the Hancock report. Of course, that report is now an absolutely central part of this Government's approach to industrial relations policy. We have not had time to assess the full impact of that as yet.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been out for a year and a half.
—Well, it was leaked in the newspapers yesterday.
—I thought you meant the report. I apologise.

—I am talking about the legislation. The point is that obviously it will have a significant impact, especially in terms of the way in which this Government apparently intends to attack section 45d and section 45e of the Trade Practices Act. Clearly the Government is out to take away from the trade practices legislation protection for consumers against the unwarranted attacks of trade union members that drive up the costs of goods and services in the the community. Consequently, we can see that that will be another attack on the competitiveness of Australian industry.

SPEECH.PARA: All this occurs at a time when increasingly we can see the development of the trade war between Japan and America. We can see that there are other pressures from the European Economic Community in terms of its trying to sell goods-perhaps coming close to dumping them-on world markets. We can see that that will end up having very significant effects on Australian industry as the months and years go by. But does the Government concern itself with those questions? No, it just ploughs on, ideologically driven by its own predilections and by its own inner desire to ensure that the trade unions are pacified and, indeed, rewarded in what they deem to be the proper way. Consequently, this legislation is now being brought down to ensure that the trade union movement is lifted out of the civil law arena and put back into the industrial courts where it can make its own rules and where it will not have to answer to the ordinary rules by which Australians in other circumstances are judged. Consequently, all of us will be the poorer. All of those things will have significant effects on the Australian industrial scene and on our ability to compete in world markets.

Last night's statement, which was comprehensively dealt with by Senator Short, laid down some of the rubbery directions which this Government intends to take for the next few months. I say `few months' because it is quite obvious that some kinds of changes may well be initiated by the time the Budget rolls around in August. Do honourable senators think that the Government has in mind an election in July? By doing so then the Government could go to the polls and seek a renewal of its mandate at a time when it can somehow stand in the shadow and glow alongside the May mini-Budget without actually having to face up to a full-blown Budget in which it would have to disclose exactly what its tax policies would be. That is something which is exercising the minds of the journalists. I see that Senator Robert Ray is reading the Herald, and indeed the front page of that paper makes that very point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which column?

—Right in the headlines; I can see it from here. I believe it says: `An Early Poll'. Clearly the Government has these things in mind. The point is that there are ulterior motives behind last night's statement. We are getting used to this pattern of things with the current Treasurer. The Government writes in a rubbery May statement ahead of a Budget. Then it comes along with further rubbery figures in the month of August when the Budget is normally brought down. It stumbles along until Christmas in the hope that nobody will take particular note of the monthly accounts that come out. Senator Walsh and Mr Keating get up in the Parliament and tell us `You cannot rely on one month's figures', whether they be for the balance of payments or the Government's deficit for that particular month. They say `You always have to project ahead'; `Look at what we are doing'; and `our policies are so good'. Then, when we get past Christmas and the figures continue to look bad, the Government says `Well, because the dollar is falling we have to take strong action. Put on the tin hats, grab the rifles and head for the trenches', and we are into the banana republic war. Then the Government makes an announcement on banana republic day, which, of course, was yesterday, that the mini-Budget will stabilise everything. Then the Government admits a few mistakes in the figures. The Government says: `The consumer price index, the inflation rate, was far higher than we expected for reasons that we did not know about at the time we did the Budget.'. It says: `The unemployment figures have not gone as well as we expected because things have not turned out in the way that we thought they would'. Then the Government hangs out for the next three or four months until the Budget comes around. That is the pattern for the way the finances of this country have been managed for the past four years-just tripping along from one disaster to the next while the Government seeks to confuse people by numerous statements, many of them contradictory even within the same week. The Government has no clear policy and no clear idea of the direction in which it wishes to take this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The tax package which was announced in September of 1985 was quite contradictory in so many ways in terms of what it sought to achieve. On the one hand, for instance, the Government said: `We are trying to encourage investment by lowering personal income tax rates, by introducing an imputation system for the company tax system and by getting rid of Division 7 of the Income Tax Assessment Act as it affects private companies'. But, on the other hand, the Government straight away introduced a capital gains tax and a fringe benefits tax alongside it. The fringe benefits tax has just about destroyed the car industry in this country, and the capital gains tax is well on its way to doing that to the rest of private investment in the community. We have in this country people who cannot get rental housing. The rental housing situation in Sydney, for instance, is such that the cost of renting an ordinary three bedroom house has now reached an average level of $267 a week. Rents have climbed by over 30 per cent in the last 18 months and are still going up. Why? It is because people are not investing in low cost housing because of the capital gains tax and the negative gearing taxation principles that have been introduced by this Government. All these things are totally antipathetic to investment. The statistics that come out each quarter demonstrate quite clearly the investment intentions, not only of those who want to invest in the stock market or in other parts of the Australian community but also particularly industry. They are just not doing so.

Senator Short told us about interest rates. That is the area of great disaster of this Government. After four years of Labor Government we now have the highest interest rates of all time. There is nothing more destructive of investment than interest rates being as high as they are. Interest rates are running at a level something like three or four times greater than the average for Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. Is it any wonder that people do not want to invest in this country for any purposes other than the quick buck? All they are seeking to do is put their money in for a short time, make a quick profit and get the money out again. Consequently, this is the reason we are seeing so much money flow in to cover our balance of payments deficit at the moment. But there is no intention of keeping this money in this country to develop it in the long run. Those points were clearly made by speakers on this side in this debate.

It is just as well that we are getting dollars into this country one way or another. How else would we possibly be able to cover the enormous deficit that this country has been building up under this Government. The total debt of $100,000m has tripled from around $30,000m when Labor came into power in 1983. We have $100,000m worth of debt. If we are to start to reduce that debt, we have to get long term equity investment into this country in order to promote more productive and competitive export-oriented industries. We need to get out and sell on the world markets, get real money flowing into this country and reduce that enormous debt that this Government has allowed to occur.

The situation is quite desperate. Investment is at a very low level. All indications from surveys being undertaken by the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the Westpac organisation indicate that the situation is not getting better-it is tending to get worse. Investment will remain very low while governments tend to impose higher and higher costs on this community through taxes. We saw more evidence of that in the statement last night where another $400m was imposed upon statutory authorities such as Telecom Australia, Australia Post and the airlines. Of course, these charges will flow through into the ordinary costs to the consumer and add to the day-to-day costs of all of us.

The same thing has happened with respect to Medicare. Private Medicare costs will go up again as a direct result of last night's mini-Budget, having only just gone up in the last three or four months. All these things will impose heavier costs on the ordinary consumer who, of course, will press for higher increases in wages. This will lead to more and more pressure on business. Eventually it will lead to less incentive for investment, which is the very source of our future job creation opportunities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stagflation.

—Exactly, Senator Vigor. Investment is not about the present: It is about the future; it is about creating opportunities for jobs; and it is the only way we can create new jobs. This Government has been bumbling along since it came to office in March 1983. It has not reduced the overall rate of unemployment very significantly at all. Indeed, the average time for which a person is now unemployed has risen from around 26 weeks a year to nearly 46 weeks a year. Amongst youth that rate is even higher. About a quarter of our youth are now unemployed almost permanently. That is a disgrace.

SPEECH.PARA: The only way we will cure those problems is by making sure that industry has incentive to invest and thereby create more jobs in the community. Investment is needed to create more industrial opportunities and to develop, not only in the manufacturing sector but also in the service and tertiary areas, export-oriented industries. Investment should not only be based on the gee-whiz technology which many of us might be intrigued by. It should also be oriented very much towards the introduction of new skills which are being developed in our educational institutions which are very well placed to ensure that the twenty-first century will be rewarding not only for us but for the next generation and the children who will come thereafter.

This motion is most important. It draws attention to the fundamental problems of the Australian economy and the fundamental weakness of this Government in addressing those problems. We in the Liberal Party believe that this Government should get off its behind and start to wind back some of the stupid measures that it has introduced in the last three years, particularly such things as the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax which we, upon coming to government, immediately will repeal. We also believe that the Government should be adopting a new approach to the development of a new industrial structure and immediately should seek to get interest rates down as quickly as possible in order to attract new investment into Australian industry.

The policies that we have seen implemented in the last few years have been disastrous for Australian industry and job creation. We need a new deal from this Government. As it looks as though we will not get that, our only hope is the election which will come perhaps sooner than later, but presumably by the end of the year. With a new government in power we will have a totally new approach to industrial development. Industrial development and investment are about job creation and providing opportunities for young people in our community. This is something to which this Senate right now should vote to commit itself.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Missen had moved by way of amendment:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I express my thanks to Senator Kilgariff, who drew my attention to the fact that I am speaking in continuation on the Family Law Amendment Bill 1985 which was introduced by Senator Durack. There has been much debate on this Bill in this chamber. This legislation is an attempt to translate moral obligation into statutory expression, and in some circumstances this is difficult to do. If one reads through the debate so far, it becomes apparent that there is great difficulty at times in getting spouses who are separated to contribute properly to their children for whom they have a responsibility. It appears from the debate that the major consideration is that children should be looked after. It is not their fault when spouses separate.

SPEECH.PARA: What can be done effectively is very much a moot point. The legislation first introduced by Senator Durack was in several parts. As things have progressed the honourable senator has seen the difficulties that could arise and the legislation has been amended. But in the end the question is one of what moral obligations there are upon spouses and how well they adhere to them. It is really a question of the general moral quality of people in the community rather than that of a law that can at times effectively render this tragedy less tragic. I congratulate Senator Durack on having raised time and again the question of how to get people to contribute to the support of their children. The mechanism, of course, is a different matter and his attempt on this occasion, albeit a valiant one, has not been successful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to confirm the Government's opposition to the Family Law Amendment Bill, a measure which can be seen in one sense to be too late and in another to be very premature. It is too late in the sense that Senator Durack was Attorney-General for the Commonwealth of Australia for quite some time and did not see fit to address the matter during that period. In another sense, however, it is well known to the Opposition and to the Australian Democrats that the Government, on 22 December last year, announced a wide ranging review of the whole system of child maintenance. In fact, our proposal, as announced at the time by the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, covers all aspects of the problems involved in the system.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government recognised for the first time the need to strike a fairer balance between public and private forms of support to alleviate the poverty faced by many children and sole parent families. We realised that the interests of the taxpayer were important, and we also realised the enormity of the problem. Over 250,000 people are at present on supporting parents benefits, at an annual cost of over $1.5 billion. So to government it is not a minor problem; it is a major one. The Labor Government has responded to that with a comprehensive plan for reform.

The plan proposed by the Minister does not go directly to the court process. It does not involve lawyers at every instance, and that to me is one of its major benefits. As the Senate will know, and as the Australian population should know by now, the Government proposes to tackle this problem by direct access to the salaries and the pay slips of non-custodial parents, who have moral, if not financial, obligations in this matter. Even though this proposal, when it was first put forward, met with opposition from supposedly independent groups such as the law profession, when we take account of the fact that the Minister was able to make some compromises, we see that we can now proceed to a system that both accommodates the legal process and, in the first instance, eradicates it. In the first instance, what the Government is attempting to do and anticipates it can do is to recover at least 80 per cent of maintenance payments due to custodial parents through this access to pay slips and pay cheques. This procedure, if put into operation, would work with the least possible cost to the people involved. There would, of course, be a consequent decrease in the income of the lawyers involved in the system; but that is not necessarily a bad thing for the social system we are trying to pursue in this country.

As I said, the Government announced this proposal on 22 December last year, and promised to introduce legislation some time this year to implement it. That legislation is not yet available, but we are only five months into 1987 and it is still the Government's intention to introduce it. We have been asked today, therefore, to debate one simplistic, minor response-a response which does not adequately address all of the problems involved in the area and which takes the wrong track towards solving those problems. For that reason, we should reject the Bill at this stage and wait for the Government's comprehensive response.

It has also been said in previous debates that this whole question should be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for inquiry and report. As Chairman of that Committee, I make it clear that we have not discussed this matter at committee level. But yesterday the Senate forced upon us an inquiry into the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Bill 1987, and that will give us enough work for the next couple of months. We also have in process another inquiry into aspects of the taxation system, which will carry the work of the Committee towards the end of this year. Given that it is an election year and that we have in train two inquiries-one official, and one being pursued by Committee members en bloc-I feel it would be totally unfair for anyone to pursue the question of referring this Bill to the Committee.

I reiterate the point that I made at the start of my remarks: This Bill represents a response to one particular aspect of a whole series of complex problems involved with child maintenance, child custody, access, and the rights and obligations of custodial and non-custodial parents. To approach that in the way attempted in this Bill, with such provisions as gaol terms for defaulters on maintenance payments-although I gather the Opposition now intends to delete that provision from the legislation-would be to give an isolated response to a very complex problem. For the sake of the good working of this Parliament, I think we should at least defer this legislation or reject it for the moment. If the Opposition needs to pursue these sorts of amendments, they can do so in response to the Government's package.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had a long debate on this Bill, and a number of attempts have been made to bring it to a conclusion. In that time, of course, much water has run under the bridge. In one sense, I suppose I should be pleased that the initiative of introducing the Bill seems to have contributed to the Government's actions on this matter and spurred it along. In fact, somebody suggested that I was a burr under the saddle. I am not sure whether I was pleased with that suggestion. Nevertheless, when I introduced the Bill on 5 December 1985, nothing effective seemed to be being done by the Government in relation to this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it was Senator Bolkus who chided me for doing nothing in this matter until December 1985, despite the opportunities that I allegedly had as Attorney-General. The fact is that the very dramatic increase in the liability for supporting parents' benefits tended to become apparent only towards the end of the term of the Fraser Government. Certainly, it was gathering pace for some years after the benefits were introduced, and particularly when the Family Law Act started to be widely applied and the offending provisions of that Act, which I have identified in the Bill, were gathering momentum. Certainly, a general review of the Family Law Act was undertaken at that time by the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. That Committee reported in, I think, 1980, as a result of which quite detailed legislation was being prepared, and the Committee's recommendations were being processed. That Committee suggested that changes should be made in this area and also in the area of matrimonial property. The latter question was ultimately referred to the Law Reform Commission, which is still considering the matter after about four years.

So it is not an area where sudden decisions are or should be made, but certainly after Senator Chaney became Minister for Social Security a lot of work was done by his Department and my Department in an endeavour to achieve some change. Indeed, Senator Chaney, as the then Minister for Social Security, took a very positive step in this direction by insisting on the observance of the Social Security Act in that people who were seeking supporting parents pensions were required to pursue their legal remedies against the non-custodial parent, of course which had been abandoned by the Whitlam Government many years earlier and which unfortunately was not changed until Senator Chaney became the Minister. In the later period of our term of office we were seeking ways and means of changing these provisions of the Family Law Act. We had hoped to have a package, together with adequate maintenance collection arrangements, but we lost office. The new Government, with Senator Gareth Evans as Attorney-General, followed that up by establishing a departmental committee to look at this question of how an adequate maintenance collection agency could be set up. The report of that departmental committee was published in 1984. That gave the Government a blueprint for an adequate maintenance collection agency, and it was my view that we would have amendments to the Family Law Act together with the establishment of such an agency. Again nothing was heard from the Government on this matter.

That is why I decided that I would have this private member's Bill drafted and introduce it, which I did in December 1985. At about the time it was introduced-I am not saying that it was because it was introduced-the Government set up another consulting body to look at the question, but that was within the Department of Social Security. Ultimately the report `Child support: A discussion paper on child maintenance' was written by Dr Meredith Edwards, and it became available towards the end of last year. In my second reading speech on this Bill I made it perfectly clear that I did not regard amendments to the Family Law Act as being sufficient to tackle the problem. I have always said that. The comment in this debate misses the point because I have never suggested that these amendments will solve the problem. Clearly, they need to be associated with adequate means of enforcing maintenance.

Some of the problems with establishing an agency to enforce maintenance, whatever form it may take, are within the existing provisions of the Family Law Act. They do not make it clear enough that both parents are responsible for the maintenance of children and that priorities should be observed. We cannot have both parents sloughing off those responsibilities on to the taxpayer. Those problems are inherent in the Family Law Act. The Government, through Mr Howe, responded to the paper on child support and the scheme that was advanced by Dr Meredith Edwards on 24 March this year. He set out the Government's response to the discussion paper which was released for public comment in October 1986. He set out the stages in which the Government will proceed in this area, after having indicated its general support for the scheme for the enforcement of maintenance which was advanced by Dr Edwards. On 24 March Mr Howe said:

Stage 1 in 1987 will introduce legislation to establish the Child Support Agency to collect child maintenance, and to amend the Family Law Act to assert the priority of child maintenance, to make sure that court orders put the financial position of children ahead of everything except the essential commitments of the parents, and to remove reference to social security eligibility to make clear that child support should not be treated as a `top-up' to social security pensions and benefits. The current system has for too long awarded inadequate levels of child support. The social security system has been burdened with this responsibility.

Then he went on about the other stages that are not relevant to this debate. There is the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, telling us that in 1987-we have not seen anything of the legislation yet-the Government would make amendments to the Family Law Act to achieve the very purposes for which I introduced this Bill-to assert the priority of child maintenance, to make sure that court orders put the financial position of children ahead of other commitments and to remove reference to social security eligibility. They are the three things for which this Bill provides.

It is very interesting to consider the bona fides of the Government in this matter. The history of this Bill, as I said, is that I introduced it in December 1985 and it was brought on for debate early in 1986. At that time Senator Evans, on behalf of the Government, announced that the Government was opposed to the Bill. He said that it was opposed to the principles that Mr Howe now says he will insert into the Family Law Act. Mr Howe's amendments, I imagine, may be worded differently from this Bill. I would be very happy to negotiate about the wording of the Bill. As a private member I do not have the facilities available for drafting what is fairly technical and difficult legislation. The Government has much better resources. I would be very happy to negotiate in relation to the wording of the legislation, but that is classically what would happen in the Committee debate. The proper course to adopt, I would have thought, is for the Government to support the second reading of the Bill and then for us to talk turkey about the detailed provisions in it.

The incredible thing is that Senator Evans, on behalf of the Government, announced over a year ago that the Government would be opposing the Bill; yet it has always been clear that before we can have an adequate and effective system of child maintenance in this country we have to amend the Family Law Act. Mr Howe, speaking on behalf of the Government, now says that that is what it will do. Stage 1 of its program, which has taken it more than four years to develop, will do the very things I have sought to do with this legislation. Yet the Government will now vote against those proposals. Is this because it is in a fit of pique that I brought in legislation and have beaten it well and truly to the draw? It looks like I have introduced my Bill two years before the Government will bring in its legislation. I suppose it believes that it can do everything better than everybody else. I do not know how Mr Howe will explain why his colleagues in the Senate voted against a Bill to do the very things that his Bill, when we see it, will do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps they are not serious about the problem.

—They really are not serious about it. Senator Reid is quite right. The history of the Government's attitude to this matter is very revealing. One other historical fact ought to be on the record. When we went out of office I had already introduced into the Senate a fairly extensive Bill to amend the Family Law Act to give effect to a number of the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. At that stage we had not finalised the matter in relation to child maintenance and the sharing of property which I mentioned. However, when the legislation was finally brought in, it disappeared with the 1983 election. Senator Evans brought it back later in 1983. In the Senate debate on that legislation I moved an amendment along the lines of this present Bill to remove the requirement of courts to look at the eligibility for social security benefits. Labor senators-to a man and a woman-voted against that amendment. Having received the report of its own departmental committee about how to set up a child maintenance agency, the Government did nothing about it for another 18 months. Finally it got busy at the end of 1985 and appointed Dr Meredith Edwards to look at the matter again. Dr Edwards reported in October 1986. Mr Howe said that the Government would implement that report in March 1987, but we still have not had any action from it. It is very doubtful whether the Government really wants or ever intends to do anything effective about this liability and responsibility of parents adequately to maintain their children.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of my great concern about this matter I introduced this Bill. At the time I acknowledged that it was not possible for me as a private member to set up such an adequate method of child maintenance enforcement. I included in the Bill a provision which would have facilitated the sanction of imprisonment if people did not pay their maintenance orders. The non-payment of maintenance orders is only one of the problems; the inadequacy or absence of orders are also problems. There is no adequate mechanism under the Family Law Act to make people pay. The section of the Family Law Act which prevents imprisonment for non-payment of maintenance has greatly contributed to the problem. It is not as though many people would be put in gaol or would ever stay there very long. When I practised in this field many years ago I found that the threat of imprisonment and warrants for arrest were usually quite enough to make people pay. The Family Law Act took that sanction away. The only possible proposal I could make as a private member was to restore that power to the courts because it is a power which they would exercise in a very circumspect way.

In this debate we have had the spectre of people being thrown into gaol because they cannot afford to pay maintenance. That is quite absurd. Anybody who has had practice in this field will know that it is very difficult indeed to persuade judges to put people into gaol in these circumstances. They would exercise that power only in the case of a most recalcitrant person. The judges would give people time to pay and if the court could be persuaded that these people did not have the means to pay of course they would not be gaoled. That is totally misguided talk and is based on ignorance of how the legal system works.

Nevertheless, because of all this furore that was created by a lot of people-not just in this chamber but also outside in comments I received on the Bill-coupled with the fact that at last the Government seemed to be moving on a blueprint for an adequate system of child maintenance in the shape of the Meredith report, I thought that I would remove that provision from the Bill. If this Bill is given a second reading, which seems unlikely, I shall move to delete the clauses about imprisonment or the amendments to the Family Law Act which, themselves, prevent the exercise of that sanction. The fact that the Bill contains these clauses should not be a reason for voting against it. I cannot fathom why the Government still persists in opposing the Bill, especially in light of the statement by the Minister for Social Security that it is now the Government's policy to do exactly the same things that this Bill seeks to do. I hope that enough honourable senators will realise that what I am now proposing is more or less the same, except in detail, as Mr Howe has proposed and that the Bill should be given a second reading.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is: That the amendment be agreed to.
—I take a point of order. This amendment was moved by Senator Missen, who is now no longer with us. I do not know whether that makes any difference; perhaps it does not-
—As you still have nine minutes left in which to speak, perhaps it would be better if you continued your speech, rather than taking a point of order.

—I apologise for not having dealt with this matter when I was speaking before. Senator Missen suggested that the debate on this Bill be deferred to enable consideration of a reference to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs.
—That is redundant.

—It does seem to be redundant; we seem to have gone past the point where that would be possible because the debate will be concluded as soon as I sit down. In any event, I would be opposed to that amendment because it seems to be quite unnecessary. The issues are simple and clear enough and do not need a Committee debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

(2) Page 2, clause 3, proposed new subsection 75 (4), lines 19 to 20, leave out ``In taking into account a matter referred to in paragraph (2) (e) or (m), the'', insert ``The''.

It was not a `death penalty' clause, as some honourable senators seemed to think. It simply gave the Court power to imprison if the person failed to pay maintenance. That is what section 107 of the principal Act says and I propose to repeal it.
