DEBATE.TITLE: NURSING HOMES AND HOSTELS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill will amend the National Health Act 1953, the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974 and the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954. The purpose of this Bill is to enable the introduction of new recurrent funding arrangements for nursing homes, quality of care standards in nursing homes and improved arrangements for granting capital assistance to non-profit organisations. These measures will improve the quality of care and quality of life provided for aged people and achieve greater efficiency in government funding of nursing homes.

Over the last decade, and over the past five years in particular, major criticisms have been made of many aspects of policy and program management in the aged care area, and in particular residential care. There have been two major reports to Parliament by Committees comprising representatives of both sides of politics. One was by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure (the McLeay Report) and the other was by the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes (the Giles Report). There has also been a report by the Auditor-General on an Efficiency Audit of the Commonwealth Administration of Nursing Home Programs. All these made strong comments about the inappropriate mix of services between and within institutional accommodation and home and community care, the unplanned and unco-ordinated approach to residential care provision, the need for significantly tightened control on the growth of nursing homes, and the need to introduce funding arrangements which provide incentives to operators to be efficient and reduce inequities between States. The often inadequate quality of resident care, the need for more consistent inspection and better quality control arrangements and the crucial roles of assessment and rehabilitation were also highlighted in these reports.

Against this background, in its February 1983 pre-election policy statement, the Australian Labor Party committed itself to a change in the approach to funding of nursing homes, foreshadowing the introduction of a program grants approach.

The Review of Nursing Homes and Hostels, which was tabled by the then Minister for Community Services, Senator Don Grimes, in the Senate on 14 April 1986, brought together the conclusions and recommendations of these previous reports and outlined a blueprint for a staged program of reform of residential care services for aged people.

As the first stage of the reform program, the Government made a significant commitment, in the 1986-87 Budget, to begin the process of redistributing resources for the care of aged people away from nursing homes to alternative less-institutionalised forms of residential care and to community care services. This will involve, as a package, additional expenditure of approximately $24m in 1986-87, $80m in 1987-88 and $150m in 1988-89.

Implementation of that first stage is now well under way. The main elements include new needs-based planning arrangements linked to capital funding arrangements covering both nursing homes and hostels, with increasing emphasis on the number of hostel places through an expanded capital program; increased resources for home and community care; the development of a Special Services Program to cater for the special needs of frail aged people which cannot satisfactorily be met through standard levels of funding; and the development of co-ordinated assessment processes, including the staged establishment and expansion of assessment teams, to assist aged people and their families to plan the most appropriate care to meet their particular needs.

The Government also foreshadowed in the 1986-87 Budget the introduction of new recurrent funding arrangements for nursing homes and arrangements to develop quality of care and life standards in nursing homes. On 31 March 1987, the Minister for Community Services announced the second stage of the Government's program of reform which, with the passage of this Bill, will see the foreshadowed arrangements turned into reality.

In developing the proposals to be given effect by this Bill, the Government has acknowledged that the achievement of improved care services for the aged depends on the co-operation and support of the community, the industry and other groups. For this reason, the Commonwealth has undertaken extensive consultations concerning the details of proposed changes with State Governments, the nursing homes and hostels industry, consumer and other welfare groups, and professional and staff organisations.

I shall now discuss the two major elements of reform, commencing with the new nursing home recurrent funding arrangements. Briefly, the new nursing home funding arrangements which this Bill will bring into effect involve the phased introduction, from 1 July 1987, of standard daily resident fees and standard Commonwealth benefits to replace the current cost-reimbursement arrangements operating for non-Government nursing homes for aged people. These new funding arrangements will constitute a uniform national system. Special conditions will not be granted to one State which are not available to others.

These new arrangements will apply to some 1250 non-Government homes caring for some 60,000 aged residents across Australia-those being private participating homes funded under the National Health Act 1953 (including both for-profit and not-for-profit homes) and not-for-profit homes funded under the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974. While ostensibly these groups of homes are funded under two different types of funding arrangements, both are essentially funded on a cost-reimbursement basis.

Under the new arrangements the Commonwealth will, in effect, fund a specified level of service of nursing home care on behalf of residents at a predetermined price. It will no longer reimburse proprietors for whatever level of costs has been incurred. In other words, emphasis will be placed on outcomes rather than inputs. This represents a vast improvement over the current arrangements which are unsatisfactory for a number of reasons.

First, residents of participating nursing homes can be faced with unexpected fee increases every few months. Many are required to pay amounts significantly above the minimum contribution, even though the standard of care may be no better than that provided in other nursing homes where the residents pay only the minimum contribution.
Second, cost savings by efficient nursing home proprietors do not produce increased profits and there is therefore no incentive to operate efficiently.

Third, the industry is also subject to an excessive degree of regulation and unwarranted operational rigidities. In order to maintain their financial viability, proprietors need to apply for a fee increase whenever their costs vary and provide detailed documentation in support of their applications.

Fourth, the quantum of Commonwealth nursing home benefits is geared to the levels of expenditure incurred by nursing homes. Because costs vary widely between homes and States, this system has led to substantial per capita inequities in benefits paid from one State to another. For example, the maximum benefit paid to ordinary care residents in participating nursing homes varies from $54.60 a day in Victoria to $35.25 a day in Queensland.

Fifth, the plethora of different funding, and funding control mechanisms, and their seeming inability to contain the mushrooming cost of nursing home accommodation, have resulted in totally unacceptable and unjustified cost escalations per bed day. In the period 1973-85, for example, the increase in Commonwealth per bed day expenditure was of the order of 606 per cent, compared with a 233 per cent increase in the consumer price index and a 308 per cent movement in average weekly earnings. The cost of nursing home care has clearly risen out of all proportion to other indicators and it is becoming increasingly difficult to prevent unscrupulous proprietors from exploiting the system to increase profits at the expense of residents and taxpayers.

The unintended and undesirable consequences of the present funding system are well illustrated by the findings of an analysis done by the Department of Community Services of nursing home operating costs incurred during the 1984-85 financial year. The study concentrated particularly on infrastructure costs-that is, all costs other than those incurred on nursing and personal care staff. This analysis confirmed that there is extraordinary diversity in the nature and quantum of funding approved by the Department around Australia for the provision of infrastructure services-State average infrastructure costs vary by 27 per cent and are 18 per cent higher in Victorian homes than the next highest State, South Australia. The analysis also showed no statistically significant relationships between infrastructure costs and factors which might explain these substantial variations in costs (such as dependency levels, bed capacity, ward size, age of home. Whether the home was free-standing or part of a complex).
Even within States, there are large inexplicable cost variations between individual homes.

The inescapable conclusion drawn from this analysis is that the substantial variations in infrastructure costs both within and between States are unjustified and that there is little basis for having different levels of infrastructure funding from home to home or State to State.

This is not to imply blame on individuals, particular sectors or particular States. Clearly it is the funding system itself that is wrong and requires change. Where the funding arrangement leads to the incurring of unwarranted additional costs, it is the taxpayer and the consumer, in the main, who `pay the piper'. In this particular case, the consumers are frail, elderly people, approximately 80 per cent of whom are in receipt of part or full pensions.

The Government cannot ignore that if there is unnecessarily high expenditure on nursing homes for the very small proportion of aged people in nursing homes, this will mean diminished funding available for less intensive accommodation or community-based services for the remainder of the aged population. Clearly, the Government would be negligent if it continued to let costs `mushroom' in the nursing homes area and thwart its objectives of providing aged people with a wider range of care choices to match more closely their individual needs.

The new funding arrangements for nursing homes being introduced in this Bill are designed specifically to redress the many problems faced under present arrangements and to achieve greater equity between States and individual nursing homes in the Commonwealth funding of aged care. They will also simplify the administration of the program and eliminate the detailed intrusion by the Commonwealth into everyday decisions of care providers about how to spend their infrastructure resources. This will give providers greater flexibility and incentives to increase efficiency, provided that appropriate care and lifestyle outcomes are achieved for residents. Finally, the new arrangements will provide much-needed control over the growth of Commonwealth nursing home expenditure.

As I mentioned earlier, the concept of the new funding arrangements is a simple one of introducing, over five annual steps from 1 July 1987 to 1 July 1991, a system of standard fees and benefits for nursing homes catering exclusively or predominantly for aged people. It is proposed that from 1 July 1987, all nursing home fees will be split into two components-one for all direct nursing and personal care costs, and the other for infrastructure costs (e.g. transport, laundry, food etc) and return on investment. This latter composite infrastructure component is known as the standard aggregated module or SAM and represents about 45 per cent of total average nursing home costs.

At this stage, the standard aggregated module will be the only component in respect of which all nursing homes for the aged will begin a gradual transition to a uniform national funding level from 1 July 1987. Until new national uniform staffing standards are agreed with State Governments and, indeed, for some time after they are introduced, current approved nursing and personal care staffing levels will continue to be reflected in fees on a cost-reimbursement basis.

The level of SAM is set in the Bill at $27.65 per occupied bed day, for 1987-88. This figure represents the average infrastructure cost for all participating homes for 1984-85 indexed by a weighted average of actual and projected movements in AWE and CPI to give a figure for 1987-88. The Bill also provides for the Minister to either gazette a higher amount or to gazette a formula in accordance with which a higher amount would be ascertained. The formula will provide that in 1988-89 and in subsequent years, the SAM will be indexed by a weighted average of the annual expected movements in the AWE and CPI indices. The index will also take into account the difference between the expected movements in these indices used to determine the previous year's SAM, and the actual movements. The Gazette notice would be subject to Parliamentary disallowance.
In response to requests from industry organisations, the Government has agreed to regular reviews of the appropriateness of the level of SAM, based on surveys of industry costs.

I should stress, however, that the level of SAM which has been set for 1987-88 is fixed and non-negotiable. It has been reached after extensive analysis by the Department of Community Services of nursing home costings data and represents a level which will result in an equitable redistribution of current levels of income within the participating sector. It will also provide a greater level of income than the average infrastructure cost for homes in the deficit financed sector and put them on the same footing as participating homes.

I should stress again that the new funding arrangements represent a transition to a uniform system. Nursing homes with infrastructure costs which are presently either above or below the SAM, will have that component of their fees adjusted in five annual steps to bring them into line with the SAM on a national basis. The 65 per cent of non-government homes which have infrastructure costs below the SAM will receive additional funding over the transition period to assist in improving their quality of care.

The 35 per cent of nursing homes which have a level of infrastructure costs above the SAM will need to bring their outlays on such items more into line with costs in the majority of homes. However, the phasing of this transition over five annual steps will allow such adjustment to be undertaken gradually to ensure that disruption to the industry and to nursing home residents is kept to an absolute minimum.

For higher cost homes whose residents may prefer, and are prepared to pay for, higher quality and more expensive services, the Government has given in-principle support for the concept of fee exemption. This would involve exempting entire nursing homes or some beds in nursing homes from the standard fee arrangements and allow those particular homes to charge at levels higher than the standard fee arrangements. The Commonwealth benefit for these beds would be reduced in proportion to the extent to which the fee charged exceeded the regulated fee. In return for greater operating freedom under the exemption arrangements, the Government will be looking for an increased acceptance of responsibility by the proprietors of such homes. To this end, the exemption arrangements are likely to involve careful assessment of the suitability of proprietors, including an assessment of the quality of care and quality of life that a home has afforded to residents under the standard fee arrangements. The exemption concept will be developed for introduction as soon as is practicable.

The Bill contains formulae for calculating the standard ordinary care fee for each nursing home, and a description of the elements which make up the formulae, including nursing and personal care costs and SAM. The Bill provides for the various elements of the formulae to be determined in accordance with gazetted legislative principles, which are subject to Parliament disallowance.

The Bill also requires the standard ordinary care fee for a nursing home to be taken into account when setting a scale of fees which may be changed by a nursing home. Other matters which will be taken into account in setting a scale of fees will be covered in the principles, and it is envisaged that these matters will include arrangements for ensuring accurate cost reimbursement of nursing and personal care staff costs and for phasing out the charging of different scales of fees within the one nursing home. The current system of temporary fee loadings will continue.

Existing appeal rights in relation to the determination of a scale of fees based on all 1986-87 costs will be preserved and in future proprietors will continue to be able to request a review of decisions relating to the inclusion of nursing and personal care staffing costs within their scale of fees. Such review requests will be required to be made within 42 days of receipt of advice of a decision in relation to a fee application.

The new funding arrangements for nursing homes will provide a greater degree of protection for financially disadvantaged people and will ensure that the group has better access to nursing home care than under existing arrangements. At present, some 80% of residents in all nursing homes are required to pay no more than the minimum resident contribution of 87.5 per cent of the basic pension and rental assistance. This minimum resident contribution will remain at this rate in all nursing homes. The Bill also provides for the Commonwealth to continue to meet the full difference between the approved fees for former deficit-funded nursing homes and the fixed resident contribution relating to those homes which is 87.5 per cent of the basic pension and rental assistance. The residents of other nursing homes pay additional fees of up to $65 per day over and above the minimum resident contribution. By the end of the transition period, the new arrangements will have greatly reduced, for many residents of these homes, the amount to be paid over the minimum resident contribution and will have provided better protection against operating cost increases.

Under current arrangements the maximum level of the nursing home benefit is adjusted each November. However, because adjustments to SAM are to be made from 1 July each year, the Commonwealth proposes also to adjust the level of the maximum Commonwealth benefit from the date, commencing this year.

The Bill also provides for special administrative arrangements to be introduced which will maintain equity between the way existing and new nursing homes are treated. Under these arrangements, the infrastructure fee component for new nursing homes which received an approval-in-principle before 1 April 1987 and which commence operation between 1 July 1987 and 1 July 1991 will be set under the same transition arrangements to SAM as existing homes. For new homes resulting from approvals-in-principle granted on or after 1 April 1987, the infrastructure fee component for the home or beds will be the SAM.

The Bill provides for similar transition provisions in relation to proprietors who rebuild sub-standard nursing homes to improve the living environment and quality of life of residents. This provision applies where approval to rebuild is either granted or sought before 1 July 1987.

Another measure is the inclusion in the Bill of a simple mechanism under the National Health Act 1953 for approving the demolition of premises occupied by a nursing home and the reconstruction of those premises on the same site. The Government intends also to introduce a similar mechanism for approving the relocation of existing nursing home beds as soon as possible. I should make it clear, however, that decisions in relation to relocation proposals will continue to involve an assessment of the appropriateness of the proposal in terms of planning and other objectives.

The Bill also provides that until 1 July 1988, `approved services' in the former deficit-funded sector provided to persons who are not nursing home residents (i.e. hostel and community residents) will continue to be funded as at present on a cost reimbursement basis. From 1 July 1988, funding for these services will be transferred to the Special Services Program which Senator Grimes announced in the 1986-87 Budget and will provide on a grant basis. This does not mean that nursing home residents will cease to receive therapeutic and rehabilitation services-these types of services will be in the future, and indeed have been for many residents in participating nursing homes in the past, largely provided as part of normal nursing home care. Nursing home residents with extraordinary disabilities may also be entitled to supplementary services under the Special Services Program to meet particularly intensive service needs unable to be met under standard funding arrangements.

As I mentioned previously, the new nursing home funding arrangements only apply to nursing homes catering principally for aged people. This Bill provides for the new arrangements to be funded only under the National Health Act 1953, and transfers to that Act the approvals of all nursing homes for aged people approved under the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974. In line with this transfer of all homes for the aged to the National Health Act 1953, the Bill contains transitional provisions to preserve the general rights and entitlements of transferred homes.

The Bill also amends the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974, so that it only applies to nursing homes where the majority of residents are disabled people who are less than 70 years of age. This amendment is reflected in a change to the long title of the Act.

The existing funding arrangements for the 69 nursing homes throughout Australia which cater principally for the non-aged disabled are to be preserved, pending development of a new system for funding these homes consistent with the principles and objectives of the Disability Services Act 1986. The Bill provides for the 69 non-aged homes to be identified in gazette notices published under the National Health Act 1953 and the amending Act.

The Bill also enables a certificate of approval-in-principle for new or additional nursing home beds for non-aged disabled people to be granted under either the National Health Act 1953 or the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974. New bed numbers for these people will not be subject to the statutory growth control arrangements which apply to nursing home beds for the aged, but will be announced by the Minister each year in the Budget context.

I turn now to the other component of the new funding arrangements: nursing and personal care costs, and to the issue of standards of life and care in nursing homes. The Minister of Community Services intends, as soon as possible, to introduce uniform national staffing standards based on a resident classification system which reflects different levels of intensity of service need. However, before these uniform national staffing standards are finalised, there will be extensive consultation with service providers, staff and professional bodies and consumer bodies.

The new uniform staffing arrangements will incorporate measures to ensure that the new standards will not apply for two years in respect of persons who are resident at the time of introduction. For these residents, the pre-existing approved nursing and personal care staffing levels will continue to apply for that two year transitional period.

A significant concession made by the Government in the course of consultations with the industry in relation to the new arrangements, has been the inclusion of payroll tax and workers' compensation insurance costs for all staff in the cost-reimbursed nursing and personal care component of the fee.

The Government acknowledges, however, that with the management flexibility introduced under standard grant arrangements, there are increased incentives to cut corners to make profits at the expense of standards of care and the quality of life of nursing home residents. It also acknowledges the criticisms of Parliamentary Reports which have identified serious deficiencies in the quality of care provided in certain nursing homes. To tackle these concerns, the Government is approaching the problem on two fronts.

The Government's first task has been to clarify the standards of care to be required in nursing homes. The Commonwealth, in consultation with the States, has now developed new outcome standards relating to quality of care and quality of life for residents in nursing homes and has prepared a document which incorporates extensive contributions from service providers, unions and professional groups, consumer bodies and many others.

The amendments included in this Bill will allow the gazettal of these standards for nursing home care under the National Health Act 1953 as the basis against which the care provided in individual nursing homes can be measured.

In implementing the new standards, the Government intends to adopt an educative and consultative role. An amount of $600,000 will be provided over 3 years for training packages aimed at directors of nursing homes and hostel supervisors. Where sub-standard care is occurring, Departmental staff will work with nursing homes to ensure that the welfare of residents is protected, and to improve overall standards as quickly as possible.

The second task is to introduce effective measures to ensure that the minority of nursing homes which have a consistent record of providing poor quality care and which have shown a disinclination to comply with Commonwealth efforts to improve care standards do not continue to do so. The principal existing sanction currently available to the Commonwealth is to withdraw approval of the nursing home but applying this is difficult because of the immediate need to find alternative care for a large group of frail aged residents if a home is closed.

As the current provisions for dealing with cases of sub-standard care have not proven to be flexible enough, the Bill includes two additional powers which the Commonwealth can use to protect the interests of frail elderly residents, where the gazetted standards of care are not complied with.

First, the Bill will enable the Minister to ensure that Commonwealth funding is not provided in respect of any new residents admitted to the nursing home which refuses to comply with standards. The withholding of Commonwealth funding in these circumstances is intended to act as a disincentive for proprietors to admit new residents, with the result that, at the very least, no further elderly people will be subjected to the poor quality care being provided in the home.

The second power in the Bill will apply only in relation to nursing homes with infrastructure costs which are less than the SAM, and will apply only during the transition period to the new standard funding arrangements. For those homes with infrastructure costs below the SAM, the Commonwealth intends that the additional income gained as the infrastructure cost component of a home's fee is moved upwards to the SAM will be used to improve the quality of care provided, where this is not already at a satisfactory level.

Where a home with unsatisfactory care standards receives an increase in infrastructure funding but does not use this additional income to improve care, it would be unjustifiable for that home to receive further increases in funding until the quality of care improves. Accordingly, the Bill gives the Minister the power to withhold increases in infrastructure funding until the home meets the gazetted care standards. Revenue lost would not be made up retrospectively in these cases even where the proprietor subsequently agrees to improve care standards.

The two additional powers are designed to indicate to providers that a persistent pattern of poor quality care will result in action being taken to protect nursing home residents. The use of these powers is seen as a more acceptable and workable approach to seeking compliance with the standards required.

Because of the desirability of involving industry, State Government, consumer and professional interests in the monitoring of nursing home performance-nursing homes after all are community facilities which are of enormous significance in the care of our frail aged people-the Minister for Community Care Services proposes to establish a peer review mechanism involving these groups to review recommendations to exercise the new powers.

Industry and consumer bodies have made the point in consultations regarding the new standards that any review and appeal mechanisms should be speedy and effective and be resourced with appropriately skilled professional and other suitably experienced personnel. Industry bodies have also rejected a remote and legalistic approach to solving the problems which arise when poor care practices are identified and have stressed the need for professional scrutiny in these areas. The Minister for Community Services has heeded those views and proposes to create a Nursing Home Standards Review Panel in each State and Territory. Discussions are to be held with State Governments on the formation of these Panels and it is likely at least one Panel will be established on a pilot basis in the near future. The pilot should serve as a proving ground for this new approach and provide guidance on establishing similar bodies in other States.

The Bill also introduces a new mechanism under the National Health Act 1953, in addition to the existing mechanism for the approval of applications for admission to an approved nursing home. This new mechanism will assist the Government in achieving its stated intention that only those who require the level of care available in a nursing home will be admitted to or remain in a nursing home. It has two elements.

First, Commonwealth benefits will be payable only in respect of a person who is approved by the Minister as requiring nursing home care. Second, the Minister will have the power to reassess, at any time, a nursing home resident's need for nursing care and to stop payment of Commonwealth benefit in respect of that resident where the Minister determines that the resident no longer needs nursing home care and that other, more appropriate care is available.

This second mechanism recognises that a person's condition can change over time and that, for many people, admission to a nursing home need not be a one-way street. As a result of the specialised nursing care and, in some cases, rehabilitation provided in a nursing home, a person's condition (for example, in the case of a stroke) can improve to the point where that level of care is no longer needed. Such a person is likely to find the nursing home environment over-protective and dependency-creating, which could work against any further rehabilitation.

Where it is found that a resident no longer requires nursing home care, he or she and any other appropriate people (for example, carers, relatives) will be counselled and given every assistance to find the necessary appropriate accommodation and support services.

In addition, the length of time for which the approval of an application for admission to an approved nursing home remains valid will be limited. Where a person is not admitted to a nursing home within a specific period, and still wishes to be approved for admission purposes, that person will be required to have his or her need for nursing home care confirmed.

These conditions will apply, in the longer term, to both Government and non-government nursing homes. However, a distinction is drawn in the Bill for the commencement of these measures in the case of Government homes, as negotiations are currently occurring with State Governments to set up the appropriate administrative mechanisms.

The Bill will also amend the current mechanism under the National Health Act 1953 for controlling the admission of people to approved nursing homes in emergency situations to ensure that such admissions are not used to subvert the normal admission control system.

First, emergency admissions are to be notified as soon as practicable to allow the Minister or his or her delegate to establish that an emergency has occurred. Then an application in accordance with the normal approval process is to be made within three working days, unless special circumstances exist which prevent the deadline from being met. This will ensure that a judgment as to whether the person was in need of nursing home care at the time of the emergency admission can reasonably be formed.

Where an application made within the prescribed time period is approved, Commonwealth benefits will be payable from the date of admission. However, where an application is made outside the prescribed period and subsequently approved, Commonwealth benefits will be paid only from the date of approval.

The Bill will also make two amendments to the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954. The first of these amendments will enable the current value of donated land and other land acquired by an eligible organisation to be used in connection with an approved home under that Act, to be counted as part of the matching funds of the organisation. The second will enable provisions to be included in agreements entered into under the Act under which the Commonwealth may recover the value in real terms of a capital grant where the agreement has been breached.

Finally, during the Senate debate on the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Act 1986, the then Opposition spokesperson on Community Services moved two amendments to omit ``or otherwise'' from new sub-section 40ad (1ab) and 40ad (1ad) of the National Health Act 1953. The then Minister for Community Services, Senator Grimes, undertook to seek and find an alternative way of wording these provisions, and on this basis the two amendments were withdrawn. This Bill therefore contains measures to remedy those perceived defects.
The new financial arrangements for nursing homes are expected to result in increased expenditure of $3m in 1987/88 and $14m in 1988/89.
The other measures in the Bill have no readily quantifiable financial impact, although it is expected that there will be some very small savings in administrative costs.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Messner) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, I present the Committee's report on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1986, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The Committee's inquiry on this matter relates to only two of the many proposals in this Bill. Those two proposals are for the use of short term redeemable preference shares and the payment of provisional tax by quarterly instalments. The majority of submissions to the Committee, apart from the one by the Commissioner of Taxation, expressed a similar viewpoint about the clauses relating to short term finance arrangements. They claimed that the amendments proposed by the Bill went further than the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of 7 April in two respects: They applied to shares other than redeemable preference shares and they applied to shares issued before the date of the announcement.

The Committee agrees with the Australian Taxation Office that it could not be construed from the Treasurer's announcement that the intention of the Government was to limit the forthcoming legislation exclusively to redeemable preference shares so named; rather, the Committee believes that the Government's intention was to highlight a particular concern relating to the abuse of the section 46 rebate and to foreshadow the necessary legislative change in that area. The Committee is naturally concerned that there was a considerable delay between the Treasurer's Press release of 7 April 1986 and the eventual introduction of the Bill. The undesirability of such a delay is acknowledged by the Australian Taxation Office.

The Committee believes that it is important that legislation, particularly in relation to tax matters, be introduced at the earliest practicable date after its announcement to ensure that as much certainty as possible is provided to the taxpaying community. However, the Committee also believes that if there is an objectionable exploitation of the taxation system, prompt government action to deal with it is essential and an announcement should not be delayed until the time the legislation is drafted. Even if the objections to the legislation were accepted, the Committee adopts the view that the terms of the Bill are necessary and justifiable to address fully and fairly the mischief indicated in the Press release.

The Committee considers that those who sought to rely on a narrow interpretation of the announcement deliberately took a risk that the foreshadowed Bill might not be as complete in its outlawing of the tax avoidance practice as would obviously be necessary. Their attempt to exploit a possible gap did not pay off. The Committee believes that there is also a matter of fairness involved. To amend the Bill to allow exemption for those who may have sought to take advantage of a possible loophole could be seen to be unfair to all those who abided by what they regarded as the clear intention of the policy as announced by the treasurer. It should be noted that submissions objecting to the terms of the Bill were received from only seven firms and a sub-committee of the Law Council of Australia.

The Committee did not receive a lot of comment on the question of instalments of provisional tax, although it received perhaps expected criticism from some who saw themselves as being negatively affected by it. But the Committee believes that the Taxation Office and the Bill deal adequately with those who have fluctuating income. In the last chapter of the report the Committee indicates its responses to each of the terms of reference that it was given. It reports:
. . . that the provisions of the Bill relating to short-term redeemable shares do not extend beyond a fair and reasonable interpretation of the terms of the announcement of 7 April 1986;
That persons will therefore not have their rights retrospectively affected by the passage of the Bill in its present form;
That there is therefore no need for the Bill to be amended;

That the quarterly payment of provisional tax will not be unduly onerous on provisional taxpayers whose income is subject to fluctuations throughout the year, and therefore there is no need for the Bill to be amended-
on that ground either-
The Committee, therefore, recommends that the Senate proceed to pass the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1986.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, I would like to speak briefly to the report at this stage and to thank our Chairman, Senator Coates, for his tabling of the report on the Committee's behalf and for his statement. Although it will be clear to honourable senators when they read the report, I draw to their attention that three of the six members of the Committee in fact dissented from the Committee's report insofar as its application to redeemable preference shares was concerned. In other words, the Committee was divided equally 3:3 on the redeemable preference shares issue. Senator Vanstone, Senator Vigor and I were the signatories to that dissenting report. Senator Vigor also had an additional comment, which he will no doubt speak to, in relation to provisional tax.

SPEECH.PARA: To us the issue of redeemable preference shares and the provisions of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1986, so far as they relate to redeemable preference shares, raise two fundamental issues which I think are of great importance in principle to this Parliament. The first one is the issue to which Senator Coates alluded-the delay between the announcement by the Government, in the form of a Press release by the Treasurer, and the bringing into the Parliament of the Bill to give effect to the Treasurer's Press release. In this case we had a delay of 7 1/2 months. That, in today's terms, is not in fact an inordinate delay. The very worrying trend by this Government in respect of the Parliament, and therefore the total community, is the long time that frequently elapses between the announcement by the Government of its intent to legislate and the sighting for the first time of the proposed legislation.

We have reached the stage, and it has been commented on by the Finance and Government Operations Committee and by many other committees of the Parliament-here I am sure I speak in a bipartisan sense-where we are very much running the risk of having government and legislation by Press release. That, in my view, is a very dangerous tendency because it has several major implications. The first is that if the legislation that is brought in does not exactly reflect the Press release intent statement the Government will have created a lengthy period of very bad uncertainty for the people who are affected by the particular measure. Secondly, there is the implication that the government of the day regards the Parliament as a body simply, in due course, to rubber stamp what the Executive Government had many months earlier, in this case 7 1/2 months, decreed would be the case. We have seen some notable examples in recent days of people in the community acting on the basis of Government statements of intent rather than on the legislation which has been introduced or which is proposed to be introduced. So this question of governing by Press release, not even by a statement in the Parliament but by a Press release which is issued outside the Parliament, and then having inordinate delays in bringing the legislation in, I think is a matter of the gravest concern. I believe that as parliamentarians we ought to be doing much more than we have been doing to insist that the government of the day-and I say this regardless of which party is in office-bring its legislation in much closer to the announcement of the intent of its proposals. That is a problem, and I think it is a fundamental one that pervades this whole area of government by Press release.

The second issue, and the one that in this case is equally worrying, is that in the view of Senator Vanstone, Senator Vigor and me the legislation that was brought in on, I think, 28 November was wider in its application than the Press release that the Treasurer put out on 7 April 1986. In our view the wider net that the legislation encompasses, relative to the Press release, means that there is a significant element of retrospectivity in this legislation, because the legislation backdates to the date of the Treasurer's Press release of 7 April. Indeed, officers of the Australian Taxation Office, who gave evidence-and for that I thank them-to the Committee said:
To the extent that the announcement-
that is, the 7 April Press release-
was not as precise in its terms as the legislation is there has to be acknowledged that there is a degree of retrospectivity.

Not only did the three members of the Finance and Government Operations Committee and the officers of the Australian Taxation Office accept and recognise that element of retrospectivity, but so too did the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. When it looked at the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) it also concluded that the relevant clauses were retrospective, and drew the attention of the Senate to this.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a general objection.
—Yes, that is true.
—It did not deal with the issues that the Committee covered.
—Yes, but they are really the same point.
—Merely the fact that it dated from a Press statement.

—I would like to look at that more closely. The honourable senator may be right. Senator Vanstone, Senator Vigor and I agreed with the Government's desire to close undesirable loopholes in the taxation system. There is no issue between us and other members of the Committee in that respect. But what we do find objectionable, and what we cannot agree to, is that this should be done through retrospective legislation. That is what this aspect of the Bill quite unequivocally is. I sympathise with the representatives of the Taxation Office and with the drafters of the legislation that the legislation does not marry up exactly with the Treasurer's Press statement. The fact that it does not is something that the Parliament of this country cannot turn a blind eye to. We must have the drafting of Press statements and the drafting of the legislation, if we are to have them both, in line with one another. If honest people going about their daily commercial or other business in the community are not able to feel confident that what is said in an official Government Press release, by a very senior Minister, particularly someone such as the Treasurer, in advance of legislation coming in, is the case and will be the case when that legislation does come in, how on earth can anyone reasonably go about his or her normal commercial activities? I believe that this Bill gives an example of a fundamental problem in the form of retrospectivity. For those two reasons we have a dissenting report from three of the six senators. I draw that to the attention of the Senator. Obviously we will want to come back to that later. Therefore, I will continue my remarks at a later date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to answer a couple of issues raised by Senator Short, but I will not delay the Senate too long over them. In terms of principles of government and parliamentary operation, I think that the other view should be put in this chamber in a fairly forthright and, I hope, brief way.
—Robust.

—Not robust, as Senator Coates said, but at least in a very simple way so that the people dealing with these sorts of issues understand that the principles behind them are in fact very simple. The first one that I wish to address is the question of the so-called accusation of government by Press release. The one thing that stands out in this Government's record in terms of not only its taxation policy but also in a number of other areas of major reform is the fact that it has not acted in an ad hoc way. It has laid down a manifesto about the way that it wants to operate, the principles that underlie its operation and where it is going. For example, we set down the parameters of the tax debate at the Taxation Summit. We have indicated quite clearly the major reforms that we intend to pursue; and we have indicated quite clearly the parameters of tax reform within which we intend to work.

SPEECH.PARA: One area that we have made quite clear in our approach to taxation law reform relates to so-called retrospectivity or what I would call due warning. It seems to me that there is a problem in the way that we have been handling tax reform in this country over the past decade or so, and it is simply this: Every reform brought in by a government to close loopholes where there have been particular abuses of taxation legislation has seen sharp operators paying the best accountants and corporate lawyers in the country to rearrange their operations in such a way as to beat those amendments which have been designed to overcome abuses. In this particular case I have to ask the question: Should the advantage in business always go to those people who can afford the best corporate lawyers and to those people who can afford the top accountants who are constantly on retainer to ensure that every loophole in the legislation is taken advantage of prior to amending legislation coming into this place.

This is an important matter for a government of this type, simply because we have made very plain what are our basic parameters in relation to tax reform. We have said: `These are the abuses, these are the changes and these are the things that we intend to do'. As a matter of principle, we have clearly let people know literally months in advance about the sorts of things that we intend to do. Of course the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is not governing by Press release; he is simply indicating what will be the major changes. If, for example, businesses wish to take advantage of what they see as loopholes and they wish to hire the best corporate lawyers and accountants to advise them about taking advantage of those loopholes before they are closed, they are quite free to do so. Of course, the only difference is that when their clients are caught I believe they have little right to squeal about the fact that they have tried to get through a loophole only to find it close on them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the same with television?

—That would be a problem if, for example, this Government operated like the Fraser Government by bringing in changes to tax law only when it was forced to do so as a result of the clamour from the community at large for a degree of fairness. I can refer to the bottom of the harbour legislation where finally the Treasurer of the day acted when community pressure was so overwhelming that he had to bring in reforms and changes to cut off certain avenues. There was no retrospectivity involved so the sharp accountants and the sharp businesses simply changed their operations to avoid being caught by the trap set by the then Treasurer. We do not intend to be caught in the same sort of syndrome.

SPEECH.PARA: Very early in the piece we announced our major tax reforms; and we announced the specific areas of intent. Of course, we are not going to be able to put them in the absolute detail required in any particular Bill that comes into this place. The intentions are very clear. In that regard, let us look at something that the Australian Taxation Office has said. I believe that the quotation from the Tax Office, as set out on page 15 of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1986, is germane to everything we are discussing today. The report states:
The policy from this press release-
that is, the policy from the press release put out by the Treasurer of the day-

is very clear. The policy is that the government was concerned at the loss of revenue by the misuse of a section 46 rebate and by substituting dividends for interest, that is exactly what this legislation does. Anyone that used shares acquired afterwards is only using a very literal interpretation of those words and ignoring what is a plain policy.

That is the point that I wish to make: If one tries to get through a loophole in a Press release, which is after all a statement of principle and of some general intent, as a consumer of credit and as an operator within the business and taxation system one takes pot luck. As I said, there is no point coming into this chamber through various committees and squealing about one's bad luck.

The second point that I wish to make-and I have already referred to it to some extent-is that there are general principles surrounding tax legislation, and we believe that they should be propounded openly and with proper warning by the government of the day. For example, does this chamber prefer, as has been the case with past governments, legislation to be prepared in secret by the Australian Taxation Office, rushed through Cabinet and then dumped into Parliament at the last minute without due warning so that every business is then forced to reorder its arrangements without proper warning? Does this Parliament insist that taxation law reform should operate in that way? If this Parliament insists that taxation laws should operate in that way, by all means go out and try and re-elect a Liberal and National party Government, because that is the sort of thing that one will get once again. Such a government will work in tax reform areas only when community pressure becomes so strong that it has to do something about it, albeit reluctantly and, even then, it will botch the job as we saw with the bottom of the harbour legislation.

This Government and I support the principle of long advanced warnings for any changes to tax reform. Those people who intend to take advantage of any loopholes that they see in either the original Press announcements or at a later stage when legislation is in draft form or as it comes into Parliament do so knowing that it is on their heads. They have to regard it as a business risk; and their advisers in accountancy firms who are no doubt paid very well to do that will suffer some loss of professional dignity and credibility. TALK.START.PARA: —I had not planned to talk today but, having heard Senator Aulich, there are some points that need to be answered. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise because of Senator Aulich's remarks earlier tonight. I notice that he is not in the chamber now. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations I present the report on the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This fairly small sales tax Bill was referred to the Committee in December last year. The main reason it was referred was that clause 3 of the Bill would insert a new sub-section 5 (1a) in the Act, which is intended to make it clear that, where goods are described in clear terms in an item or sub-item of one of the taxing schedules and might be argued as being also covered by a general description in an item or sub-item in the First Schedule-the exemption Schedule-the goods are not covered by the First Schedule, but by the relevant taxing schedule. The amendment would give legislative effect to the rule of statutory interpretation that provides that a specific item overrides a generally expressed item.

In response to the query about the problem of defining the word `specific' and `general', the Australian Taxation Office indicated that parliamentary counsel regarded `specific' as plain English not requiring further definition that was clearer than the word itself. After the hearing that the Committee held, the Second Commissioner, Mr Nolan, advised the Committee that after further thorough consideration he confirmed the view he gave at the Committee's hearing that the proposal should not be amended. He said:

Following the Committee's suggestion, we have looked closely at the structure of the clause. In consultation with Parliamentary Counsel we tested out various alternative combinations of words but, in the result, unable to offer anything that, in our view, would better convey the intention of Clause 3 while remaining sufficiently general to cover the range of cases where there could be conflict between the First and other Schedules . . . The review has confirmed us in the opinion that the clause is sound and that its enactment would not lead to any untoward consequences for sales taxpayers.

Therefore the Committee recommends that the Senate proceed to pass the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986. The amendments proposed in clause 3 should be enacted to ensure that as little doubt as possible exists as to the legislature's intention regarding interpretation of the principal Act. While administration and interpretation of the Act may continue to cause differences over questions of classification, definition and description-and that is inevitable-the Committee believes that the amendment should be passed to confirm that the Taxation Office's interpretation has Parliament's support. The Committee also believes that the Bill should be passed to ensure prompt enactment of clause 4 to amend the existing exemption for the Governor-General, State governors and members of their families and staff. Enactment of the clause will also mean that the sales tax legislation again is consistent with relevant customs and excise legislation. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report on the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986 is similar to the report that we have just debated in the sense that a dissenting view was again expressed by three of the six members of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. The three senators who dissent are Senator Vanstone, Senator Vigor and I. The problems raised in this Bill are, I think, of a less contentious nature than those in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) that we have just debated. Nevertheless, there are at least one or two important issues of principle involved in this Bill to which Senator Vanstone, Senator Vigor and I want to draw the attention of the Senate. For that reason, I draw particular attention to the addendum to the report which gives our views. Firstly, let me say that we have no dis- agreement at all with clause 4 of the Bill, which, as Senator Coates said, would amend the First Schedule of the sales tax law to give the Governor-General, the State Governors and their families and members of staff who are not Australian citizens similar treatment to the rest of the community in relation to importation and liability to sales tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter with which we have dispute relates to clause 3 of the Bill which, as Senator Coates has said, would insert a new sub-section 5 (1a) into the Act, the intention being to make it clear that, where goods are described in clear terms in an item or sub-item of one of the taxing schedules, and might be argued as being also covered by a general description in an item or a sub-item in the First Schedule, which is the exemption schedule, the goods are not covered by the First Schedule but rather by the relevant taxing schedule. In effect, that very tortuous form of wording means that the amendment would give legislative effect to the rule of statutory interpretation that provides that a specific item overrides a generally expressed item.

The Commissioner of Taxation put forward several reasons why clause 3 should be included in the Bill. They are listed in our report. They say in summary form that, to use the Commissioner's words, the amendment `would add more elegance' to a particularly complex body of legislation; that it would remove any doubts for practitioners and taxpayers as to the rules of interpretation to be employed by the Australian Taxation Office; and that it would put an end to frivolous and unreasonable claims for exemption.

On the other hand, the Committee received several submissions which strongly rejected these assertions and, on the contrary, claimed that the amendment would result in a number of new classification, interpretation and definitional problems; that the amendment would, contrary to the Taxation Office's claim, enact an interpretation that differed from the Taxation Office's previous interpretation; and that it would make the job of self-assessment of liability by sales taxpayers, and those advising them, more uncertain and costly.

I think it would be true to say that the Committee-certainly Senator Vanstone, Senator Vigor and I-was not convinced of the strength of the Commissioner's argument without necessarily drawing a judgment on the objections which were raised and which I have just mentioned. The difficulty that we found was the lack of real reason put forward by the Taxation Office for the need for clause 3. Indeed, if I may, I quote briefly from some of the evidence given by officials of the Taxation Office to the Committee:

If it were decided not to proceed with the amendment, that would not alter the ATO's approach to administration of the sales tax law. Indeed, that will be the case if the amendment is agreed to. To that extent the amendment is not strictly necessary.

That raises an important point of principle. The Government claims and proclaims loudly that it is doing all it can to reduce regulation and additional legislation, to get off the back of businesses in the community, to make the law simpler, and so on and so forth; and the Opposition accepts that as a highly desirable objective. I would therefore argue strongly that, if we are to add still further to the complexity of the law, be it in the area of sales tax or anywhere else, and if we are going to add to the legislative burden facing people there must be a good, strong, well argued and compelling reason for the need for that legislation. Half of the members of the Committee were strongly of the view that no compelling case had been made for the necessity for this amendment. According to the Taxation Office officials, it will not have any effect on the administration of the Act. It will not have any revenue effect one way or the other. Therefore, quite rightly, we would agree with the Taxation Office when it says that it is not strictly necessary. It is about time that this Parliament started saying that enough is enough when legislation is brought into this place that does not add anything other than a whole volume of words and more complexity to an already complex and exceedingly overlegislated nation. It is for that reason, as a matter of principle, that Senator Vanstone, Senator Vigor and I object to clause 3. We see no reason whatsoever for it; and if there is no compelling reason put forward, we do not think it should be accepted.

One or two other matters arose in the Committee's consideration. In particular, there was debate on the question of the use of the words `namely' and `including' in the sales tax legislation. As I understand it, sales tax legislation nowadays frequently uses the word `namely' in a way that the Taxation Office would in effect define as `including'-I think I am right in that. It is a very confusing issue, one that needs to be cleared up. The Opposition would not wish to pursue it too much further here, because the Taxation Office has advised the Committee that it will be undertaking a broad review of the complete area of sales tax legislation within the next 12 months. We would assume automatically that that review would catch up with this question of the use of `namely' and `including'. I draw it to the attention of the Senate because, as the legislation currently stands, the situation is rather confused. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1987[COGNATE BILLS:ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL 1986ABORIGINAL LAND (LAKE CONDAH AND FRAMLINGHAM FOREST) BILL 1987ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER HERITAGE PROTECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1987]
ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating four Bills-the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987, the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1986, the Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Bill 1987 and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Amendment Bill 1987. I will begin my contribution to this second reading debate by addressing some very brief remarks to the first of those Bills, the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987. When the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) introduced the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1986 in October last year he pointed out that a number of matters were being deferred pending clarification of certain problems. The Government has now brought forward this proposal which includes guidelines for exploration and mining on Aboriginal land. As the Minister has said, the compromises that have been reached may not please everybody. The Australian Democrats remain concerned about certain aspects of the Bill which have been raised with us in our extensive consultations with Aboriginal groups, and we will be pursuing these matters in detail later in the debate and during the Committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to address the bulk of my remarks to the third and fourth Bills. Initially I refer to the Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Bill. I remind the Senate that these two bills in this cognate debate come to the Senate as a result of legislation which at first had been proposed in the Victorian Parliament. As a senator from Victoria, I have taken a considerable interest in these Bills, both at the time the originating Bills were proposed in the Victorian Parliament and since the Victorian Government announced its intention to pursue them in the Federal Parliament.

Earlier today Senator Zakharov said that the Victorian Legislative Council is just like the Senate, in that the Government of Victoria does not have a majority in that upper House. I suggest that that is only partly true. Certainly it is true that the Victorian Labor Government does not have a majority in its upper House as the Hawke Federal Government does not have a majority in this upper House. There is a significant difference, particularly in relation to Bills such as Aboriginal land rights Bills and Aboriginal heritage Bills which we have before us today, and that is that the Australian Democrats do not have a presence in the Legislative Council of the Victorian Parliament. If we had the balance of power there I believe that we would not be debating these Bills here today. The issue of land rights for two particular Aboriginal communities in Victoria and the issue of Aboriginal heritage in Victoria came before the Victorian Parliament after extensive consultation with the Victorian Aboriginal community. The Australian Democrats have a strong commitment to this type of legislation. As I said, I believe that we would not be debating these Bills today if the similarities between the Victorian upper House and this one were closer in relation to the position of the Australian Democrats. I believe confidently that after the next State election in Victoria there will be a much greater similarity between the two Houses.

Specifically in relation to the Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Bill 1987, I would say quite categorically that we are appalled at the obstructionist, unjust and spurious so-called State rights position which has been taken by the Victorian division of the Liberal Party of Australia under its Leader, Jeff Kennett, and which led to this Bill having to be dealt with by the Federal Parliament rather than the Victorian Parliament. I clearly recall in January this year reading newspaper reports and listening to radio interviews in which the Leader of the Opposition in Victoria, Mr Kennett, beat his breasts and claimed wildly and loudly that he would tour Victoria and get the people of that State to rise up against what he called the injustice of granting inalienable freehold title to the Aboriginal people of Condah and Framlingham.

The Victorian divisions of the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia quite simply chose not to understand or accept that to Aboriginal people ownership of land means something different from what it means to most white people. The Kerrup-Jmara people of Condah and the Kirrae Whurrong people of Framlingham, like their sisters and brothers throughout Australia, belong to the land. They do not see land as something to be privately possessed by individuals or real estate agents, to be carved up and sold to the highest bidder to be turned into supermarkets, industrial estates or whatever. The Australian Democrats' principle which guides the formulation of our Aboriginal affairs policy states:
To Aboriginal people, the land is their very life. The people and the land are indivisible. The land is the spirit of the people.
This view is a far cry from the paternalistic, Anglo-Saxon and market-oriented views held by the Liberals and the Nationals as they expressed it in the context of the Victorian legislation.

After a few heady days of waving his hands in the air Jeff Kennett fell flat on his face. The people of Victoria were not deceived and he clearly did not have their support, as he made his whistle-stop tours. Indeed, I believe that most people in Victoria see the absolute justice in returning land now to those from whom it was take in the past. As well, in the 1968 Federal referendum the Australian people voted in favour of giving the Federal government responsibility for Aboriginal issues such as land rights. I understand that more than 90 per cent of the people of Victoria supported this question that was proposed in the referendum.

When the impasse in the Victorian Parliament occurred earlier this year my colleague Senator Macklin, the Democrats spokesman on Aboriginal Affairs, and I, as an Australian Democrats senator for Victoria, issued a joint Press release giving our agreement in principle to allowing the speedy passage of the Federal legislation, pending, of course, our examination of the contents of the Bills which we understood would have to be redrafted for passage through the Federal Parliament and noting that the mindless obstructionism of the Victorian Opposition in the Legislative Council clearly showed the need for urgent electoral reform and a Democrat presence in the upper House in that State.

From the mid-nineteenth century the Aboriginal people of the Framlingham Forest area witnessed the gradual selling off or leasing of parts of their land. This continued until the 1950s. At Lake Condah the Aboriginal people were dispossessed of their land in a slightly different way, with their reserve officially closing in the early twentieth century and finally being divvied up for soldier settlement after World War II. Now, some three decades later and after some eight years of hard work, consultation and negotiation with bureaucracies, the Government and the wider community, we are finally seeing some justice for the people of Condah and Framlingham-justice which in this case takes the form of returning Aboriginal land to Aboriginal people.

Just how much land are we talking about? For Condah it is only some 55 hectares of crown land and for Framlingham it is just over 1,100 hectares. I have been told by some of the Aboriginal women of Condah that prior to colonisation their land covered some 12,000 square kilometres. Those who oppose Aboriginal land rights should be ashamed of their attitude when they hear how the parcel of land has diminished. The scare tactics of opponents of this kind of legislation, who say that the Aboriginal community is likely to take all land away from everybody, are shameful as well.

However, while the Australian Democrats support this legislation, we pass on to the Parliament the concern of the Kerrup-Jmara and the Kirrae Whurrong communities that they would have preferred the Federal Government to have introduced, in the case of the land rights legislation, two Bills to cover the two areas of land rather than this one Bill, as was the case in the Victorian Parliament where this action originated. After speaking with members from both Aboriginal communities, we share their view and regret that the Federal Government did not do as the Victorian Government had done, which was to treat the two communities as two distinct communities and provide two distinct pieces of legislation.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 6.30 p.m., pursuant to sessional order, I put the question:
