SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise, after an exhausting three-week sitting, because this week we have commemorated an important anniversary for Australia and I think that something should be said about it. On 12 May-that is, last Tuesday evening, when Australians were bracing themselves in anticipation of the May economic statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-a fleet of square riggers, the ships comprising the First Fleet re-enactment squadron, were riding at anchor on the Motherbank off the Isle of Wight. Yesterday, Wednesday 13 May, with the swelling of the morning tide on the Solent the ships hoisted their sails, weighed anchor, caught the breeze and made their stately way past thousands of people lining the Portsmouth foreshores and set their compasses for Teneriffe, the first port of call on the eight-month voyage to Sydney Harbour. As the re-enactment of the First Fleet voyage jibed and beat its way past the Isle of Wight, the ships were reviewed by the Queen from the deck of HMS Sirius, the Royal Navy vessel named after the convoy escort on the original First Fleet. When the review was completed the signal was hoisted on the command ship, `proceed to your intended destination'. Thus the fleet made its way into the English Channel and towards Australia. The original First Fleet over 200 years ago hoisted the same signal and the fleet made its way to what was then known as Botany Bay, the proposed thief colony in New South Wales or what has latterly been called the `fatal shore'.

SPEECH.PARA: Thus we saw this week the first major event in the celebration of Australia's Bicentennial. Over the remaining months of this year and throughout next year we Australians will celebrate 200 years of European settlement in this country. I would prefer to celebrate the anniversary of Federation in Australia rather than European colonisation of this country, but since we are celebrating the Bicentennial we should also commemorate an anniversary which has been overlooked in the sailing of the First Fleet re-enactment but which has a particular pertinence still for Australia, 200 years after that first sailing. I am indebted to Robert Hughes, author of the timely but frightening book, The Fatal Shore, to be reminded that, when Commander Phillip, later to be Governor Phillip, hoisted the first signal `proceed to your destination' to the original First Fleet, no vessel moved. The naval vessels got under way, but not the transports. No sail filled and no capstan turned on the commercially chartered vessels comprising the first fleet.

The reason for the inactivity was that the sailors crewing the commercial ships had walked off the job in an industrial dispute. At the time there were no unions in Britain. The sailors involved were not unionised. Nor could workers combine in legally sanctioned unions in that country for more than half a century after that sailing. The act of the First Fleet sailors was illegal-grossly so-in the Britain of the Agricultural Revolution years, but it was an act of solidarity that could have seen the sailors transported along with the convicts in the hulks that comprised the First Fleet. Certainly, the ringleaders of that walk-off faced the gallows in the ultimate naval execution of mutiny. In other words, the sailors in the First Fleet faced far more hideous and callous penal clauses than even Joh Bjelke-Petersen could conceive of in the recently enacted legislation in Queensland.

However, the question that should be asked is: Why did those sailors take that action? That is the sort of question that I hope will be asked in the forthcoming weeks and months when we debate the industrial legislation that was put down in the House of Representatives today by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Ralph Willis. The question that should be asked is: Why do people voluntarily forgo income by going on strike? Why do they inflict upon themselves economic loss? What injustice, real or perceived, drives them to deprive themselves and their families of part or all of their wages? If we debated industrial relations from that point of view we would have an intelligent debate in this country. We should start with the first question: Why? If we did that we would avoid the disgusting perversion of rational debate that now threatens over this legislation that will shortly come to the Senate.

The first element of this debate is to paint unions as ogres. That type of debate blames the messenger for the problems, and seeks to claim that if the messenger were removed so would be the problem. But it is inconsistent with the free market thinking of the conservatives, if we use their own terms as the basis of the opening part of this argument. Conservatives argue that there is a right for free enterprise within civilised limits, but what they do not argue is that that right of free enterprise should be conceded to unions. They say that it goes only to companies which, after all, are only a combination of shareholders who have put up the money to finance the companies. Unions are a combination of workers who have put up their labour to make the companies, once financed, operative. The conservatives who espouse free market arguments should not rationally limit that view only to those who put up the money. In the forthcoming industrial relations debate in this country I would like to hear from the conservatives, who argue against unionists, an answer to the following question: Why do they discriminate and not include labour in their free market philosophies?

In Australian unions and employers concede the free enterprise notion in favour of regulation by an arbitral authority. In the Willis legislation introduced today the principle was enshrined quite properly that arbitration is the way to go in a civilised, enlightened community. It is a philosophy supported by employers, unionists, governments, and, throughout our history, by the people of Australia in all elections and votes on policies dealing with this matter.

Another argument used is a furphy which should be answered in the forthcoming debate, and that is that unions go on strike because union bosses-not the rank and file-require it. In starting this debate it is pertinent to point out that over the last 30 years laws have been enshrined in the statutes requiring unions to register their rules in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The union's rules are not necessarily the rules that unions choose; they are rules that are authorised and registered by the Commission in complying with the principles in the legislation as to what is reasonable, fair and democratic.

If there is an accusation against union rules, it should be an accusation against the Commission, not against the unions. If one looks at the record one will see that unions have a democratic structure. Union officials are politicians in that they are regularly elected and in that they need to satisfy their constituents who, after all, pay fees to maintain them in office. Therefore, if one takes the narrow, simplistic view of blaming the officials, the representatives of those in dispute, one is again shooting the messenger. In saying that, I am not saying that everything is always perfect, because this is an imperfect world dealing with human relations. Nevertheless, it is overwhelmingly the case and it is idle to argue otherwise.

If people believe that penalties are the way to go and refuse to face the reality of the particular grievances in an industrial dispute, they will face the same problems that the authorities faced when the First Fleet sailors walked off and faced the gallows as the ultimate penal sanction. We have to look at the issue that gave rise to their dispute. In the case of the First Fleet, the sailors had not been paid for nine weeks. The owners of the vessels chartered to the Admiralty to transport the convicts to Australia were private owners. They chartered their vessels at a rate of tonnage and months employed by the Admiralty. They hired and paid the crews, but the dispute was caused by the fact that the crews had not been paid for nine weeks prior to departure. The owners assured the crews that they would be paid when the vessels were at sea. The crews knew from bitter experience that therefore all their services-their rum, tobacco, clothing and the things that they purchased from the ships' stores-would be bought from a monopoly source at inflated prices. They demanded their wages before they left Portsmouth so that they could buy the goods they needed for the long voyage of eight months to Australia at ordinary market rates in the town and not at inflated prices charged by the employers. If we look at the cause of the walk-off of the First Fleet sailors, we would say from this distance of history that objectively they were right. Only those who would argue that workers are commodities and should be traded would take the owners' view from this perspective.

Their grievance, however, is a grievance from which we still suffer today. The Senate yesterday debated papers, one of which related to the report of the Arbitration Inspectorate for the period 1 July 1985 to 30 June 1986. I commend honourable senators to the speech of Senator Foreman when that paper came before the Senate. That speech was an exemplary dissertation on the reason why an Arbitration Inspectorate exists, which is to police the awards of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, awards which have the force of law in that they arise after proceedings and are given assent by the Commission, which is a statutory body that is independent of government. The speech explained why the Inspectorate polices the Arbitration Act itself. On page 11 of the report of the Arbitration Inspectorate one sees the heading `Award breaches and penalties imposed'. I wish to quote the four points listed in paragraph 38 which refer to the activities of the Inspectorate in recovering moneys outstanding to workers over the past 12 months. The first point states that 28,686 prima facie breaches of Federal awards were detected. The second point indicates that $4,069,949 was paid to 18,251 employees by 4,684 employers in voluntary termination of award breaches. The third point states that, of 79 award breaches involving 11 employers referred for prosecution, one was withdrawn and the remainder were found proven by the courts. I interpolate that there is a perfect prosecution record in the past 12 months by the Inspectorate against employers on complaints received and acted on by the Inspectorate. The final point under that paragraph indicates that penalties totalling $5,420 were imposed by the courts, which also made orders for payments of $7,519.

In other words, the industrial position in Australia, as reported upon by the Inspectorate, is a record of industrial lawlessness by employers in not honouring award obligations imposed on them by a fair arbitration system to which they have rights as well as do the unions. The $4m-plus recovered is but the tip of a large iceberg because that figure does not indicate what unions, in direct negotiations with employers, have recovered on behalf of their members. I would assert that the amount recovered by unions vastly outweighs the amount recovered by the Inspectorate. Nor does the figure include amounts that have never been recovered, and will not be recovered, because workers are in a position where they do not resort to the Inspectorate or are intimidated by employers. They are in a weak industrial position or have no unions to represent them. That is the classic case in areas of female employment, youth employment, particularly in fast food outlets, Aboriginal employment and a lot of migrant employment. It highlights the degree of industrial lawlessness by employers-a subject of which we hear little in industrial relations debates today. It is the subject on which the sailors in the First Fleet went on strike in what in feudal England was an illegal act.

In the next weeks and months the debate on industrial relations will flow on both chambers of this Parliament from the Bill which has been presented today by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis. Part of that debate will focus-I believe unnecessarily-on the role of sanctions and penalties in industrial relations. Indeed, there are sanctions and penalties in the legislation presented by the Minister in the House of Representatives. But if we debate just that we miss the whole point of how to achieve an industrial relations system which will improve the regulation of relations in the workplace. It is often felt that it is not important to consider why people take action so long as a host of penalties are stored up to deter or coerce them from taking action. Therefore, we never discover whether the reasons for their taking that action are a real injustice or an injustice that can be mediated upon and thus resolved, or something that is not an injustice at all. If we believe in coercion in industrial relations, as does the Queensland Premier and as do Opposition members by their record in respect of the Arbitration Act or the Trade Practices Act, we shall be operating on the basis of the same nineteenth century philosophy as gave rise to the dispute that bedevilled the sailing of the First Fleet.

I hope that in the ensuing debate the ghosts of the First Fleet sailors will be honoured in the memory by the conduct of a rational debate which will concentrate on rational issues. It should concentrate on why people in the workplace take the actions they do and on the best way to resolve such matters in a humane and reasonable way for all parties. If that becomes the benchmark of the debate, all the politicians in both Houses of this Parliament will carry out a service for Australia in the Bicentennial year which the victims in the First Fleet did not have carried out for them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 March 1987 (Hansard, page 1300) Senator Messner asked me as the Minister representing the Attorney-General the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer him to an article that appeared in the Times on Sunday of 22 March concerning the reporting of an apparent decision by the Government to introduce a system to award costs in cases heard by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Has such a decision been made or has the Government reviewed proposals for the introduction of such a system? In particular, will the effect of such a measure be to discourage prospective complaints in seeking to have administrative decisions, particularly in relation to taxation assessments and related matters-I point out that these can be very small as well as somewhat larger-reviewed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal? This comes on top of the Government's disgraceful decision to impose a $200 filing fee for all matters heard by the AAT.
The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The decision referred to in the Times on Sunday article of 22 March 1987 was a decision the Government took that the unsuccessful party in AAT proceedings should bear the costs of the successful party, except in income maintenance cases. That decision has not been implemented, in view of the decision of the Government that there should be a general review of the procedures of the AAT.

The Attorney-General has established a Task Force to conduct the review and it has received a number of submissions concerning the awarding of costs in AAT proceedings. The Government will consider further, after examining the report of the Task Force, what is the most appropriate system for awarding costs in AAT proceedings.
